There are two interpretations of the gates of heaven not being opened, including that their deeds will not be accepted and will not reach Allah, no matter how great their deeds and efforts. Not only will their deeds and efforts not reach Allah, but their prayers and requests will also not reach Him. In another interpretation, according to Ibn 'Abbas, their souls will not be directly accepted by Allah, because Allah only accepts good words and righteous deeds, as He says:

"To Him ascends good speech, and righteous work raises it." (Fathir/35: 10)

Besides that, they will never enter Paradise. In this verse, Allah gives an analogy for them, that they will not enter Paradise unless a camel can enter the eye of a needle. Meaning, it is impossible for them to enter Paradise forever. Such is the recompense that Allah gives to those who sin in that way, namely those who deny the verses of Allah and refuse to accept them in an arrogant manner.
text.41:
This verse further clarifies their place in Hell. They will have mats and blankets made of fire. Allah says:

And indeed, Hell will encompass the disbelievers. (at-Taubah/9: 49)

That is the recompense given by Allah to those who wrong themselves and wrong others. Every disbeliever is included in the group of people who do wrong.
text.42:
This verse explains that those who believe and do righteous deeds according to their ability will be inhabitants of Paradise. This is a reward for their belief in Allah and their affirmation of the prophethood of Prophet Muhammad, who conveyed revelation and religious teachings, with full obedience performing all His commands and avoiding all His prohibitions. They will not be expelled from Paradise, and all the pleasures within will not be taken away forever.

Allah does not burden any soul beyond its capacity. All of Allah's commands and prohibitions are not heavy or burdensome. Righteous deeds that will make a person an inhabitant of Paradise are easy, not difficult or troublesome. The religion of Islam is a religion that is easy to practice, not a difficult one. It is easy to practice for men and women, old and young, and healthy and sick people, and even easy to practice for all levels of society, whenever and wherever they are.
text.43:
This verse explains how the state of the inhabitants of Paradise is vastly different from the state of the inhabitants of Hell, like day and night. The inhabitants of Paradise have no feelings of resentment or hatred. Allah removes these feelings of resentment and envy from their hearts. Allah cultivates feelings of love, gentleness, respect, and joy. In contrast to the inhabitants of Hell, they are hostile to one another, making demands, accusing each other, and humiliating each other. The inhabitants of Paradise enjoy themselves and rejoice in Paradise, beneath which rivers flow, but the inhabitants of Hell are in a state of distress and gloom, enveloped by blazing fire. The inhabitants of Paradise are always grateful and thankful, showing their happiness and joy.

They praise Allah who has given them guidance during their life in the world so that they become people who believe and do good deeds, which causes them to become inhabitants of Paradise. If it were not for Allah's guidance, they would certainly not believe in the Messenger of Allah, or they would become people who are unjust and disobedient. Because the Messenger was sent to bring true teachings, guiding his people to believe in Allah, the One and Almighty, and encouraging them to do good deeds. Then the inhabitants of Paradise hear a call from the angels, a very pleasant and joyful call, a call that is a form of honor and glory, namely, this is your place called Paradise, which Allah has bequeathed to you as a reward for the good deeds that you did during your life in the world.

Entering Paradise is a reward for good deeds based on faith in Allah. Also, because of the mercy of Allah. If the mercy of Allah did not exist, a person would certainly not enter Paradise, which is a place of pleasure that Allah has prepared for His servants who believe and do good deeds, but if there is no mercy from Allah, then a person will certainly not enter Paradise. Because good deeds are not comparable to the blessings of Paradise.

From the words "We have bequeathed" is contained the mercy of Allah. It is impossible for a person to enter Paradise, even if his good deeds are great, without the mercy of Allah for him. The Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said:

"The deeds (of anyone) will not admit him into Paradise." They (the Companions) asked, "Will not even you, O Messenger of Allah?" He said, "No, not even I, unless Allah bestows His mercy and grace upon me." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)
text.44: This verse explains that in the afterlife, a dialogue will occur between the inhabitants of Paradise and the inhabitants of Hell. This happens after the inhabitants of Paradise have settled in Paradise and the inhabitants of Hell have settled in Hell. The inhabitants of Paradise, with all the pleasures and delights they have obtained, and with radiant faces, turn their faces towards the inhabitants of Hell who are suffering because of their disobedience and disbelief in Allah and His Messenger, saying, "Indeed, we have obtained what Allah promised us, which was conveyed by His Messenger. We have obtained pleasure, eternal glory, the delights of which we cannot describe in Paradise. Have you obtained torment and punishment?" They answer, "Indeed, we are receiving torment, as was threatened to us through His Messenger." In the midst of such a conversation, a call is heard from the angels saying, "The curse of Allah is upon the wrongdoers who oppress themselves, who did not want to accept Allah's mercy during their time in the world, namely, entering the Paradise that Allah has promised."
text.45:
This verse explains who is meant by the unjust people (zalim). They are those who always try to prevent themselves or others from following the path of Allah as conveyed by the Messenger of Allah. Preventing the following of true religious teachings, in order to seek Allah's pleasure. Trying to mislead others from the right path.

In addition to that, those who try to distort religious teachings, not following the true teachings, are also included among the unjust. The methods they use for this purpose are various. Among the greatest sins is fostering the disease of shirk. Tawhid is changed into shirk by mixing the teachings of tawhid with the teachings of other religions in worship and prayer. Associating partners with Allah with idols and others, or making idols as a *washilah* (intermediary) to Allah, this act is included in shirk and is clearly forbidden. Allah says:

"And they were not commanded except to worship Allah, [being] sincere to Him in religion, inclining to truth, and to establish prayer and to give zakah. And that is the correct religion." (al-Bayyinah/98: 5)

Another way is by creating all kinds of doubts in religion, they excessively complicate the way to carry out various religious commands. So that people will gradually run away from religion. Actually, the unjust people are among those who do not believe in the Hereafter. They do not believe in the coming of the Day of Judgment, do not believe in the Day of Recompense and other things related to the Day of Judgment.
text.46:
This verse explains that between the inhabitants of Paradise and the inhabitants of Hell there is a very strong boundary. This boundary is in the form of a wall that does not allow either of them to exit or move places. Above this wall, there is a highest place, a place for those who have not yet been admitted to Paradise. They remain there awaiting Allah's decision. From that high place, they can see the inhabitants of Paradise and see the inhabitants of Hell. Both groups of inhabitants recognize each other by the signs on them. Like recognizing their faces which have been described by Allah in the Qur'an. Allah says:

On that Day some faces will be bright, laughing, rejoicing at good news; And other faces on that Day will be dust-stained, Overwhelmed with grimness. Those will be the disbelievers, the wicked ones. ('Abasa/80: 38-42)

Those who live in the high place above the boundary wall have good deeds that are balanced with their bad deeds, not yet able to enter Paradise, but not becoming inhabitants of Hell. They are temporarily placed there, while waiting for Allah's mercy and grace to be able to enter Paradise.

It is narrated from Ibn Mas'ud, that the Messenger of Allah said:

"The scales will be placed on the Day of Judgment and all good and bad deeds will be weighed. Then those whose scales of good deeds are heavier than their scales of bad deeds, even if by the weight of a mustard seed/atom, will enter Paradise." And those whose scales of bad deeds are heavier than their scales of good deeds, even if by the weight of a mustard seed/atom, will enter Hell. It was said to the Messenger of Allah, what about those whose scales of good deeds are equal to their scales of bad deeds? The Messenger of Allah replied: they are the inhabitants of A'raf, they have not yet entered Paradise but they greatly desire to enter it." (Narrated by Ibn Jarir from Ibn Mas'ud)

After that Ibn Mas'ud said, "Indeed, the scales can be heavy or light by a small seed. Whoever has the same weight of good and bad deeds, they are the inhabitants of A'raf, they stand waiting on the bridge.

Then they are turned to look at the inhabitants of Paradise and Hell. When they see the inhabitants of Paradise, they say: "Peace and prosperity be upon you." When their gaze is turned to the left, they see the inhabitants of Hell, saying, "Our Lord, do not place us with the wrongdoers." They both seek refuge in Allah from their place. Ibn Mas'ud said, "Those who have good deeds, they are given light that illuminates their front and right sides. Each person and each people is given light upon arriving on the bridge, Allah extinguishes the light of the hypocritical men and hypocritical women. When the inhabitants of Paradise see what is in front of the hypocrites, they say, "Our Lord, perfect our light." As for the inhabitants of A'raf, their light is in their hands, it will not be extinguished. At that time Allah says:

They have not [yet] entered it, but they long eagerly [to enter]. (al-A'raf/7: 46)

What is meant in this verse is that the inhabitants of A'raf call out to the inhabitants of Paradise, wishing them peace and prosperity, because of their longing for the blessings that Allah has given to the inhabitants of Paradise. They have not yet been able to enter it, while their hearts are already longing to enter.
text.47: This verse explains that when the inhabitants of A'raf turn their gaze towards the inhabitants of hell, fear arises within them, and they plead to Allah that they not be placed with the wrongdoers in hell. Whereas, seeing the inhabitants of Paradise brings them joy and pleasure. Therefore, when they see Paradise, they offer greetings of peace, due to the longing in their hearts to see the delights within it. So, the intent of this verse is to instill a sense of fear and dread in the inhabitants of A'raf, so that it can serve as a lesson for humanity to be careful not to commit deeds that bring about sin.
text.48:
This verse explains the dialogue between the inhabitants of A'raf and the inhabitants of Hell, consisting of those who were arrogant and haughty during their lives in the world. These were people who felt noble because of their wealth and abundant possessions, felt proud of their lives in the world, and looked down upon the poor and weak believers, those weak in strength and weak in position, and with few followers. They always boasted that those who lived rich and noble, and were powerful in the world, were the ones who would be happy in the Hereafter and avoid the punishment of Allah. This is explained by Allah in His word:

"And We did not send a warner to any city except that its affluent said, "Indeed, we are disbelievers in that with which you have been sent." And they said, "We are more [than you] in wealth and children, and we will not be punished." (Saba/34: 34-35)

The inhabitants of A'raf recognized them by the signs on them, such as their black and dusty faces, and signs that could be recognized during their lives in the world, such as the leaders of the Quraysh and their groups who were enemies of Islam, and always oppressed and persecuted Muslims, including Abu Jahal, Walid bin Mugirah, Ash bin Wail, and others. The inhabitants of A'raf said to them, "Did not your abundant wealth help you from the torment of Hellfire, nor your arrogance towards the believers whom you considered weak? Is there no benefit or reward that you hoped for, so that you could escape the painful punishment?"
text.49:
This verse explains the continuation of the conversation between the inhabitants of A'raf and those mentioned above. When the conversation was directed towards the group of believers whom they considered weak, poor, and lowly, and whom they had previously tortured, such as Suhaib, Bilal, and the family of Yasir, a question was posed to them with a tone of reproach and contempt: "Are these the ones you used to say would not receive mercy from Allah, to the point that you dared to swear and act arrogantly while insulting them? What is the reality now? They are the fortunate ones who receive mercy from Allah, while you are cowering in hell, receiving all kinds of torment and punishment from Allah."

Then, after that conversation, Allah invites the inhabitants of A'raf to enter Paradise, after being temporarily detained in the place called A'raf. Allah invites, "Enter Paradise, you do not need to feel fear or sadness in it." Such is the state of those who were disobedient and arrogant during their lives in the world; in the Hereafter, they will be humiliated and reproached not only by the inhabitants of Paradise but also by the inhabitants of A'raf who are awaiting Allah's decision to enter Paradise.
text.50:
This verse explains that the inhabitants of hell ask the inhabitants of paradise for a little water or food as sustenance and a gift from Allah to the inhabitants of paradise. The inhabitants of hell are very thirsty and hungry because of the heat of the hellfire. So, without shame, they ask the inhabitants of paradise for water and food, even though they already know that their request will not succeed, but will only add to their torment. Their request receives a response that is quite saddening to their feelings, adding to their thirst and hunger. The inhabitants of paradise answer, "Indeed, Allah has forbidden water and food for the disbelievers, just as Allah has forbidden them from entering paradise and has increased the painful torment of hell for them." It is narrated from Ibn 'Abbas:

"That an inhabitant of hell called out to his companion, 'O my brother, help me, indeed I have been burned, so give me a little water.' Then it was said to his brother (who was asked for help), 'Answer that request.' Then his brother recited this verse, "Indeed, Allah has forbidden both to the disbelievers." (Narrated by Ibn Jarir from Ibn 'Abbas)
text.51:
This verse explains who the disbelievers are, for whom Allah has forbidden drinking and eating the food given to the inhabitants of Paradise. They are those who, during their lives in the world, claimed to be religious but only as a mockery and a game. They did not practice religion with the intention of purifying their souls and obtaining rewards from Allah in the Hereafter. They were religious in name only, but their deeds contradicted the teachings of religion. In fact, sometimes they became obstacles to the implementation of religious teachings in society.

They were already immersed in the cradle of worldly pleasures. They only followed their desires, indulging in fun and joy without regard for what is halal and haram, what is right and what is wrong. They were not like the believers, who made the world like a garden to be planted with good deeds, the results of which could be harvested in the Hereafter. Because they were submerged in the waves of worldliness, lulled and swayed by temporary pleasures, they forgot the everlasting pleasures. It is fitting that on the Day of Judgment, Allah will forget them, not help them, because during their lives in the world they forgot Allah, as if they would not return to the eternal abode. Therefore, on the Day of Judgment, Allah will leave them in the blazing fire of Hell, because they did not want to do good deeds during their lives in the world, did not believe in the Hereafter, and they always argued against and denied the verses of Allah conveyed by His Messengers, even opposing those Messengers of Allah.
text.52:
This verse explains about the book that has been revealed to mankind, namely the Al-Qur'an, a heavenly book containing explanations and guidance for mankind in verses that are quite clear and bright because they have been explained by Allah to mankind through His Messenger Muhammad saw. The Al-Qur'an is a guidance and mercy for those who believe and trust that the Al-Qur'an is a revelation from Allah. If someone is willing to study it, and is willing to practice all of Allah's commands and abandon all of His prohibitions, he will receive happiness and Allah's mercy. The Al-Qur'an contains the basic principles of religion in general, both those related to aqidah and worship, as well as those related to muamalah, broad interactions between nations in this world.

With the Al-Qur'an as a guide and direction for mankind, it is hoped that the disease of blind imitation by following the ways of ancestors that are not in accordance with the teachings of the Al-Qur'an, shirk, worshipping other than Allah, such as idols, graves that are considered sacred, and others can be eliminated. The Al-Qur'an teaches tauhid, only to Allah should humans worship and ask for help. Thus, expressions such as those found in Allah's words below will no longer be heard, namely:

"Indeed, we found our fathers upon a religion, and we are in their footsteps following." (az-Zukhruf/43: 23)
text.53:
This verse explains the state of those who are unwilling to make the Qur'an a guide and direction in their lives to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter. They place more trust in the misguided teachings of their ancestors than in the teachings of the Qur'an which the Messenger of Allah (saw) conveyed truthfully. By acting in this way, they are waiting for the coming of Allah's punishment which will result in regret. On the Day of Judgment, what they are waiting for becomes a reality.

The promises and threats conveyed by the messengers will be proven on the Day of Judgment, namely that those who believe and do good deeds will receive happiness, and those who disbelieve will receive punishment and be in misery. On that day, those who forgot Allah and did not believe in the messengers who brought guidance and truth, even those who doubted and opposed them, will be judged. Therefore, if they receive punishment, it is only fitting.

On that day, they will have no power to escape punishment. All they can do is wish for help from people or things they once glorified or worshipped, such as ancestors who were used as a source of *taqlid* or idols that were worshipped. They also wish to be returned to life in the world, so that they can work and do good deeds according to the teachings of Allah. Such wishes are impossible. They cannot return to the world, because the universe and its contents have been destroyed. Therefore, at the end of this verse, it is stated that they have lost. In the world, they lost because they defiled themselves with *shirk* and disobedience, and in the hereafter they also lost because they received punishment.

They lose because everything they did in the world brings no benefit whatsoever. What they have fabricated all this time disappears and vanishes from their sight. They expect *shafa'at* from something they worship. The *shafa'at* they hoped for never comes. Finally, regret and loss arise.
text.54:
At the beginning of this verse, Allah affirms that He is the One who created the heavens and the earth in six days (periods). He is the Owner, the Ruler, and the Regulator. He is the God who deserves to be worshipped, and to Him, humans must ask for help.

Although only the heavens and the earth are mentioned in this verse, what is meant is everything in this universe, because what is meant by the heavens is all the realms above, and what is meant by the earth is all the realms below, including the realm between the heavens and the earth, as mentioned in His word:

Who created the heavens and the earth and what is between them in six days and then established Himself above the Throne (ʿArsh). (al-Furqan/25: 59)

As for what is meant by six days, it is six periods that Allah has determined, not the six days we know, which are the days after the creation of the heavens and the earth, while the day in this verse is before that. The following is an explanation of the meaning of six days in this verse according to scientists:

According to Marconi (2003), the explanation of the six periods is as follows: The First Period, namely the period from the 'Big Bang' from Singularity, until the separation of the Gravitational Force from the Single Force (Superforce), space-time began to separate. However, the Space-Time Continuum that was born was still vague, where energy-matter and space-time were not clearly different. The Second Period, the period of the formation of the inflation of the Universe, but this Universe is still not clear in its shape, and is called Cosmic Soup. The Strong-Nuclear Force separates from the Electro-Weak Force, and the fundamental materials begin to form: quarks, antiquarks, and so on. The Universe begins to expand. The Third Period, the period of the formation of atomic nuclei in this Universe. The Weak-Nuclear Force begins to separate from the Electromagnetic Force. Atomic nuclei such as protons, neutrons, and mesons are composed of these quarks. This period is known as the period of the formation of atomic nuclei (Nucleosyntheses). Space, time, as well as matter and energy, begin to appear separate. The Fourth Period, electrons begin to form, but are still in a free state, not yet bound by the atomic nucleus to form a stable atom. The Fifth Period, the formation of stable atoms, the separation of matter and radiation, and the Universe, continue to expand and begin to appear transparent. The Sixth Period, the Universe continues to expand, atoms begin to form aggregates into molecules, macro-molecules, then form proto-galaxies, galaxies, stars, solar systems, and planets.

As for the length of a day according to religion, only Allah knows, because in the Al-Qur'an itself, it is explained that a day in the sight of Allah is equal to a thousand years, in His word which is mentioned:

And indeed, a day with your Lord is like a thousand years of those which you count. (al-Hajj/22: 47)

And there is also an explanation of fifty thousand years as in His word:

The angels and the Spirit ascend to Him during a day the extent of which is fifty thousand years. (al-Ma'arij/70: 4)

There are several hadith that indicate that the six days are our current days, including those narrated by Ahmad and Muslim from Abu Hurairah. Abu Hurairah said:

"The Messenger of Allah held my hand and said, "Allah created the earth on Saturday, created the hills on Sunday, created the trees on Monday, created the bad things on Tuesday, created the light on Wednesday, created the mountains on Thursday, and created Adam on Friday after Asar, the last creation, at the last moment between the time of Asar and the beginning of the night." (Narrated by Ahmad and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

This hadith is rejected by hadith scholars because it contradicts the nash of the Al-Qur'an. From the aspect of its sanad, this hadith is also weak because it is narrated by Hajjad bin Muhammad al-Ajwar from Juraij who was no longer sane at the end of his life. According to al-Manar, this hadith is included in the Israiliyat hadith that were made by the Jews and Christians and said to be from the Messenger of Allah saw. In other verses, the periods of the creation of the heavens and the earth are explained in more detail, as found in Allah's word:

Say, "Do you indeed disbelieve in He who created the earth in two days and attribute to Him equals? That is the Lord of the worlds." (Fushshilat/41: 9)

And He placed on the earth firmly set mountains over its surface, and He blessed it and determined therein its [creatures'] sustenance in four days without distinction - for [the information] of those who ask. Then He directed Himself to the heaven while it was smoke and said to it and to the earth, "Come [into being], willingly or unwillingly." They said, "We have come willingly." And He completed them as seven heavens within two days and inspired in each heaven its command. And We adorned the nearest heaven with lamps and as protection. That is the determination of the Exalted in Might, the Knowing.

From these verses, it can be concluded as follows:

1.  The creation of the earth, which originated from lumps that looked like smoke, was two periods, and the creation of land, hills, mountains, as well as various plants and stars, was also two periods. Thus, the creation of the earth and all its contents was completed in four periods.

2.  The creation of the heavens, which originated from lumps of fog, with all its contents, was also in two periods. As for how the process of the creation of the heavens and the earth occurred, the Al-Qur'an does not explain it in detail, and it is the obligation of experts to investigate it and know the time or period required for each stage of its occurrence.

Then, after the creation of the heavens and the earth was completed, Allah established Himself above the Throne (Arsy), managing and regulating all matters related to the heavens and the earth according to His knowledge and wisdom. About how Allah established Himself above His Throne and how He regulates the universe, it cannot be equated or described like the establishment of a king on his throne because Allah should not be likened or equated with His creatures. However, this must be believed and believed in, and only Allah Himself knows how it really is. The companions of the Prophet did not feel any doubt in their hearts regarding Allah's establishment on the Throne. They believed in it and believed in Him without knowing how it was pictured. Thus, Imam Malik said when asked about the issue of Allah's establishment on the Throne as follows, "Allah's establishment is something that is not foreign, but how it is done cannot be thought of."

Apostleship is from Allah, and the obligation of the Messenger is to convey, so the obligation of humans is to justify it. Such is the opinion and stance of scholars from the past until now, so it is not appropriate for humans to dare to describe Allah's establishment on His Throne. Na'im bin Ahmad, the teacher of Imam al-Bukhari, said about this, "People who liken Allah to His creatures are infidels, people who deny Allah's attributes as explained by Him (in His book) are infidels, and there is no likeness in Allah's attributes as explained by Him or explained by His Messenger. So whoever establishes things that are accepted from the sahih hadith in accordance with Allah's majesty and negates the attributes of deficiency for Him, then he has indeed taken the right path. Furthermore, Allah explains that He is the One who covers the day and night so that the sunlight disappears on the surface of the earth, and this happens very quickly. What is meant is that the night is always chasing the sunlight, it has been covered, night has occurred, and in the place that has not been chased by the night, the sun still illuminates it and there is still day. Thus, the alternation of day and night or the alternation of night and day continues. In another verse, Allah says:

He created the heavens and earth in truth. He wraps the night over the day and wraps the day over the night and has subjected the sun and the moon, each running [its course] for a specified term. Unquestionably, He is the Exalted in Might, the Perpetual Forgiver. (az-Zumar/39: 5)

This happens because the earth, which is round, always rotates on its axis under the sun. Thus, on the surface of the earth that is exposed to sunlight, day occurs, and on the face of the earth that is not exposed to its light, night occurs. Then Allah also explains that the sun, moon, and stars are all subject to His command and the regulations that have been established. Everything moves according to the rules that have been determined, and none of them deviate from the rules that have been determined. Thus, there is a harmony and harmony in the journey of each so that there will be no collision or crash between one and the other, even though there are countless stars and other celestial bodies in the sky. All of that is because He is the All-Creator, All-Knowing, All-Wise. Glory be to Allah, Lord of the universe. Only Allah is worthy of worship, to Him every servant must offer prayers asking for His grace and mercy, and to Him also every servant must be grateful and thankful for all the blessings that have been given. How far astray are those who associate Him with His creatures and offer prayers to something that cannot give benefit or harm.
text.55:
This verse contains ethics in supplicating to Allah. Supplication is a private conversation between a servant and his Lord to convey a request so that Allah is willing to grant it. Therefore, supplicating to Allah should be done with full humility, truly with *khusyuk* (devotion) and surrender. Then, the supplication should be conveyed with a soft and gentle voice that comes from a pure heart. Supplicating with a loud voice eliminates *khusyuk* and may lead to *riya* (showing off) and other influences, and may result in the supplication not being granted by Allah. Supplication does not have to be with a loud voice, because Allah is All-Hearing and All-Knowing.

Narrated by Abu Musa al-Asy'ari, he said, "When we were with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) on a journey, we heard people reciting the *takbir* (glorification of God) in a loud voice. Then the Messenger of Allah said:

"Have mercy on yourselves, do not raise your voices, for you are not calling upon one who is deaf or far away. Indeed, you are calling upon Allah, the All-Hearing, the Near, and He is always with you." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Musa al-Asy'ari)

Speaking loudly in supplication can disturb people, especially those who are worshiping, whether in mosques or other places of worship, except for what is permitted with a loud voice, such as the *talbiyah* during the Hajj season and reciting the *takbir* on the days of Eid al-Fitr and Eid al-Adha. Allah praises Prophet Zakaria (peace be upon him) who supplicated with a soft voice:

(He said:) "My Lord! Indeed my bones have grown feeble, and my head is glistening with grey hair, and I have never been disappointed in my prayer to You, O my Lord!" (Maryam/19:3)

Then this verse is closed with a warning, "Indeed, Allah does not like transgressors." This means that it is forbidden to transgress in all matters, including supplication. Everything has a defined limit that must be observed, and should not be exceeded.

Speaking loudly and excessively in supplication is considered transgression, and Allah does not like it. Also included in transgressing in supplication is asking for something that is impossible according to *sharia* or reason, such as someone asking to become rich, but not wanting to work, or someone wanting their sins to be forgiven, but they continue to wallow in sin, and so on. Supplicating like that is like wanting to change *sunnatullah* (Allah's law) which is impossible to happen. Allah says:

But no change will you find in Allah's way (Sunnah), nor will you find deviation from Allah's way (Sunnah). (Fathir/35:43)

Directing supplication to other than Allah or using intermediaries (*washilah*) of people who have died is a very reprehensible transgression. Supplication should only be directed to Allah, and should not deviate to others. Allah says:

Say, "Invoke those you claim [as deities] besides Him, and they do not possess [power to] remove harm from you or alter [it]." Those whom they invoke seek [for themselves] means of access to their Lord [as to] which of them would be nearest, and they hope for His mercy and fear His punishment. Indeed, the punishment of your Lord is ever feared. (al-Isra'/17:56-57)

Hadith of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him):

Narrated from Abu Hurairah, he said, "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Ask Allah for *washilah* for me." They asked: O Messenger of Allah, what is *washilah*? The Messenger of Allah replied: "Close to Allah *azza Wa Jalla*, then the Messenger of Allah recited the verse; (they themselves) seek a way to their Lord, which of them is closest to Allah." (Narrated by at-Tirmidzi from Ibn Mardawaih)
text.56:
In this verse, Allah forbids humans from causing corruption on Earth. This prohibition against causing corruption encompasses all areas, such as corrupting social interactions, the physical and spiritual well-being of others, livelihoods and sources of sustenance (agriculture, trade, etc.), damaging the environment, and so on. Allah has created the Earth with all its completeness, such as mountains, valleys, rivers, oceans, land, forests, and so on, all of which are intended for the needs of humans, so that they can be cultivated and utilized in the best possible way for their welfare. Therefore, humans are forbidden from causing corruption on Earth.

Furthermore, Allah also sent down religion and sent messengers to provide guidance so that humans can live in happiness, security, and peace. As the seal of prophethood, Allah sent the Prophet Muhammad saw who brought the teachings of Islam as a mercy to all the worlds. If humans follow the teachings of Islam correctly, then everything will be good, individuals will be good, the nation will be good, and the state will also be good.

After Allah forbids humans from causing corruption, the end of this verse reveals again about the ethics of prayer. When praying for worldly or *ukhrawi* (hereafter) matters, in addition to doing so wholeheartedly, with *khusuk* (humility) and a gentle voice, it should also be accompanied by feelings of fear and hope. This kind of prayer will strengthen faith and will keep one away from despair, because one is directly pleading to Allah, the Almighty and the All-Rich. Allah's mercy will be poured out upon those who do good, and prayer is a good deed. Therefore, Allah's mercy is certainly near and will be poured out upon them. The encouragement to do good is often expressed in the Al-Qur'an, such as doing good to neighbors, to fellow humans, to friends, to the environment, and others. Therefore, if someone is going to slaughter an animal, they should do it in a good way, namely with a sharp knife so as not to cause suffering to the animal.
text.57:
With these two verses, Allah affirms that one of the great blessings bestowed upon His servants is moving the wind as a sign of the arrival of His favor, namely the wind that carries thick clouds that He drives to a dry land whose plants have been damaged due to the absence of water, its wells are dry due to the lack of rain, and its inhabitants suffer from thirst and hunger. Then He sends down heavy rain in that land so that the land that was almost dead becomes fertile again and its wells are full of water, thus its inhabitants live with self-sufficiency from the abundant yields of those plants.

Regarding the role of rain in "reviving" the "dead" land mentioned in the Qur'an, it has been analyzed by experts in science because rain, besides carrying water droplets, a material that is important for the life of all living creatures in the world, it turns out that rainwater droplets also carry materials that function as fertilizer. When seawater evaporates and reaches the clouds, it contains something that can revitalize dead land. Rainwater droplets containing these revitalization materials are commonly known as "surface tension droplets." These materials are obtained from the surface layer of the sea that evaporates. In a thin layer with a thickness of less than one-tenth of a millimeter and commonly called the "micro layer" by biologists, many organic litters are found originating from the decomposition of microscopic algae and zooplankton. Some of these litters collect and absorb several elements, such as phosphorus, magnesium, and potassium, which are rarely obtained in seawater. These litters also absorb heavy metals such as copper, zinc, cobalt, and lead. Plants on land will obtain most of the mineral salts and other elements needed for their growth along with the arrival of rainwater.

The salts that fall with rainwater are a miniature of the fertilizers commonly used in agriculture (Sodium, Potassium, Calcium, etc.). Heavy metals in the air will form elements that will increase productivity during plant growth and fruiting. Thus, rain is a very important source of fertilizer. With the fertilizer contained in rainwater droplets alone, in 100 years, nutrient-poor soil can collect all the elements needed for plant growth. Forests also grow and obtain their necessities from all the chemicals that come from the sea.

In this way, about 150 tons of fertilizer fall to earth every year. Without this mechanism, perhaps the number of plant species would not be as many as we know today, and ecological imbalances could also occur.

Indeed, not all countries receive this abundant blessing, but there are also some places on earth that do not receive much rain, and there are even some areas that receive rain but the soil in those areas is wasted without any benefit whatsoever. Regarding the lands that do not receive rain, Allah says:

Do you not see that Allah drives the clouds gently, then joins them together, then makes them into a mass, and then you see the rain emerge from within them? And He sends down from the sky mountains (of clouds) wherein is hail, and He strikes therewith whom He wills and averts it from whom He wills. The flash of its lightning nearly blinds the sight. (an-Nur/24: 43)

According to this verse, heavy rain accompanied by hail does not fall in all corners of the earth, only Allah determines where the rain will fall and where the thick clouds will only pass by so that the area remains barren and dry.
text.58:
This verse explains that the types of soil on the face of the earth are of two kinds: some are good and fertile, so that when even a little rain falls, they can grow various kinds of plants and produce abundant food; and some are not good, so that even though heavy rain has fallen, the plants still live poorly and cannot produce anything. Then Allah gives an analogy with the revival of dead lands, to establish the truth of the occurrence of Yaumal Mahsyar: That is, where the dead are brought back to life and gathered in Padang Mahsyar to receive rewards for all their deeds, the good being rewarded many times over and the bad being rewarded accordingly.

If dry and dead land can be brought back to life by Allah by sending rain upon it, even though the land is barren and has no element of life in it, then surely Allah can also bring back to life people who have died, even if only bones remain or they have all become soil. Regarding bringing the dead back to life, Allah says:

And he makes an example for Us and forgets his [own] creation. He says, "Who will give life to bones while they are disintegrated?" Say, "He will give them life who produced them the first time; and He is, of all creation, Knowing." (Yasin/36: 78-79)

Furthermore, Allah gives an analogy with good and fertile soil as well as bad and infertile soil to explain the nature and character of humans in receiving and placing Allah's guidance. People who are good in nature and character can accept the truth and use it for their own benefit and for the benefit of society. People who are bad in nature and character do not want to accept the truth and even always deny it, so they do not get any benefit for themselves from that truth, let alone for their society.

Ibn 'Abbas said: This verse is an analogy given by Allah for the believer and the disbeliever, for the good and the evil. Allah likens these people to good and bad soil, and Allah likens the revelation of the Qur'an to the falling of rain. So the good earth, with the falling of rain, can produce flowers and fruits, while the bad earth, when rained upon, can only grow very little. Likewise, a soul that is good and clean from the diseases of ignorance and moral degradation, when illuminated by the light of the Qur'an, becomes a soul that is obedient and virtuous.

As for the evil and dirty soul, when illuminated by the Qur'an, it is rare for it to become good and virtuous. Rasulullah said:

"The parable of knowledge and guidance with which I have been sent is like abundant rain that falls on the earth. So among the land there is that which is clean (fertile) and can receive the rain, then it grows plants and abundant grass. But there is also among it land that is barren (hard) that does not absorb rainwater and does not grow anything. That land can hold water (collect it), so Allah makes people able to benefit from that water, they can drink, irrigate plants. There is also some flat land that cannot hold water and does not grow plants. So those diverse lands are a parable for those who can understand the religion of Allah. Then he benefits from those instructions and teaches them to people, and also a parable for those who do not care about it and do not want to accept that guidance." (Narrated by Ahmad, al-Bukhari, Muslim and an-Nasai)

Prophet Muhammad gave the predicate (nickname) al-Hadi and al-Muhtadi to the first group who benefited themselves and gave benefits to others, and gave the predicate al-Jahid to the third group who did not benefit themselves and could not give benefits to others. But Prophet Muhammad did not comment on the second group, namely people who cannot give benefits to others, because people from this group are of many kinds, among them are hypocrites and also those who do not practice their religious teachings even though they know and spread Allah's teachings to others. Thus Allah gives an analogy with His blessings and favors so that they are grateful for by those who feel that blessing.
text.59:
In this verse, Allah recounts the story of Prophet Noah and his prophethood. In the period between Prophet Adam and Prophet Noah, the world began to develop its civilization. Initially, people still worshipped Allah according to the religion brought by Prophet Adam. But over time, due to their preoccupation with worldly life, they began to distance themselves from religion, causing the spirit of religiosity to decline. The teachings of *tauhid* (monotheism) that had sprouted in their hearts began to fade. Statues of their leaders, initially made to honor and commemorate their services, were turned into objects of worship or partners with Allah, because according to their understanding, these statues could bring them closer to Allah. Eventually, they forgot Allah and viewed the statues as gods from whom they expected goodness, sought blessings, and feared punishment.

After people's belief in Allah faded during that time, Allah did not leave them continuously in error. Therefore, Allah sent Prophet Noah to his people. The story of Prophet Noah's prophethood is addressed to the Arabs in and around Mecca who denied the prophethood of Prophet Muhammad. Their knowledge of the history of the prophets and peoples of the past was very limited because they only heard it from the Jews and Christians around them.

In this verse, Allah assures them that He had indeed sent Prophet Noah to his people to warn them of Allah's wrath because of their disbelief. After Noah was appointed as a Messenger, he called upon his disbelieving people to abandon idols and worship the One God, the Creator of all things, He is the true God. Humans are obligated to worship Him with full *khusyuk* (humility) and *tawadhu'* (submission). Prophet Noah expressed to his people his concern that they would receive a severe punishment on the Day of Reckoning if they did not heed his call.

Some *mufassirin* (Quran commentators) view that the Day of Reckoning referred to in this verse is the day the flood occurred. Furthermore, the concern expressed by Prophet Noah to his people indicates that Prophet Noah had despaired after carrying out *dakwah* (proselytizing) for a considerable period, but there was no response from his people, as is known from the following verses:

He (Noah) said, "My Lord, indeed I invited my people night and day, but my invitation increased them not except in flight [from the truth]." (Nuh/71: 5-6)
text.60:
In this verse, Allah explains that the leaders of Noah's people believed that Prophet Noah was truly in error, because Prophet Noah forbade them from worshipping idols, which they considered as helpers before Allah and as intermediaries to bring them closer to Him. Such was the behavior of those who disbelieved; they even often accused those who believed in Allah of being in error, as mentioned in Allah's word:

"And when they see them, they say, "Indeed, these are truly lost." (al-Muthaffifin/83: 32)

Allah's word:

"And those who disbelieve say of those who believe, "If it had been good, they would not have preceded us to it." And when they are not guided by it, they will say, "This is an ancient falsehood." (al-Ahqaf/46: 11)
text.61: This verse explains Prophet Noah's rejection of his people's accusations by affirming that he was certainly not in error, because he was in fact a messenger of Allah and what he was calling them to was not arising from his own thoughts alone, which might be driven by personal interests. But what he presented was the revelation of Allah, whose truth is certain, and therefore it must be conveyed to them so that they can achieve happiness and avoid destruction as a result of associating partners with Allah.
text.62: This verse explains that Prophet Noah affirmed to his people that he was tasked by Allah to convey His commands so that people would believe in the One God, in the Hereafter, in the Messengers sent by Allah, in the Angels of Allah, and to convey the laws that Allah has determined, both those pertaining to worship and those pertaining to social interactions (muamalat). In conveying his mission, Prophet Noah accompanied it with subtle threats in the form of advice to his people to fear Allah's punishment as retribution for those who do not believe in Him and deny His Messengers. Prophet Noah also affirmed that he truly knew things that his people did not know, all of which he knew from Allah. Such was the persistence of Prophet Noah in convincing his people.
text.63:
In this verse, Allah explains Prophet Noah's rebuke to his people, that it was not appropriate for them to feel astonished or doubtful about the arrival of a warning from the Lord brought by a man from among themselves. He warned them about the torment that would befall them if they persisted in disbelief. With that warning, they would be able to protect themselves from acts of shirk and munkar so that they might obtain Allah's mercy.

As for what caused his people's doubt and astonishment about his prophethood, it was because Prophet Noah did not possess any special advantages. But if they used sound reasoning, they would realize that advantages among humans are obtained not only through human effort itself, but also from Allah's grace, because Allah is the Almighty.

In the reality of human life, differences are apparent among each person, both physical and spiritual differences. Therefore, they should have welcomed the call from someone who possesses advantages and privileges as a messenger to save them from Allah's punishment due to disbelief and lead them to truth and piety towards Allah in order to obtain His pleasure and mercy.
text.64:
This verse explains that most of Prophet Noah's people continued to mock and deny him, persisting in opposing God's commands and becoming increasingly immersed in disobedience. Their consciences were closed off, preventing them from learning from the signs of God's greatness and from benefiting from the wisdom of the Messengers' mission. Their ears were also deafened, preventing them from affirming the existence of the Hereafter, the Day of Reckoning, which Prophet Noah conveyed. Humans should know that a person living in this world must be accountable for their actions to Allah as their Creator. The Prophet pointed to the existence of life on the Day of Judgment. But people who do not use their minds assume that human life is only in this world without any accountability in the Hereafter.

Unconsciously, they have equated themselves with animals, which is why various evil deeds such as shirk arose on this earth. Because of the denial of Noah's people, God's punishment befell them, in the form of wind and a flood that drowned them. Only a few of Noah's followers were saved by Allah from drowning at the time of the disaster because they were in the ark that had been prepared long before. Most of his people drowned because they were immersed in disbelief (kufr) and disobedience.
text.65:
This verse explains that Allah sent to the people of 'Ad the Prophet Hud from among themselves and commanded him to call his people to worship Allah, the One and Only God, and to abandon everything they deified, because besides Allah there is no God and nothing deserves to be worshipped; all worship is only for Allah. Therefore, Prophet Hud encouraged them to be mindful of Allah and to abandon everything that angered Him in order to avoid His punishment. At another time and opportunity, he commanded his people to use their intellect. Allah says:

"And to the 'Ad [We sent] their brother Hud. He said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. You are not but inventors [of falsehood]. O my people, I do not ask you for it any payment. My payment is only from the One who created me. Then will you not reason?" (Hud/11: 50-51)

'Ad was the son of Iram bin Aus bin Sam bin Noah. This is explained by Muhammad bin Ishak. According to Ibn Ishak, al-Kalby said: the people of 'Ad were idol worshippers, just like the people of Prophet Noah who made statues of people they considered sacred after they died. Then these statues were considered as gods. The people of 'Ad also made statues, they named them Tsamud and others they named al-Hatar. They lived in Yemen in the Ahqaf region between Oman and Hadramaut. They were a people who caused corruption on earth because they were proud of their physical strength, which other people did not possess.

Because they treated the inhabitants of the earth as they pleased in a tyrannical manner, Allah sent Prophet Hud from among themselves, because it was Allah's decree that the messengers who were sent were taken from their own people, who understood their people better and whose call was more acceptable because they knew his personality. However, when Prophet Hud conveyed his message, which was to call his people to worship Allah, the One and Only God, and to abandon tyrannical acts, his call was denied and they even opposed him, as explained in Allah's word:

"As for 'Ad, they were arrogant upon the earth without right and said, "Who is greater than us in strength?" Did they not consider that Allah who created them was greater than them in strength? And they were rejecting Our signs." (Fushshilat/41: 15)
text.66: This verse explains that the leaders of Hud's people who remained in disbelief and continued to strongly oppose Hud's prophethood not only rejected his call, but they also affirmed that they were in the true religion and considered the Prophet Hud to be in error. This was because he abandoned their religion and insulted the prominent figures among his people whom they considered sacred. These people, after death, were sanctified in the form of idols in order to obtain intercession (syafaat) and blessings (berkah) from them. The Prophet Hud opposed their understanding. Therefore, they accused the Prophet Hud of being a liar who was in error, just as the previous messengers were also rejected by their people because they had opposing views with their people.
text.67: This verse explains the refutation that Prophet Hud was never in error as they accused him, because he was a messenger of Allah, sent to them to convey His commands. The Lord of the universe, the All-Knowing, knows who is astray or weak in intellect and who is in the truth or perfect in intellect.
text.68:
This verse explains Prophet Hud's affirmation to his people, that he only conveyed the commands of his Lord so that they would believe in Him, in the Hereafter, in the Messengers, in the Angels of Allah, in the existence of Paradise and Hell, and so that they would carry out the commands of the Lord, both those related to worship and to social interactions (muamalat). Prophet Hud affirmed that he was truly sincere and trustworthy. With these words, it was as if Prophet Hud was stating to his people, "It is not fitting for me to lie to my Lord who sent me as a messenger."

Such is the portrayal of the character of Allah's chosen messengers when faced with the disobedience of a people who not only opposed them but also impolitely accused the messengers with various very base accusations. Nevertheless, the messengers faced them with calmness and with hearts full of patience.
text.69: In this verse, Allah explains the rebuke of Prophet Hud to the leaders of his people, that it was not fitting for them to be astonished and doubtful about the arrival of a warning and teaching from their Lord brought by a man from among them. Allah's teaching came to them precisely when they were in error. They should not have doubted the person who brought the call. They should have used their intellect to pay attention to the call brought to them, which was a true call, a call that would save them from Allah's punishment. He also reminded them of Allah's blessings and mercy, that they were not only heirs of the people of Noah whom Allah saved from the flood because of their faith in Him, but also that Allah had favored them with physical strength and large bodies. Therefore, they should be grateful to Allah by being mindful of Him (taqwa). If they were not grateful, Allah would inflict His punishment as He inflicted punishment on the ungrateful people of Noah and replace them with another nation. They were reminded of Allah's blessings so that they would be grateful by worshipping Him sincerely, thus avoiding polytheism by abandoning the worship of idols. In this way, they must abandon idol worship to achieve happiness in the Hereafter and obtain a place with Allah that has been prepared for His servants who are grateful for His blessings.
text.70: It turned out that the people of Hud were a very stubborn and disobedient people. They still answered and mocked the call of the Prophet Hud, saying, "Indeed, you have come to us, O Hud, so that we worship Allah by abandoning what our forefathers worshipped. Is this not something that amuses us? Do you not know that the objects of worship inherited from our elders bring us closer to God as intermediaries because we have not yet become holy; do we not need the gods worshipped by our elders? If you are indeed a messenger of Allah and what you convey to us is true, then bring upon us the punishment you promised."
text.71:
After the people of Hud opposed him and rejected his call to abandon the worship of idols, even demanding that the punishment be brought upon them immediately, Prophet Hud said to his people that Allah had decreed a punishment that would befall them and that they would experience the wrath of Allah, meaning they would be distanced from His mercy. The punishment that would befall them was a very strong wind with a very loud roar that would slam them to the ground until they died prostrate. Allah says:

The 'Ad people denied [their prophet], so how [severe] was My punishment and warning. Indeed, We sent upon them a screaming wind on a day of continuous misfortune, tearing away the people as if they were uprooted palm trunks. Then how [severe] was My punishment and warning. (al-Qamar/54: 18-21)

Prophet Hud declared to his people that the names of the idols, whether they named them or their ancestors named them, were not worthy of being the subject of debate with him. Because giving names with the names of God to idols and statues is very unreasonable. Likewise, naming them as intermediaries to draw closer to Allah, or givers of intercession, and other divine attributes. These names have no basis. Allah has not sent down any explanation or proof of these names. Allah is the One God, only to Him should humans worship directly; nothing is justified in being His partner. If it were justified, Allah would certainly give an explanation with His revelation. Prophet Hud called on them to wait for the descent of the punishment from Allah that they had requested, and he himself was among those waiting to witness the arrival of the punishment that would befall his disbelieving people.
text.72:
After the people of Hud opposed and demanded the promised punishment, the punishment of Allah came upon them, and Allah saved Hud and those who believed from that punishment.

The punishment was in the form of a violent, extremely cold wind that destroyed the people of 'Ad, because they denied the greatness of Allah and even rejected His messengers. They were wiped off the face of the earth by a wind that destroyed everything, as mentioned in the word of Allah:

"Destroying everything by command of its Lord. And they became such that nothing could be seen except their dwellings. Thus do We recompense the wrongdoing people." (al-Ahqaf/46: 25)
text.73:
This verse explains that Allah sent the Prophet Saleh to his people, namely the people of Thamud. Thamud is the name of a tribe from the Arab nation that was destroyed, known as "Arab Ba'idah," who inhabited Hijr, the 'Ula region north of Medina, Saudi Arabia. Thamud is the name of their ancestor, the son of 'Atsir bin Iram bin Sam bin Nuh. The emergence of the Thamud people was after the 'Ad people were destroyed by Allah. According to a narration, when the Messenger of Allah was in the Battle of Tabuk in the 9th year of Hijri, he passed through the area of the Thamud people's ruins. The Messenger of Allah forbade his companions from entering the area, saying:

"Do not enter the places of those who were afflicted with Allah's punishment unless you are weeping. If you are not weeping, do not enter the place so that you are not afflicted with a calamity like the calamity that befell them." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Such was the Prophet's advice to his companions to avoid places that had been struck by disaster.

Saleh (peace be upon him) was a Prophet sent by Allah to the people of Thamud. He came from the best lineage, position, and household of the Thamud people, as well as his character. The miracle of his prophethood was the "she-camel of Allah." Prophet Saleh carried out his duty by conveying the commands of his Lord to his people. Prophet Saleh called them to worship Allah, the One and Only God, emphasizing that there is no god but Allah, therefore they should fear Him. Prophet Saleh invited them to accept his call and not to follow those who were swept away in polytheism, which would lead them into Hell, as a result of their abandoning the true teachings of religion. Prophet Saleh told his people that the proof of the truth of his prophethood was a camel he called the "Camel of Allah," which Allah created in an unusual way. According to some commentators, this camel came out of a large rock at the request of the Thamud people as a miracle that they should pay attention to.

Allah gave Prophet Saleh a miracle in the form of a she-camel as proof of his apostleship, because the Thamud people asked for proof of his apostleship. Prophet Saleh asked his people to let the camel eat whatever was on Allah's earth, because this earth belongs to Allah and this camel is Allah's camel, and it is not appropriate for them to hinder the camel, let alone hurt or slaughter it. Prophet Saleh threatened them that they would receive a painful punishment from Allah if they disturbed or killed the camel.

In order to avoid difficulties between them and the camel, the days for drinking at the well were arranged for them and for the camel, due to the scarcity of water, as stated by Allah's words:

*And inform them that the water is to be shared between them, each share [of water] being distinctly timed.* (al-Qamar/54: 28)

Also, Allah's words in another verse:

*He said, "This is a she-camel; for her is a time to drink, and for you is a time to drink, [each] on a known day.* (asy-Syu'ara'/26: 155)
text.74: After Prophet Salih invited his people to worship Allah and advised them to treat the camel well, Prophet Salih began to remind them of the blessings of Allah that they had received, including being given power and strength to prosper on this earth as successors to the people of 'Ad. Allah gave them the ability and capability to build palaces and the knowledge to make building materials such as bricks, lime, tiles, and the skill and perseverance to carve hills and mountains to be used as their homes and residences in the winter. They made hills and mountains into bungalows to avoid the dangers of rain and cold. They only came out of the hills in other seasons for farming and other work. Prophet Salih called on them to remember these blessings of Allah so that they would be grateful to Him, by worshipping Him alone and abandoning destructive actions on this earth, including actions that are not pleasing to Allah in the form of disbelief (kufr), polytheism (shirk), and injustice (zalim).
text.75:
This verse explains that the arrogant leaders of the Thamud people said to those who were weak and believed in Prophet Saleh, mocking them as if they were mistaken for believing in the prophethood of Prophet Saleh. They stated that these weak people were not hopeless, perhaps because they believed in Saleh's prophethood. Indeed, it is customary that the weak, having no vested interests, still adhere to their conscience, which is why they readily accept the call of the Prophet or the advice of righteous people.

As for the prominent and wealthy, it is very difficult for them to follow others, especially to accept advice that prevents them from following their desires, even if it contradicts their own conscience. Such is the behavior of those who have status because of their position or wealth, as stated in Allah's word:

"And they denied them wrongfully and arrogantly, while their [inner] selves were convinced thereof [of their truth]. So see what was the end of the corrupters." (an-Naml/27: 14)

The weak people of Thamud who believed did not immediately answer their question, but wisely replied that they believed in what Prophet Saleh brought, because the guidance was true and came from Allah.
text.76: After the weak group who believed answered with a wise response that they believed in Allah, and what was brought by the Prophet Saleh, this verse explains the words of the arrogant leaders of the Thamud people as a response to the words of these weak people. They said that they denied what was believed by the weak people. They avoided saying they denied what was brought by the Prophet Saleh, because they feared the impression that they were acknowledging the prophethood of Saleh (peace be upon him).
text.77:
After that, they acted rebelliously by slaughtering the camel and defying the commands of Allah conveyed to them by Prophet Saleh. They called upon one of their fellows to kill the camel, as explained by the word of Allah:

"Then they called their comrade, and he took (a sword) and slaughtered (her)." (al-Qamar/54: 29)

However, in verse 77 it is said that those who killed the camel were many among them. This indicates that the criminal act of one person is considered the criminal act of many if the person who committed the crime did so with the agreement of the many or at their command. Therefore, responsibility for the criminal act is placed upon him and the many together, and punishment is inflicted upon them. They then challenged Prophet Saleh to bring the punishment promised to them, namely the punishment of Allah, if Saleh was truly a messenger of Allah conveying a threat from Allah.
text.78: After they challenged Prophet Saleh by demanding the promised punishment of Allah, Allah defended His Messenger and his followers. This verse explains the punishment of Allah that was sent down upon them in the form of a terrible earthquake and lightning that shook the hearts of men, shaking the earth like a great earthquake that destroyed all buildings, so that they all perished. Surely, the lightning was not ordinary lightning, but extraordinary lightning specifically inflicted upon them as punishment for the disobedience of the people of Thamud.
text.79:
After the people of Thamud were destroyed by lightning, this verse explains that Prophet Saleh, with emotion and sadness, said to those who were already dead that he had indeed delivered the message of his Lord and had sufficiently given advice to them, but they did not like to accept the advice. This call of Prophet Saleh addressed to his dead people shows how much he loved his people. This reminds us of the call of Prophet Muhammad to some of the Quraysh people who had died and were buried in the Battle of Badr. The Messenger of Allah said:

"O Abu Jahl bin Hisham, O Utbah bin Rabi'ah. O Shaybah bin Rabiah and O so-and-so son of so-and-so, Have you now found what Allah promised to be true? Because I have found what my Lord promised to be true." Umar said, "O Messenger of Allah, what is the point of talking to lifeless bodies?" The Messenger of Allah replied, "By the Lord in Whose hand my soul is, you do not hear what I say any better than they do. But they cannot answer." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Thalhah al-Anshari).

Verse 79 does not state that Prophet Saleh avoided his people before the punishment of Allah came, nor does it state the fate of some of the people of Thamud who believed in Prophet Saleh. However, verse 79 clearly states that Prophet Saleh was saved by Allah. Ibn Kathir explains that Allah saved Prophet Saleh and his followers from the punishment and then they went and lived in Haran.
text.80:
This verse explains that Allah sent Prophet Lut to convey religion to his people so that they would worship Allah, and Prophet Lut asked them in a stern tone, "Why do you commit such lewdness as no people before you have ever committed?" in the hope that they would realize and abandon that vile behavior. The people of Prophet Lut were the first to commit sodomy (homosexuality), so they received a sin like the sin of those who imitated them, as explained in the hadith:

"Whoever introduces a bad practice in Islam, and that bad practice is followed afterwards, then he will bear the burden of the sin of those who follow that bad practice." (Narrated by Muslim)

Another hadith explains:

"Whoever calls to guidance will have a reward like the reward of those who follow him, without that detracting from their reward in the slightest. And whoever calls to misguidance will have a burden of sin like the burden of those who follow him, without that detracting from their burden in the slightest." (Narrated by Muslim)

Allah created men and women with the aim of developing human offspring to prosper this world. Each gender has lustful desires that encourage the realization of the need for these two types of humans to meet as a means of procreation.

Women, in their form, are beautiful, delicate, and attractive. There is a mutual attraction between men and women like the attraction between positive and negative. If humans are like that, how strange it is if there is a group of people who deviate from Allah's provisions. How great is the violation of humanity committed by a man who has relations with another man with the aim of not developing offspring.

If killing each other is considered something bad, then the actions of the people of Prophet Lut can be said to be worse and can degrade the degree of humans and humanity to be lower than animals. This is because no male animal has relations with another male as the people of Prophet Lut did. Allah's decree regarding this is that men are for women and women are for men. The people of Lut not only disbelieved in Allah and were ungrateful for His blessings, but also committed homosexuality, which eventually also encouraged women to commit lesbianism (having relations with each other). Allah sent Prophet Lut to such a people to convey Allah's teachings so that they would return to the right path and abandon bad behavior that contradicted *sunnatullah*. Because they rejected Lut's call, Allah destroyed those people.

Prophet Lut was the son of Haran bin Tarikh. Tarikh was the brother of Prophet Ibrahim. Lut was born in the eastern edge of southern Iraq, formerly called Babylon. At the will of Prophet Ibrahim, Lut resided in the city of Sodom, one of the cities in the Jordan region. Lut died around Jordan, formerly known as the Dead Sea (Laut Lut).
text.81:
This verse is a continuation of verse 80, explaining that Prophet Lut affirmed to his people that they were indeed committing homosexuality, an act that not only contradicts human *fithrah* but also hinders human reproduction. Homosexual acts are solely aimed at releasing lust, as the perpetrators are lower than animals. Animals still require the opposite sex to satisfy their lust and the desire to have offspring. For example, crawling and flying animals begin their lives with a female and a male to build nests together in trees. Meanwhile, homosexual behavior has no such purpose other than to vent lust.

With enthusiasm, Prophet Lut condemned and ridiculed their behavior. At the end of this verse, it is stated that Prophet Lut always ended his speech with the words:

"But O my people, you are truly a transgressing people, because you abandon sound reason and deviate from human *fitrah*, so that you do not think about the bad consequences of your behavior, namely cutting off offspring, damaging health, and violating civilization."

If the people of Lut did not deviate from *fitrah*, always thought soundly, and had noble character, they would certainly avoid that vile and cursed act. Condemnation of the actions of Prophet Lut's people is repeatedly stated with various expressions, such as Allah's word:

"Do you approach men with desire instead of women? Rather, you are a people behaving ignorantly." (an-Naml/27: 55)

Also, Allah's word in another verse:

"Do you approach men, and cut off the road, and commit evil in your meetings?" (al-'Ankabut/29: 29)
text.82:
This verse explains the reaction of Lot's people to the reprimands and advice presented by Prophet Lot, accompanied by logical and undeniable reasons. Nevertheless, they continued to reject the truth. Some of their leaders issued an order that Prophet Lot and those who believed in him be expelled from their homeland on the grounds that Prophet Lot and the believers were clean people and not worthy of associating with them, because they were corrupt and impure people. Therefore, it was better that Prophet Lot and his followers not live in the same village as them, because there was a difference in character between them and Prophet Lot. They committed vile acts with pride, while Prophet Lot and the believers were people who purified themselves from that cursed act. Mockingly, they wanted Prophet Lot and his followers to be expelled, so that they could continue to act freely without anyone disturbing them.

How low was the morality of Lot's people, without shame they proudly committed acts of disobedience in the form of curses while insulting people of noble character. Only people who do not believe in Allah and the Hereafter can fall into this low rank.
text.83:
This verse explains that Allah saved Prophet Lut and those who believed in him, except for his wife, because she did not believe in Prophet Lut and even betrayed him. His wife sided with the disbelieving people of Lut. Therefore, she was included among the people of Lut who would also receive punishment in the Hereafter. Another verse explains that before the punishment was sent down upon the people of Lut, Allah commanded Prophet Lut and his believing followers to leave their land, as explained in His word:

"They (the angels) said, "O Lut, indeed, we are messengers of your Lord; they will never reach you. So set out with your family during a portion of the night and let not any among you look back - except your wife. Indeed, she will be struck by that which strikes them. Indeed, their appointment is [for] the morning. Is not the morning near?" (Hud/11: 81)

His other word:

"So set out with your family during the night and follow behind them and let not anyone among you look back and proceed to where you are commanded." (al-Hijr/15: 65)

Also, His word:

"And We brought out from therein the believers. And We found not within it except one house of Muslims [i.e., submitting to Allah]. And We left therein a sign for those who fear the painful punishment." (adz-Dzariyat/51: 35-37)
text.84:
This verse explains that Allah destroyed the people of Lot with stones known as "sijjil stones," which were sent down from the sky like rain, as mentioned in Allah's words:

So We turned (the cities) upside down, and rained down on them stones of hard clay. (al-Hijr/15: 74)

Allah's words:

So when Our command came, We turned (the cities of Lot) upside down, and rained down on them stones of baked clay, layer upon layer. (Hud/11: 82)

No *tafsir* scholar can explain how these stones were gathered from the earth and lifted up, or the layer of earth that was lifted above them, and then fell down like rain. Similarly, the form of the stones, whether they were made of hard clay alone or mixed with elements of burning substances, or stones originating from fragments of stars.

In this verse, Allah shows His power to Muhammad and his *ummah* to learn from the events and behavior of those who deny Allah and His messengers. If Allah wills their destruction, it can happen through natural causes, for example: earthquakes, epidemics, wars, and victims of slander, and it can also happen through extraordinary causes such as the flood that drowned the people of Noah, the wind that swept away the people of Hud, the lightning that destroyed the people of Saleh, and the rain of stones that wiped out the people of Lot.

Regarding the homosexual acts committed by the people of Lot, there is disagreement among *fiqh* scholars about the punishment, as follows:

1.  Imam Abu Hanifah is of the opinion that the perpetrator should be thrown from a high place, accompanied by stoning. But according to one narration, the perpetrator is only given *ta'zir*, a punishment to deter them, whether *muhsan* or not *muhsan*.

2.  Imam Malik believes that the perpetrator should be stoned (*rajm*) (whether *muhsan* - previously married - or not). The same applies to the partner if they are adults. But according to one narration, *ta'zir* is applied to those who are not *muhsan*.

3.  Imam Shafi'i explains that the perpetrator should be stoned (*rajm*), whether *muhsan* or not. According to one narration, the perpetrator is stoned if he is *muhsan*. If not *muhsan*, they are flogged one hundred times.

4.  Imam Ahmad believes that both perpetrators should be killed.

5.  The opinion of some of the Prophet's companions, such as Abu Bakr, Ali, Ibn Zubair, is that the perpetrator should be burned.
text.85:
This verse narrates that the people of Madyan, the people of Prophet Shu'aib, were ungrateful to Allah, in addition to associating partners with Him. Their morals were very bad, so their lives were steeped in deception, even in matters of exchange and weighing. According to a narration, if a foreigner came to visit, they would agree to accuse the foreigner's money of being counterfeit, thus exchanging it at a very low price (exchange rate). To this people, Allah sent Prophet Shu'aib so that he could show them the right path and abandon cheating in measures and weights.

As is usual, Allah strengthens the prophethood of each of His Prophets with miracles, as is known from the hadith of Abu Hurairah, namely:

"There is no Prophet from among the prophets except that he was given signs of his prophethood that made people believe in him. Indeed, what was given to me was the revelation that was conveyed to me, namely (Al-Qur'an). So I hope that I will have more followers than the followers of the prophets on the Day of Resurrection." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

There is not a single verse in the Al-Qur'an that explains the miracles given to Prophet Shu'aib. Fakhrur Razi in his tafsir, quoting az-Zamakhsyari in his tafsir "Al-Kasysyaf," says that among the miracles of Prophet Shu'aib was that he gave his staff to Prophet Musa. That staff destroyed the large snakes belonging to Pharaoh's magicians. He also said to Prophet Musa that these goats would all give birth to offspring with black and white fur, and it turned out to be true as he had said.
text.86:
After Prophet Shu'aib forbade his people from causing corruption on the earth, this verse explains that Prophet Shu'aib also forbade them from sitting on the roads to disturb passersby. They threatened the lives of those who believed, and if someone who did not yet believe intended to visit Prophet Shu'aib, they would say that Shu'aib was a liar who wanted to tempt people to abandon the religion of their ancestors.

At the end of the verse, Prophet Shu'aib invites them to remember the past when they were few in number, then Allah multiplied their descendants and provided them with abundant sustenance. Therefore, they should be grateful to Allah by abandoning polytheism and acts of injustice, and they should learn from the events that befell the people who committed injustice, including abandoning the true religion of the nations before them, such as the people of Noah, the people of 'Ad, and the people of Thamud. They should learn from what caused Allah to destroy the nations before them. Thus, Prophet Shu'aib indirectly warned his people not to suffer the same fate as those who had been destroyed by Allah.
text.87: This verse expresses the expertise of Prophet Shu'aib in conveying the teachings of Allah, presented with firm, wise, and impressive words. Prophet Shu'aib said to them that if there were a group among them who affirmed his call to worship Allah, the One and Only God, and abandon unjust acts such as reducing people's rights in weighing and measuring, then they would be spared from Allah's punishment.
