Conversely, if there were a group among them who still did not respond to his call and remained in disbelief and injustice, then Prophet Shu'aib threatened them to await the decision of the most just Lord, which is to defend His believing servants and destroy the disbelieving group who commit injustice.
text.88:
This verse explains that the leaders of the Madyan tribe said to Prophet Syuaib that they would expel Syuaib and his followers from their land if Prophet Syuaib refused to return to the religion of their ancestors and stop his preaching to his people.

In other words, they told Prophet Syuaib and his followers to choose whether they would remain in the new religion and continue preaching but be expelled from their land, or be willing to return to the religion of their ancestors and become members of the community of their polytheistic people.

It should be noted that the words "return to the religion of their ancestors" give the impression that Prophet Syuaib had once been a follower of his people's religion, and of course had also participated in worshiping the objects they worshiped. This is not true, because the prophets and messengers of Allah are always protected from major sins, including sins caused by associating partners with Allah (shirk).

At the end of the verse, it is explained that Prophet Syuaib answered their challenge by asking whether they would still force him and his followers to return to their religion or whether they would expel him and his followers from the land of Madyan if he refused that suggestion.

Prophet Syuaib affirmed to his people that he and his followers were not afraid of being expelled from their land, and they would remain in the religion of Allah and continue their preaching. Prophet Syuaib's love for the religion of Allah was greater than his love for the homeland whose inhabitants disbelieved in Allah. He and his followers prioritized living in the pleasure of Allah, so that they could truly obtain happiness in this world and the hereafter. Religion and faith are matters of the heart that cannot be forced in any way. He and his followers hated shirk, because shirk is a major sin that is not forgiven by Allah.

A messenger who carries the mandate to spread the religion of Allah does not object to leaving his homeland if the situation and conditions in that place do not allow him to carry out his duties. As is known, Prophet Ibrahim had performed hijrah, leaving his homeland, the city of Ur in Chaldea, in order to uphold the religion of Allah. Likewise, Prophet Muhammad had migrated from Mecca to Medina because his love for the religion of Allah exceeded his love for his homeland and other things. People who are reluctant to migrate for the sake of Allah will be condemned by Allah, as Allah says:

"Indeed, those whom the angels take [in death] while wronging themselves - [the angels] will say, "What [was] your condition?" They will say, "We were oppressed in the land." The angels will say, "Was not the earth of Allah spacious [enough] for you to emigrate therein?" For those, their refuge is Hell - and evil it is as a destination. Except for the oppressed among men and women and children who cannot devise a plan nor are they directed to a way - For those it is expected that Allah will pardon them, and Allah is ever Pardoning and Forgiving." (an-Nisa/4: 97-99)
text.89:
This verse explains Prophet Shuaib's words to his people who had threatened to expel him from their land if he did not stop his preaching. Prophet Shuaib said: "How great a sin and a lie would we be committing against Allah if we were to return to your religion, while Allah has saved us and guided us to the straight path. If someone follows your teachings without knowledge, it is considered as someone who is fabricating a lie against Allah, so how about someone who deliberately fabricates a lie against Him, and deliberately deviates from the path that has been shown to him consciously, even though he has knowledge of it. Such disbelief is a heinous act, and will not be forgiven. Therefore, we will not do it."

From Prophet Shuaib's affirmation, it can be concluded that Allah has saved his followers and companions, including himself, from the polytheistic religion adhered to by his people, or it can also be interpreted that Allah has saved Prophet Shuaib from polytheism. He never adhered to the beliefs held by his people and did not worship what they worshipped. Then Allah guided him to the right path. This is similar to what Prophet Muhammad experienced, as affirmed by Allah in His word:

"And He found you lost and guided [you]." (ad-dhuha/93: 7)

His other word:

"And thus We have revealed to you an inspiration [i.e., the Qur'an] of Our command. You did not know what was the Book or [what was] faith, but We have made it a light by which We guide whom We will of Our servants. And indeed, [O Muhammad], you guide to a straight path." (asy-Syura/42: 52)

Furthermore, Prophet Shuaib affirmed to his people that it was not appropriate and unreasonable for him and his followers to abandon the true religion and return to their religion, unless Allah willed it. The meaning is that Prophet Shuaib and his followers were convinced that the religion adhered to by his people was an untrue religion, while the religion adhered to by him and his followers was a true religion that could guarantee the safety and happiness of mankind in this world and the hereafter.

Allah did not want Prophet Shuaib and his followers to return to the religion of his people, which was full of polytheism, because Allah Himself had freed him from polytheism and guided him to the true religion. Therefore, Prophet Shuaib and his followers would not return to their religion.

Then Prophet Shuaib reminded them that Allah's knowledge is vast, encompassing everything. He knows all the wisdom and things that will bring harm to His servants. His will always applies in accordance with that wisdom. So everything that happens to His creatures is inseparable from that wisdom. Therefore, he and his followers only put their trust and surrender to Allah, and are accompanied by obedience in carrying out what Allah has commanded them, namely, guarding His sharia and religion. He is the One who will protect Prophet Shuaib and his followers from all the threats and disturbances of his people and from all dangers where Prophet Shuaib has no power to avoid and fight them.

It should be noted that one of the conditions of *tawakal* (reliance on Allah) is steadfastness in implementing the sharia that Allah has established, and obeying the general rules that He has established, both regarding nature and society, especially the relationship between cause and effect. For example, if we want to obtain sustenance from Allah, then we must strive, and maintain Allah's rules in carrying out these efforts. If the effort has been carried out according to the necessary methods, and maintaining the rules that Allah and His sharia have established, then we put our *tawakal*. *Tawakal* that is done without being preceded by a correct effort and in accordance with Allah's rules is a wrong *tawakal*. That is why the Prophet Muhammad saw once reprimanded a person who did not tie his camel when he wanted to face the Prophet, because he said he had put his *tawakal* in Allah first. He should have tied his camel first before leaving it. This is an effort to put *tawakal*. According to the usual circumstances, the camel will not run away if it has been tied properly. The Prophet said:

"Tie it and then put your trust (in Allah)." (Narrated by at-Tirmidzi)

After Prophet Shuaib declared his surrender to Allah swt, and then ended with, may Allah give a fair decision between him and his people, then he declared his recognition and belief that Allah swt is the best giver of decisions, because He is the Most Just and the All-Knowing.

As is known, before the birth of Prophet Shuaib in Madyan, many messengers had been sent by Allah to convey His religion to mankind. In general, these messengers were challenged and opposed by some of their people, who disbelieved in Allah. In the end, these messengers received help from Allah because they were people who carried out Allah's commands and always acted honestly and did good. Conversely, it was the disbelievers who met a bad fate as a result of their disbelief.
text.90:
The disbelievers among the people of Prophet Shuaib, namely their leaders who denied the verses of Allah and rejected His messenger, had committed injustice, including preventing others from believing in Prophet Shuaib and the religion he brought. They said: "If you believe and follow the call of Shuaib who invites to the religion of monotheism, surely you will lose because of that action, leaving the religion of your ancestors that you have adhered to all this time. You will lose glory and honor, because by following Shuaib you will consider your ancestors to be misguided and will be punished by Allah. Besides that, you will also lose wealth and multiple profits in trade because the religion of Shuaib does not allow deception in buying and selling, especially regarding measures and weights."

The leaders of Prophet Shuaib's people clearly acted arrogantly and disbelievingly. This arrogant attitude arose because they were in power in that land, and this characteristic prompted them to issue threats to Prophet Shuaib and his followers to expel them from Madyan. While their disbelief caused them to act to prevent others from embracing the religion of Allah brought by Prophet Shuaib. They are people who are misguided, and try to mislead others.
text.91:
Disbelief in Allah and the act of hindering others from embracing the religion of Allah are enormous crimes. Such people rightly deserve a fitting punishment. Therefore, Allah inflicted upon them a severe torment in the form of a devastating earthquake and thunder that destroyed them, so that they lay dead, scattered beneath the ruins of their houses, as if they had never existed in that land.

The story of Prophet Shuaib, besides being found in Surah al-A'raf, is also found in Surah Hud/11:85-95). However, there is a difference in mentioning the name of the torment inflicted upon his disbelieving people. In Surah al-A'raf verse 91, it is mentioned that the torment was in the form of "ar rajfah," which is a devastating earthquake. Meanwhile, in Surah Hud verse 94, it is mentioned that the torment was in the form of "Ash shaihatu," which is a loud, thunderous sound. However, these two verses are not contradictory, because both types of torment can occur in one sequence and produce the same result; the loud sound of lightning and the earthquake destroyed them, so that they lay dead, scattered beneath the ruins of their houses.

The story of Prophet Shuaib is also found in Surah ash-Shu'ara; here it is mentioned that Prophet Shuaib was sent by Allah to the people of Aikah (ash-Shu'ara/26:176). Meanwhile, in Surah al-A'raf, it is mentioned that Prophet Shuaib was a brother of the people of Madyan, that is, the inhabitants of the land of Madyan.

According to the explanation of Ishaq Ibnu Basyar, quoted from Ibn Asakir, Ibn Abbas gave the following explanation: "The people of Aikah were people who inhabited the swampy areas located between the coast of the Red Sea and the land of Madyan." From this explanation, it can be understood that Prophet Shuaib was sent by Allah to his people who had a relationship with them, all the way to the Red Sea. Both peoples had similarities, both regarding their disbelief and regarding the various acts of disobedience they committed, such as their dishonesty in weighing and measuring when trading. Prophet Shuaib preached the religion to all of them. Allah's torment befell both groups at the same time, or at a time close in distance. The torment inflicted upon the people of Madyan was in the form of "Ar rajfah," which is a devastating earthquake accompanied by a very loud rumbling sound, while the torment inflicted upon the people of Aikah was in the form of a hot wind and very hot air, which ended with the arrival of a cloud mass. They then gathered under the cloud that shaded them to get cool air, because they thought the cloud would bring rain, but the cloud mass turned out to be a hot cloud that would be inflicted upon them so that they all died, struck by the hot cloud. Some commentators are of the opinion that the torment inflicted upon the two groups was the same. (This will be explained further when interpreting Surah ash-Shu'ara).
text.92:
In the preceding verses, it was mentioned that the leaders of Prophet Shu'aib's people had threatened to expel Prophet Shu'aib and his followers from the land of Madyan if they refused to return to the religion of their ancestors. In this verse, Allah provides an explanation as an answer. Allah affirms that the consequence that will be suffered by those who threatened to expel Prophet Shu'aib from Madyan is that they themselves will be destroyed and vanish, as if they had never lived and inhabited this land. Likewise, those who deny Prophet Shu'aib and say that whoever follows his religion will surely be at a loss, it is they who are truly at a loss, while those who believe and follow the religion brought by Prophet Shu'aib will be saved and obtain Allah's pleasure.

From this verse, a valuable lesson can be learned, namely that those who strongly desire to remain in their land, living happily and acting arbitrarily towards those who uphold the truth, will inevitably meet a consequence that contradicts their expectations, namely destruction. Similarly, those who want to obtain the greatest possible profit by taking other people's wealth in a false way, such as through corruption, will inevitably meet an unfortunate fate, namely: the loss of property and self-respect forever.
text.93:
When the torment befell the people of Prophet Shuaib, and he departed from them, filled with sorrow, he said: "O my people, I have conveyed to you the messages of my Lord and advised you, but you turned your backs on all of it, so why should I grieve over a people who disbelieve?".

Prophet Shuaib was sent by Allah to guide his people to the true religion in order to achieve the pleasure of Allah and happiness in this world and the hereafter. For this, Prophet Shuaib had poured out all his energy, but they had chosen the path of error. They even denied him and threatened to expel him from his homeland. They had thrown themselves into the abyss of destruction because of their disbelief in Allah and His Messenger. Indeed, Allah did not wrong them.
text.94:
In this verse, it is explained that one of Allah's established decrees is that He sends His messengers to a people. Then, if that people denies His messenger, Allah inflicts trials upon them in the form of hardship in sustenance and suffering. These trials are intended to awaken them so that they become a people who are submissive and humble, sincerely praying to Allah's presence that they be released from this torment.

Luxury and the pleasures of life cause people to forget their Lord. However, when they are afflicted with hardship and difficulty, it will awaken awareness in their hearts, then they return to the path shown by their religion, and strive to improve themselves.

"And if Allah were to extend the provision for His servants, they would surely transgress in the earth, but He sends [it] down in an amount which He wills. Indeed He is, of His servants, Aware and Seeing." (ash-Shura/42: 27)

A person can only feel the blessing of wealth if they have once lost that wealth. A person only understands the blessing of health if they have once been sick. The same is true of other blessings that Allah has bestowed upon mankind.

Thus, it is clear that if Allah at some point withdraws His blessings from a person or a nation, the purpose is so that they become aware and willing to believe and obey Allah, certain of the attributes of Allah's power, justice, and compassion for His creation. So that they will return to humbling themselves before Allah and submitting to His rules, and hoping for His forgiveness, to release them from the hardship that befalls them.
text.95:
This verse explains that after they were afflicted with hardship and difficulties in life, and they strove to improve and pray to Allah, then Allah bestowed upon them blessings and ease in life, so that they obtained prosperity and sufficient wealth. This prosperity and sufficiency of wealth enabled them to develop offspring. Sufficient wealth and numerous offspring are the pinnacle of enjoyment for humans.

Those who believe, if they obtain blessings from Allah, whether in the form of wealth or offspring, will certainly increase in faith and gratitude, and will perform more good deeds. However, those who are weak in faith, when they obtain prosperity and abundant enjoyment, forget Allah Who bestows those blessings, and arrogance and pride arise. They say: "Our ancestors also experienced enjoyment and hardship, and so do we. The hardship we have experienced, and the happiness we feel now, are the same as what our ancestors experienced. The hardship that befalls us is not a result of the sins we have committed, and the happiness we obtain is not the result of the good deeds we have done." This admission and attitude is clearly an injustice that can occur at all times.

Thus, wealth and happiness have made them forget the relationship between cause and effect, and caused them to forget the power, justice, and compassion of Allah. This is because they do not understand the *Sunnah* of Allah that applies in this universe; they do not understand the factors that cause happiness and misery on this earth. Whereas Allah has given guidance with His word:

"Indeed, Allah will not change the condition of a people until they change what is in themselves." (ar-Rad/13: 11)

Therefore, their denial and arrogance arose after obtaining prosperity. Allah inflicted upon them a punishment that came suddenly, while they were unaware of its coming. They did not fulfill the *Sunnatullah* that applies in the affairs of society, and their minds were unable to think about it. Moreover, they did not want to follow the guidance, advice, and warnings of the Messenger to them. In this regard, Allah has said:

"So when they forgot that with which they had been reminded, We opened to them the doors of every (pleasant) thing, until, when they rejoiced in that which they were given, We seized them suddenly, and they were thereupon in despair." (al-Anam/6: 44)

The characteristic of the disbeliever is that when they obtain enjoyment and happiness, they are arrogant and conceited, not grateful for Allah's blessings. Conversely, when they are afflicted with calamity, they despair and complain, not thinking about the causes within themselves that cause the calamity. Allah says:

"And when affliction touches man, he calls upon Us; then when We grant him a favor from Us, he says, "I have only been given it because of [my] knowledge." Rather, it is a test, but most of them do not know." (az-Zumar/39: 49)

The pleasure obtained after hardship, which is then followed by a tormenting punishment, was not only experienced by the people of Prophet Shuaib, but also by the nations of previous prophets, namely the people of Prophet Noah, Prophet Hud, and Prophet Saleh. Prophet Hud warned his people, namely the people of Ad, as follows:

"And remember when He made you successors after the people of Noah and increased you in stature. So remember the favors of Allah that you might succeed." (al-Araf/7: 69)

Furthermore, Prophet Saleh also warned his people, the people of Thamud, about something similar:

"And remember when He made you successors after 'Aad and settled you in the land, you take for yourselves palaces from its plains and carve out homes from the mountains. Then remember the favors of Allah and do not commit abuse on the earth, spreading corruption." (al-Araf/7: 74)

The generation living today should truly realize this, so as not to experience the miserable fate experienced by previous nations, because of their denial and arrogance towards Allah. If the current generation is blessed by Allah with a better fate, in the form of economic and social stability, knowledge, and so on, let them not forget themselves and commit disobedience on earth. All the blessings bestowed by Allah should be gratefully received and utilized in a way that pleases Him and kept away from all kinds of disobedience. May Allah always increase His grace and blessings to all who are grateful.
text.96:
In this verse, it is explained that if the inhabitants of the city of Mecca and the lands surrounding it, as well as all of humanity, were to believe in the religion brought by the last prophet and messenger, namely Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him), and if they were to be pious towards Allah, thus distancing themselves from all that He has forbidden, such as polytheism and causing corruption on earth, then Allah would surely bestow upon them abundant goodness, both from the heavens and from the earth. Blessings that come from the heavens, for example, are rain that waters and fertilizes the earth, so that plants grow and livestock multiply, all of which are greatly needed by humans. In addition, they would obtain a great deal of knowledge, as well as the ability to understand the *Sunnatullah* that applies in this universe, so that they are able to connect cause and effect. Thus, they will be able to build a good life, and avoid the disasters that usually befall people who deny Allah and are ungrateful for His blessings and favors.

If the inhabitants of Mecca and its surroundings do not believe, deny the Messenger, and reject the religion he brought, and continue in the polytheism and disobedience they commit, then Allah will inflict punishment upon them, even though that punishment is not the same as the punishment that was inflicted upon previous peoples, which was destructive. The certainty of this punishment is in accordance with the *Sunnatullah* that He has established and cannot be changed by anyone other than Allah.
text.97: In this verse, Allah gives a warning to those who disbelieve, in the form of a question, "Do the people of the cities feel secure that Our punishment will not come upon them by night while they are asleep?" The meaning is that Allah's punishment is inflicted upon those who have received the call of the messengers but disbelieve and do not use their intellect. Because if they were to think and learn from the events experienced by previous communities, the result of being immersed in the pleasures of life to the point that they forget Allah who gives blessings, surely they would feel anxious about the possibility of Allah's punishment coming upon them. Such anxiety would certainly encourage them to immediately improve their behavior, including distancing themselves from all forms of shirk and disobedience. However, the reality is not so. They even feel safe and have no fear whatsoever of Allah's punishment coming upon them. This is evident from their behavior, which continues to be immersed in pleasure, and remains in shirk and various forms of disobedience to Allah.
text.98:
In this verse, Allah once again censures the behavior of those who disbelieve, namely, they appear to have no concern about the possibility of Allah's punishment coming upon them when they are in a state of heedlessness.

With this statement, Allah warns them that His punishment may befall them while they are heedless, whether during their morning sleep or while they are engrossed in frivolous pursuits, so that they will no longer have time to prepare themselves for their salvation. Therefore, it is best for them to realize and be wary of Allah's punishment, especially since they have heard the call of the Messenger and the advice given to them to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter.
text.99:
In this verse, Allah once again repeats His rebuke of the behavior of the disbelievers, "Do they feel secure from Allah's plan? But none feel secure from Allah's plan except the losing people." Then Allah explains that it is such people who will be the losers.

With this statement, Allah affirms that a person of sound mind who holds fast to the fitrah (natural disposition) that He has bestowed upon humanity, and who pays attention to historical events and occurrences, as well as to the signs of Allah, will certainly not feel secure from the coming of His punishment. However, those who disbelieve have truly lost their sound minds and the fitrah that Allah has bestowed upon them, and they also refuse to pay attention to historical events and the signs of Allah, so they have truly become the losers. They have lost their fear of the coming of Allah's punishment, even though they constantly commit disobedience and shirk (associating partners with Allah).

For the believer, the correct attitude is to be certain of the forgiving and merciful nature of Allah, yet he must always fear His punishment that may come upon him unexpectedly, as a result of his actions. Therefore, they are always careful and avoid things that will cause that punishment to come upon them.

In the Al-Quran, the disbelievers are often called "the losers." So, those who lose their fear of Allah's punishment are the same as those who despair of Allah's forgiveness and mercy; both of these characteristics are among the characteristics of the disbelievers, who are also called the losers.
text.100:
In this verse, it is emphasized that the people who inherit a land after the disappearance of its inhabitants due to Allah's punishment for their denial of Him, understand and believe that Allah is capable of inflicting that punishment upon them for their sins if He wills. Also, Allah is capable of sealing their hearts, so that they can no longer receive religious lessons and advice and are unwilling to believe.

As mentioned in the previous section, Allah sent several messengers to their people before the sending of Prophet Shu'aib to his people. The previous peoples were afflicted with Allah's punishment because of their sins and their denial of Allah. The punishment that befell them was so severe, destroying them in such a way, that it was as if they had never lived on this earth. After they disappeared, Allah brought a new people to inhabit the land. This new people knew the history of the previous people, because their books and holy scriptures mentioned it. They knew what the people had experienced, namely a terrible punishment. And they knew the things that caused that punishment to be brought upon them, namely because of the sins of their denial of Allah and His Messenger.

They should have been able to learn from historical events, to understand that Allah is capable of inflicting a similar punishment upon themselves if they commit sins and disobedience like the previous people.

This verse is not only a warning to the disbelievers, but also to the Muslims. After knowing the reasons for the punishment inflicted on the people of the previous Messengers and after knowing *sunnatullah* (Allah's way) regarding sinful peoples, we should distance ourselves from similar mistakes, so that we are not afflicted with Allah's punishment that will cause us to lose everything.
text.101:
In this verse, Allah tells Prophet Muhammad that Allah is recounting to him some of the news concerning the lands that He has destroyed because of the behavior of their inhabitants who were disbelieving and fond of committing disobedience. By knowing these stories, Prophet Muhammad will not feel sad seeing the behavior, disbelief, and arrogance of his people, because what he is experiencing has been experienced by previous messengers. The behavioral patterns of the disbelievers and polytheists are the same throughout time, and the *Sunnatullah* that applies to them also does not change.

The events that befell the mentioned lands occurred in the past, centuries before the birth of Prophet Muhammad, so neither he nor his people knew about these events. Therefore, Allah reveals these events to Prophet Muhammad through the Al-Quran so that they can be a lesson for his people.

Furthermore, in this verse, Allah reveals that the messengers were sent to previous communities, bringing clear explanations and evidence of the oneness of Allah, but they still refused to believe in Allah and His religion. They remained disbelieving and constantly engaged in polytheism and various acts of disobedience.

Some of them knew the truth brought by the messengers, but they still disbelieved. Disbelief had indeed become their character and nature, while others disbelieved simply because of blindly following what they inherited from their ancestors, without thinking about it or examining it first.

In another verse similar to this verse, Allah says:

"Then after him We sent messengers to their peoples, and they came to them with clear proofs, but they would not believe in what they had rejected before. Thus We seal over the hearts of the transgressors." (Yunus/10: 74)

Allah's further word explains that Allah seals the hearts of the disbelievers. The word "seal" reminds us of the making of coins and other materials from metal. The item is shaped and engraved when the metal is being heated, then after the metal cools and solidifies, it can no longer be shaped or engraved. Such is the analogy of the conscience of the disbelievers, it has solidified and closed off completely, so they can no longer receive any lessons or advice that is presented to them. They refuse to accept the religion brought by the messengers, which calls to the *akidah* of *tauhid* and worshiping Allah alone, no matter how clear the explanations and evidence, as well as the reasons and arguments, that are given to them.
text.102:
In this verse, it is emphasized that Allah found that most of the previous communities did not like to keep their promises, and most of them were transgressors (fasik).

Regarding the "promise" referred to in this verse, there are several interpretations from the scholars. Among them, some say that the promise refers to the original fitrah (natural disposition) that Allah gave to every human being, which is the inclination that encourages humans to return to their Lord when they face difficulties; or to be grateful to Him when they are spared from difficulties or obtain life's pleasures. However, they remain in denial and disobedience. Conversely, the pleasures and ease of life do not encourage them to be grateful to Allah, and they do not even acknowledge these blessings as gifts and mercy from Him.

Another opinion states that the "promise" in the verse refers to the original nature or fitrah that Allah gave to every human being, which is the inclination towards the belief in tawhid (monotheism), faith in His oneness, and worshiping Him alone, without associating anything with Him. However, in reality, they have abandoned their fitrah, and cast aside the belief in tawhid, even associating partners with Allah, ignoring the calls of the messengers and the explanations and evidence presented. They only follow the desires of their own lusts and the whispers of Satan, contrary to their pure fitrah. In a hadith narrated by Imam Muslim, it is mentioned that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) said:

Allah swt said: "Indeed, I have created My servants as believers in tawhid; then the devil came and turned them away from their original religion, and forbade them what I had made lawful for them." (Riwayat Muslim)

In another hadith narrated by Imam al-Bukhari and Muslim, the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said:

"Every child is born in a state of fitrah, then his parents make him a Jew, a Christian, or a Magian." (Riwayat al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Thus, it is clear that if a person deviates from the belief in tawhid, it is due to external influences, not the fitrah that he brought from his mother's womb, which Allah bestowed upon every human being.

As for the characteristic of fasik mentioned in this verse, it refers to someone who repeatedly commits various sins, ignoring religious advice and teachings, as well as its laws and threats.

It should be noted that Allah's statement in this verse says that most of them were fasik. This implies that not all of the previous communities were fasik and abandoned the belief in tawhid, which is the pure fitrah that Allah bestowed upon every servant. In fact, some of them remained in their pure fitrah, so they immediately welcomed the arrival of the messengers who brought the religion of tawhid, and they always distanced themselves from all kinds of disobedience and polytheism. These are the ones who always accompanied the messengers in facing threats and disturbances from the disbelievers, and they are the ones whom Allah always saved along with His Messenger from the torment and disasters inflicted upon the fasik people.
text.103:
The story of Prophet Musa (Moses), peace be upon him, in the Quran is mostly found in Makki surahs, both long and short, starting from Surah al-A'raf, which is the first Makki surah according to the arrangement of the surahs of the Quran, where the story of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) is found. Then there are also Surah Taha, Ash-Shu'ara, An-Naml, Al-Qasas, Yunus, Hud, and Al-Mu'minun.

The name of Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) is often mentioned in the Quran more than 130 times. No other prophet or king has their name mentioned as many times in the Quran. This is partly because the story of Prophet Musa is very similar to the story of Prophet Muhammad. In addition, both prophets had large communities with high levels of power and civilization.

Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) was the son of Imran. He was of Israelite nationality, born in Egypt, when the Children of Israel settled in Egypt, during the reign of the Pharaohs.

In this verse, Allah tells us that after sending His messengers mentioned in the previous verses, He sent Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) with His signs to Pharaoh and his chiefs. Pharaoh was the title used by the kings of Egypt in ancient times, just as the title "Kisra" was for the kings of Persia and the title "Caesar" for the kings of Rome. The Pharaoh who ruled in Egypt during the time of Prophet Musa was named Minepthah Ramses II. He was a ruler of the nineteenth dynasty, around 1491 BC. Minepthah's mummy (corpse) still exists today and is kept in the Egyptian National Museum, Cairo.

It is mentioned in this verse that Pharaoh and his chiefs disbelieved in the signs of Allah brought by Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) to them. They rejected the signs or miracles brought by Musa (peace be upon him) with arrogance and pride. Pharaoh and the leaders of his people enslaved their people, especially the Children of Israel, who were foreigners living in Egypt at that time, under the oppressive rule of Pharaoh and his chiefs.

If Pharaoh and his chiefs had believed in Prophet Musa and the religion he brought, then all the people of Egypt at that time would have believed as well, because they were all under the control of Pharaoh and his dignitaries.

Because of the denial of Pharaoh and his dignitaries, at the end of this verse, Allah commands Prophet Muhammad and his ummah to pay attention to the consequences of those who deny His messengers and cause corruption on earth, namely by committing injustice and enslaving fellow human beings. Allah will tell in the next verse how Prophet Musa, as one of the oppressed Children of Israel, was finally able to defeat Pharaoh's magicians and convince his scholars of the truth of the message he brought.

The Children of Israel are the descendants of Prophet Yaqub (Jacob), whose other name was Israel. Prophet Yaqub came from Canaan (Palestine). He moved to Egypt with his family and sons after being invited by his son, Prophet Yusuf (Joseph), to move to Egypt. Prophet Yusuf at that time was appointed by the King of Egypt as a ruler in charge of the country's supplies. The descendants of Prophet Yaqub then multiplied in Egypt, eventually becoming a large nation called the Children of Israel.

Pharaoh tried to prevent the Children of Israel from continuing to multiply by killing every male child born to them and allowing the female children to live. They were required to pay very high taxes and were made forced laborers and subjected to various forms of oppression and slavery.

Therefore, Allah sent Prophet Musa to free them from Pharaoh's slavery and bring them out of Egypt. Allah's help to Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) further was to inflict punishment on Pharaoh and save the people of Prophet Musa, and the drowning of Pharaoh and his followers and his army in the Red Sea when they were chasing Prophet Musa and his people. This story contains a valuable lesson that material strength alone does not guarantee victory for a person or a nation. Conversely, a people who have strong faith in Allah will surely receive help from Him, so that the people will be able to defeat those who only rely on material strength.
text.104:
In this verse, the first words of Musa (Moses), peace be upon him, to Pharaoh after Allah appointed him as a Messenger are narrated. Prophet Musa informed Pharaoh that he was a messenger of Allah, the Lord of the Universe. This notification meant that: Musa had carried out his duty as a prophet of Allah, the Creator and Ruler of the entire universe. Therefore, Pharaoh should accept Prophet Musa's explanation and not hinder his duty as a Messenger.

Furthermore, Prophet Musa added that he spoke the truth about Allah. Meaning: what he said, that Allah is the Lord of the Universe, and that He had sent him as a Messenger, was the truth. He did not say anything untrue, because it is impossible for Allah to send someone who likes to lie.

Then it was emphasized again that Musa brought evidence bestowed upon him by Allah to prove the truth of his *dakwah* (call/invitation). In that statement, Prophet Musa used the expression: "Indeed, I have come to you with a sign from your Lord." This was to show that Pharaoh was not God, but merely a servant of God. While the true God is Allah SWT.

This explanation is very important, because the arrogant Pharaoh had claimed to be God and ordered his people to worship him. So, Prophet Musa's affirmation denied Pharaoh's lies and arrogance, which had positioned himself as God. In addition, Prophet Musa's expression also implies that the evidence he brought was a gift from Allah, not from himself.

At the end of this verse, it is mentioned that after presenting the above explanations, and after a tiring struggle, Musa, peace be upon him, demanded that Pharaoh release the Children of Israel from the clutches of his power and enslavement, and allow them to go with Prophet Musa to leave Egypt, back to their homeland in Palestine, so that they would be free and independent to worship their Lord and carry out His teachings.

Prophet Musa's demand implies that slavery by humans against fellow humans must be eliminated, and a ruler should give freedom to those under his rule to embrace religion and perform worship according to their respective beliefs. Therefore, if Pharaoh did not want to believe in Allah, he should not prevent others from believing and worshiping according to their beliefs.

It is interesting to note that the first words of Prophet Musa, peace be upon him, in carrying out his duty as a Messenger are different from the words of the Prophets and Messengers before him when they began their *dakwah*, for example:

a. The first words of Prophet Nuh (Noah), peace be upon him, to his people were as follows:

"We had certainly sent Noah to his people, and he said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a tremendous Day!" (al-Araf/7:59)

b. The words of Prophet Hud to the people of 'Ad were:

"And to 'Aad [We sent] their brother Hud. He said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. Then will you not fear Him?" (al-Araf/7: 65)

And the words of Prophet Saleh to the people of Thamud were:

"And to Thamud [We sent] their brother Salih. He said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. There has come to you clear evidence from your Lord. This is the she-camel of Allah [sent] to you as a sign. So leave her to eat within Allah's land and do not touch her with harm, lest there seize you a painful punishment." (al-Araf/7: 73)

c. The words of Prophet Shuaib to his people, the inhabitants of Madyan, were:

"And to the people of Madyan [We sent] their brother Shu'ayb. He said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. There has come to you clear evidence from your Lord. Give full measure and weight and do not deprive people of their due and cause not corruption upon the earth after its reformation. That is better for you, if you should be believers." (al-Araf/7: 85)

While the first words of Prophet Musa addressed to Pharaoh were:

"O Pharaoh, I am a messenger from the Lord of the worlds." (al-Araf/7: 104)

If we compare these verses, we see a difference between them, namely that: the first words of the Messengers before Prophet Musa, peace be upon him, addressed to their respective peoples contained a call to the religion of *tauhid* (monotheism), namely worshiping Allah alone, on the grounds that there is no god for humans other than Allah. While the first words of Prophet Musa addressed to Pharaoh contained a notification to him that Musa was a messenger of Allah. Thus, in that statement, there was no explicit call to Pharaoh to worship Allah.

From this, we can draw the following conclusions or understandings:

a. The main object (target) of Musa's *dakwah* was not only Pharaoh but also his own people, namely the Children of Israel. Musa was tasked with freeing the Children of Israel from Pharaoh's enslavement and guiding his people to the true religion.

b. Prophet Musa knew the character and behavior of Pharaoh. Pharaoh not only denied Allah, but he also considered himself to be God and ordered others to worship him. Therefore, Pharaoh was only given a warning that the real God was not him, but Allah, the Creator of the universe. Because there was no benefit in inviting Pharaoh to worship Allah, this invitation would certainly be ignored and disregarded.
text.105:
In this verse, the first words of Moses spoken to Pharaoh after Allah appointed him as a Messenger are narrated. Prophet Moses informed Pharaoh that he was a messenger of Allah, Lord of the Universe. This notification means that: Moses had carried out his duty as a prophet of Allah, the Creator and Ruler of the entire universe. Therefore, Pharaoh should accept Prophet Moses' explanation and not hinder his duty as a Messenger.

Furthermore, Prophet Moses added that he spoke the truth about Allah. Meaning: what he said, that Allah is the Lord of the Universe, and that He had sent him as a Messenger, is the truth. He did not say anything untrue, because it is impossible for Allah to send someone who likes to lie.

Then it is emphasized again that Moses brought evidence bestowed upon him by Allah, to prove the truth of his da'wah (call to Islam). In that statement, Prophet Moses used the expression: "Indeed, I have come to you with clear proof from your Lord." This is to show that Pharaoh was not God, but merely a servant of God. While the true God is Allah swt.

This explanation is very important, because the arrogant Pharaoh had claimed to be God and ordered his people to worship him. Thus, Prophet Moses' affirmation refuted Pharaoh's lies and arrogance, who had positioned himself as God. In addition, Prophet Moses' expression also implies that the evidence he brought was a gift from Allah, not from himself.

At the end of this verse, it is mentioned that after presenting the above explanations, and after a tiring struggle, Moses as demanded that Pharaoh release the Children of Israel from the clutches of his power and enslavement, and allow them to go with Prophet Moses to leave Egypt, back to their homeland in Palestine, so that they would be free and independent to worship their Lord and carry out His teachings.

Prophet Moses' demand implies that slavery by humans against fellow humans must be abolished, and a ruler should give freedom to those under his rule to embrace religion and perform worship according to their respective beliefs. Therefore, if Pharaoh did not want to believe in Allah, he should not prevent others from believing and worshiping according to their beliefs.

It is interesting to note that the first words of Prophet Moses as in carrying out his duties as a Messenger are different from the words of the previous Prophets and Messengers when they began their da'wah, for example:

a. The first words of Prophet Noah as to his people were as follows:

"We had certainly sent Noah to his people, and he said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. Indeed, I fear for you the punishment of a tremendous Day!" (al-Araf/7:59)

b. The words of Prophet Hud to the people of 'Ad were:

"And to 'Aad [We sent] their brother Hud. He said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. Then will you not fear Him?" (al-Araf/7: 65)

And the words of Prophet Salih to the people of Thamud were:

"And to Thamud [We sent] their brother Salih. He said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. There has come to you clear evidence from your Lord. This is the she-camel of Allah presented to you as a sign. So leave her to graze on Allah's earth and do not touch her with harm, lest there seize you a painful punishment." (al-Araf/7: 73)

c. The words of Prophet Shuaib to his people, the inhabitants of Madyan, were:

"And to the people of Madyan [We sent] their brother Shu'ayb. He said, "O my people, worship Allah; you have no deity other than Him. There has come to you clear evidence from your Lord. Give full measure and weight and do not deprive people of their due and cause not corruption upon the earth after its reformation. That is better for you, if you should be believers." (al-Araf/7: 85)

While the first words of Prophet Moses addressed to Pharaoh were:

"O Pharaoh, I am a messenger from the Lord of the worlds." (al-Araf/7: 104)

If we compare these verses, there is a difference between them, namely that: the first words of the Messengers before Prophet Moses as addressed to their respective peoples contained a call to the religion of *tauhid* (monotheism), namely worshiping Allah alone, on the grounds that there is no god for humans other than Allah. While the first words of Prophet Moses addressed to Pharaoh contained a notification to him that Moses was a messenger of Allah. Thus, in that statement, there was no explicit call to Pharaoh to worship Allah.

From this, we can draw the following conclusions or understandings:

a. The main object (target) of Moses' da'wah was not only Pharaoh but also his own people, namely the Children of Israel. Moses was tasked with freeing the Children of Israel from Pharaoh's enslavement and guiding his people to the true religion.

b. Prophet Moses knew the character and behavior of Pharaoh. Pharaoh not only denied Allah, but he also considered himself to be God and ordered others to worship him. Therefore, Pharaoh was only given a warning that the true God was not him, but Allah, the Creator of the universe. Because there was no benefit in inviting Pharaoh to worship Allah, this invitation would certainly be ignored and unheeded.
text.106: In this verse is mentioned Pharaoh's response to Prophet Musa, that if it were true that Prophet Musa came to demonstrate his prophethood, then he should prove the truth of his words, that he was a messenger of Allah, and that he received miracles from Him. Initially, Pharaoh suspected that Musa was simply lying about being a messenger of Allah. Therefore, Pharaoh requested that the proof of his prophethood and miracles be shown not only in front of him but also in public so that many people would know about it.
text.107: Pharaoh's challenge was immediately answered by Prophet Musa by displaying two kinds of his miracles. First, Musa threw his staff to the ground, and suddenly the staff became a large snake that possessed the biological characteristics of a snake, able to move and walk in reality, unlike the snakes created by the magicians of that time, which only appeared as if they were moving snakes, when in fact they were not. People saw the object as moving because their minds had been influenced beforehand by the magicians. This was different from the snake that transformed from Prophet Musa's staff.
text.108:
In this verse, it is explained that Prophet Musa (Moses) showed his second miracle, which was his hand appearing radiant, emitting a bright light.

After he threw his staff, and those present witnessed the snake that transformed from the staff, Prophet Musa then inserted his hand into his armpit through the neck of his garment, and then took it out. It turned out that his hand became brilliantly white and sparkling, and could be clearly seen by those who witnessed it, including Pharaoh and his followers.

In the story of Prophet Musa found in Surah Taha, Surah an-Naml, and Surah al-Qasas, it is emphasized that the sparkling white color that appeared on Prophet Musa's hand at that time was a healthy white color, not a white color caused by vitiligo or other diseases.

It should be remembered that in the books of tafsir that base their interpretations on narrations received from people of the past, there are often exaggerated and very strange stories about the snake that transformed from Prophet Musa's staff. We must be vigilant and careful in accepting such narrations, because they do not have a strong basis. Some even originate from Israiliyat narrations, which are tales that come from the Jews, which infiltrated the Muslim community with the aim of damaging the Islamic religion from within. Historical facts show that the slander and chaos that occurred within the Muslim community, even the assassinations of caliphs, were instigated by these infiltrators, such as Abdullah Ibn Saba from the Jewish people who pretended to convert to Islam. He then created chaos in the fields of aqidah (creed), politics, and so on, in the early days of Islam.

Thankfully, among the Islamic scholars, there have emerged vigilant intellectuals who have conducted investigations into these narrations and prefer narrations that have a strong basis, the truth of which is not doubted.
text.109:
In this verse, it is explained that after the leaders of Pharaoh's people witnessed the miracles shown by Prophet Musa to them, their consciences did not believe; instead, they accused Prophet Musa of performing magic. They considered the transformation of Prophet Musa's staff into a large snake, which they witnessed, to be the same as what famous magicians of that time could do.

Magic can be divided into three types:

1.  Magic that uses certain natural objects, which are treated in such a way with specific methods known only to magicians themselves, thus producing an effect (impression) that is very amazing for societies whose way of thinking is still primitive (simple).

2.  Magic that is based on the speed of the hand in hiding and revealing certain objects, so that their shape and appearance look different from their actual state. This is similar to magic tricks in our time now.

3.  Magic that is based on the science of hypnosis, which is influencing weak souls by people who have strong souls. And sometimes they use the influence of jinn, resulting in frightening actions that make people hysterical, such as the *jailangkung* game, and so on.
text.110:
This verse explains that Pharaoh's dignitaries incited Pharaoh by declaring to him that Moses was a knowledgeable person with malicious intent, namely to seize power from Pharaoh's hands and expel him and his followers from the land of Egypt. This incitement was successful, leading Pharaoh to ask them what they would do to Moses.

In the story of Prophet Moses found in Surah Yunus, the words of Pharaoh's dignitaries to Prophet Moses are also explained as follows:

"They said, "Have you come to us to turn us away from that [way] upon which we found our fathers and so that you two may have greatness in the land? And we are not believers in you." (Yunus/10:78)
text.111:
Because Pharaoh sought advice from his dignitaries, they suggested that Moses and his brother (namely Prophet Aaron) be detained, and the resolution of the matter be postponed for the time being. In addition, Pharaoh's dignitaries said that Pharaoh should immediately send messengers to all corners of the land to gather highly skilled magicians, who were expected to be able to defeat the miracle of Prophet Moses that had been shown to them.

Their suggestion to postpone the matter of Prophet Moses indicates that Pharaoh had intended to kill Prophet Moses and his brother Aaron. Then the dignitaries suggested that Pharaoh should not rush to carry out the killing before testing its truth by confronting him with skilled magicians, so that the matter would become clear to the public.

From this verse, it can be understood that the suggestion to gather all the most skilled magicians in the land of Egypt at that time shows how great the miracle that Allah bestowed upon Prophet Moses was, so that they felt the need to gather all the skilled magicians to oppose him. Besides showing the ignorance of Pharaoh and his followers, who could not understand that what Prophet Moses showed them was a gift from Allah Almighty. Because of their lack of understanding, they thought it was the same as magic. In addition, this event also shows that one of the characteristics of humans is to like to oppose even though they see something that is true. This trait is what drove Pharaoh and his followers to gather their magicians to oppose Prophet Moses (peace be upon him).

If we investigate the motive that drove them to oppose the messenger and the religion he brought, it was none other than their fear of losing influence, and their desire to maintain their position, power, authority, and possessions. So Pharaoh's leaders incited Pharaoh by stating that Moses intended to seize power from Pharaoh's hands and expel him from his land. Such sycophantic behavior is always found throughout time.

In addition, this event also shows that one of the characteristics of humans is to like to oppose even though they see something that is true. This trait is what drove Pharaoh and his followers to gather their magicians to oppose Prophet Moses (peace be upon him).

If we investigate the motive that drove them to oppose the messenger and the religion he brought, it was none other than their fear of losing influence, and their desire to maintain their position, power, authority, and possessions. So Pharaoh's leaders incited Pharaoh by stating that Moses intended to seize power from Pharaoh's hands and expel him from his country. Such sycophantic behavior is always found throughout time.
text.113: After Pharaoh mobilized his people to gather skilled magicians from various corners of his dominion, when these magicians came to Pharaoh, they said to him, "Will we receive a reward, for this difficult task, if we are successful in defeating Moses?" Thus, the magicians' motivation was the same as the background of Pharaoh's dignitaries' struggle: material possessions, position, and money. There was absolutely no idealism, spiritualism, or noble morality. Their life's purpose was only for the moment: money.
text.114:
Pharaoh answered their question, "Yes, you will receive a great reward, and besides that, you will be among those close to us, so you will obtain rank and wealth that will give you pleasure and happiness."

Pharaoh's answer to the magicians showed that he greatly needed their strength and expertise, because he was very worried about losing his position and kingdom, believing that disaster would befall him if he did not fulfill their requests. Therefore, the reward promised to them was not only a wage in the form of money and goods, but also rank and position as people close to the king. This was a dream and pride coveted by many.
text.115:
After receiving a reassuring answer and promise from Pharaoh, the magicians then turned to Prophet Musa and said to him: "Which of us will begin first, you or us?"

This challenge of theirs shows that Pharaoh's magicians were very confident and very proud of the power of their magic. They did not care about the consequences that would befall them if they were unable to prove the power of their magic, if not for this excessive confidence they certainly would not have given their enemy the first opportunity.
text.116:
Prophet Musa allowed them to go first, without feeling worried about the power and effectiveness of their magic, because he was certain of Allah's help, and he was certain that miracles would not be defeated by human magic.

The magicians then threw their ropes and staffs to the ground, and they bewitched the sight of the crowd who witnessed the event, including Prophet Musa himself. The crowd was affected by their magic, seeing all the ropes and staffs had turned into snakes, so they felt afraid, because they thought they were real snakes. Allah says:

"Then suddenly their ropes and their staffs appeared to him [Musa] as though they were moving swiftly because of their magic." (Taha/20: 66)

They seemed to have successfully performed a powerful magic that had a great influence on the people who witnessed it. Even Prophet Musa himself initially felt apprehensive. This is mentioned by Allah in other verses with His saying:

And His saying in the following verse:

"So Musa conceived fear within himself. We said, "Fear not! Indeed, you are superior (victorious)." (Taha/20: 67-68)
text.117: After Allah calmed Prophet Musa, Allah said to him, "Throw down your staff (to the ground)." Then suddenly the staff transformed into a real serpent, and swallowed all the serpents resulting from their magic. Because the miracle of Prophet Musa's staff becoming a real serpent, and then eating the ropes and small sticks that were bewitched into serpents, this became an extraordinary event worthy of being a miracle of a Prophet, a messenger of Allah.
text.118:
In this verse, it is affirmed that with the disappearance of all the snakes created by Pharaoh's magicians from the sight of those who witnessed it, it signified victory for the miracle of Prophet Musa over the deeds of the magicians, which were full of falsehood and deception. Their magic became powerless in the face of the miracle of Allah's messenger.

In the story of Prophet Musa found in Surah Taha, in connection with this matter, Allah says:

"What they have produced is but the trickery of a magician, and the magician will never be successful, no matter how he comes." (Taha/20: 69)

While in his story found in Surah Yunus, Allah says the following:

"And when they had thrown, Musa said, "What you have brought is [only] magic. Indeed, Allah will expose its worthlessness. Indeed, Allah does not amend the work of corrupters." (Yunus/10: 81)
text.119:
In this verse, Allah affirms that the magicians were defeated in that place, and they became humiliated. This means that if before that event, the magicians felt proud and excessively confident, after the defeat, their lies and falsehood were exposed, because their magic had no power at all. In addition, because of this defeat, their hopes of obtaining wealth, rank, and riches that Pharaoh had promised them vanished.

The defeat of the magicians meant the defeat of Pharaoh and his dignitaries. Initially, they believed that the most intelligent magicians they had gathered from various places within their territory could easily defeat Prophet Musa. Therefore, he made extravagant promises, but it turned out that his magicians were defeated, and Prophet Musa was victorious, so Pharaoh and his leaders' hopes of maintaining their greatness and power faded. Their greatness disappeared in the eyes of the people, and they became humiliated. Moreover, this event occurred on one of their holidays and was witnessed by many people. Regarding this, Allah says in another verse:

He (Musa) said, "Your appointment is on the day of the festival, and let the people be assembled in the forenoon." (thaha/20: 59)
text.120:
This verse explains that after witnessing the magnificence of Prophet Musa's miracle, the magicians immediately prostrated to Allah, because they were convinced of the truth of Prophet Musa's call, and that he was not a magician as they had previously thought, according to the accusations of Pharaoh and his chiefs. Furthermore, they realized that their magic, which they had boasted about all this time, was only falsehood and powerless when faced with the truth that came from Allah the Almighty. They no longer had any respect for Pharaoh and his chiefs who had tried with all their might to deny the power and greatness of Allah, the Creator and Ruler of the universe.

Regarding the prostration of the magicians, Allah explains it in another verse as follows:

"Then the magicians fell down prostrating. They said, "We have believed in the Lord of Harun and Musa." (thaha/20:70)

In another verse, Allah says:

"So the magicians fell down prostrating. They said, "We have believed in the Lord of the worlds." (asy-Syuara/26:46-47)
text.121:
This verse explains that after witnessing the magnificence of Prophet Musa's miracle, the magicians immediately prostrated to Allah, because they were convinced of the truth of Prophet Musa's call, and that he was not a magician as they had previously thought, in accordance with the accusations of Pharaoh and his dignitaries. Furthermore, they realized that their magic, which they had boasted about all this time, was only falsehood and powerless when faced with the truth that came from Allah the Almighty. They no longer had any respect for Pharaoh and his dignitaries who had tried with all their might to deny the power and greatness of Allah, the Creator and Ruler of the universe.

Regarding the prostration of the magicians, Allah explains it in another verse as follows:

"Then the magicians fell down prostrating. They said, "We have believed in the Lord of Aaron and Moses." (Taha/20:70)

In another verse, Allah says:

"So the magicians fell down prostrating. They said, "We have believed in the Lord of the worlds." (asy-Syu’ara’/26:46-47)
text.122:
(120-122) In these verses, it is explained that after witnessing the magnificence of Prophet Musa's miracle, the magicians immediately prostrated to Allah, because they were convinced of the truth of Prophet Musa's call, and that he was not a magician as they had previously thought, according to the accusations of Pharaoh and his chiefs. Furthermore, they realized that their magic, which they had boasted about all this time, was only falsehood and powerless when faced with the truth that came from Allah the Almighty. They no longer had any respect for Pharaoh and his chiefs who had tried with all their might to deny the power and greatness of Allah, the Creator and Ruler of the universe.

Regarding the prostration of the magicians, Allah explains it in another verse as follows:

"Then the magicians fell down prostrating. They said, "We have believed in the Lord of Harun and Musa." (Taha/20:70)

In another verse, Allah says:

"So the magicians fell down prostrating. They said, "We have believed in the Lord of the worlds." (ash-Shu'ara'/26:46-47)
text.123:
In this verse, it is narrated that Pharaoh, in great anger, said to the magicians who had declared their faith in the Lord of Prophet Moses, "Why did you believe in him before I gave you permission?" Meaning, why did they declare faith in Moses and the religion he brought, which is based on belief in the oneness of Allah, even though he had not given them permission or ordered them to do so. Why did they submit to become followers of Prophet Moses before asking Pharaoh for permission first.

Pharaoh's statement shows that he still did not realize that what Prophet Moses showed before him was a miracle given by Allah that could not be defeated by anyone. And he did not realize that those who witnessed the victory of Prophet Moses no longer had any respect for him, and that he was no longer a lord to be obeyed. In addition, he accused the magicians of having conspired with Prophet Moses beforehand, so that their defeat when facing Prophet Moses had been planned in advance. Therefore, he continued his threat against them with the following statement: "Indeed, this is a trick you have planned in the city to drive out its people from Egypt; but you will soon know the consequences of this."

In another verse, Allah mentions that Pharaoh accused Prophet Moses of being a master of magic who had taught his magic to the magicians, to jointly deceive Pharaoh and his followers in order to expel him from the land of Egypt, so that they could then seize power in the land of Egypt, and Pharaoh said:

"Indeed, he is your leader who taught you magic." (thaha/20: 71)
text.124:
In this verse, it is narrated that Pharaoh continued his threat to them: "Surely I will cut off your hands and your feet on opposite sides, and then I will crucify you all."

Thus, Pharaoh considered the magicians guilty because they believed in Allah without seeking his permission first. Therefore, he felt entitled and powerful to impose a severe punishment on them, by cutting off their right hands and left feet, or vice versa. After that, he would crucify each of them. This punishment was also intended to intimidate others who intended to commit similar deception against him or intended to rebel and free themselves from his power.

Pharaoh was very worried that his people, the Egyptians, would also follow in the footsteps of the magicians to believe in Moses (peace be upon him), because this would lead to the collapse of his kingdom and his power as a god to his people who had been forced to worship him as God. In addition, he also tried to act as if he was defending the interests of his people, namely maintaining their independence and protecting their religion. Therefore, he said that the magicians had conspired with Moses to seize power in Egypt from their own country.

Such is generally the attitude of a tyrannical and cruel ruler. He is very worried if his people turn their faces to another leader. However, a nation that has self-respect and wants to preserve its fundamental rights will surely unite to oppose that tyrannical power, no matter how great the ruler is.
text.125:
In this verse, Allah recounts that the magicians felt no fear whatsoever in the face of Pharaoh's threats against them. In fact, with steadfastness and full conviction, they said to Pharaoh, "Indeed, to our Lord we will return."

This statement of theirs affirms that they were completely unconcerned with Pharaoh's threats against them. Even if Pharaoh were to kill them, it would provide them with the opportunity to immediately meet their Lord, and to receive His forgiveness and mercy, which they greatly desired. They were certain that Pharaoh and all of them would return to God. Even if Pharaoh killed them, Pharaoh would not live forever in this world. He would eventually return to the Lord of the Universe, so that God would judge them and Pharaoh.

With this last understanding, it can be understood that their statement contains a sharp insinuation that Pharaoh is not God as he has claimed all along; even behind his power, there is a higher power. And they prioritize the mercy and pleasure of Allah over satisfying worldly desires alongside Pharaoh and his dignitaries.

In the story found in Surah asy-Syuara, Allah mentions the words of the magicians as follows:

"They said, "No harm. Indeed, to our Lord we will return. Indeed, we aspire that our Lord will forgive us our sins because we were the first of the believers." (asy-Syuara/26: 50-51)
text.126:
In this verse, Allah recounts the next words of the magicians to Pharaoh. They revealed Pharaoh's evil towards them, which was that Pharaoh wanted to take revenge on them by torturing them cruelly. And all of that was only because they had believed in the verses of their Lord when those verses came to them.

Their words imply that Pharaoh would not influence them, because faith in Allah is something very precious and in accordance with the original human nature, and is the basis for their happiness in this world and the hereafter.

Pharaoh rebuked the magicians because they had prostrated and believed in Allah without asking Pharaoh's permission first. In addition, Pharaoh had accused them of conspiring with Prophet Musa to seize power from him, and to expel the Egyptians from their homeland. Finally, Pharaoh threatened to cut off their hands and feet, in addition to the torture of crucifixion. All of that was essentially Pharaoh's anger towards them. After that, Pharaoh tried to take revenge for their actions and anyone who believed in Allah and fulfilled the call of Prophet Musa. Whatever efforts Pharaoh made still did not bring him any results. On the contrary, Pharaoh and his nobles would meet a very bad fate.

In another verse, Allah's word to Prophet Musa and Harun is mentioned as follows:

"You two and those who follow you will be the victors." (al-Qashas/28: 35)

Furthermore, Allah tells about the magicians, that after they gave such a firm answer as above, they then prayed to Allah, may they be given patience, and if Allah causes them to die, let it be in a state of submission to Him. Their prayer to Allah to be given patience shows how important patience is in every struggle, especially the struggle against injustice.

Patience does not only mean the ability to restrain oneself from anger, but also means self-awareness, controlling desires, and being resilient in facing all obstacles and suffering.

A patient person will not take revenge, even though he is able to do so. A patient person can always maintain sound reasoning, so that he will not fall into actions that can harm himself and the struggle of his people.

The way to achieve patience is a strong faith in Allah and the Hereafter. This has been proven by the historical reality of mankind, namely that a people with strong faith are the most patient and resilient people in the struggle and have high courage. Because of that patience and courage, ideas and efforts arose in some military leaders in several countries, to promote religious education and spiritual development for soldiers and officers of the armed forces, so that they have a strong faith that will produce the qualities of patience and courage.

In the meantime, Allah repeatedly in His word promises His help for those who are patient, and He gives guidance so that humans are always patient and encourage others to be patient. Allah says:

"(They are) those who are patient and put their trust only in their Lord." (an-Nahl/16: 42)

His word again:

Except for those who have believed and done righteous deeds and advised each other to truth and advised each other to patience. (al-Ashr/103: 3)

The teaching about patience is very important in Islam, so that in the Al-Quran it is mentioned about 100 times, either in the form of commands about being patient, or in the form of praise for those who are patient, or promises of victory, good fortune and Allah's help for those who are patient. And often the words patience are coupled with the words faith, piety, tawakal, truth, struggle, strength of determination and so on.

In the hadith of the Prophet Muhammad there are also many teachings about patience. Regarding the relationship between patience and courage, he said:

"The strong person is not the one who can wrestle people down, but the strong person is the one who can control himself when he is angry." (Narrated by Imam al-Bukhari, from Abu Hurairah ra)

A patient person is always calm and has a clear mind, so that all his words and actions can be controlled well. His stance is not shaken by threats and temptations of any kind. Therefore, in another hadith, the Prophet Muhammad saw said

"Patience is a bright light." (Narrated by Muslim, at-Tirmidzi, and others)

Conversely, a person who is impatient will certainly lose his sanity, and is easily influenced by Satan, so that his words and actions cannot be controlled. This will lead to bad consequences and will cause losses and regrets. Therefore, the Prophet Muhammad saw warned with his saying:

"Haste is the work of Satan." (Narrated by at-Tirmidzi)

Because of the importance of the quality of patience, it is not surprising why those who have believed in Prophet Musa as in the story asked Allah to be given abundant patience, so that their faith would not be shaken by the threats of Pharaoh and his nobles.
text.127:
In this verse, it is narrated that the prominent figures from Pharaoh's people said to him, "O Pharaoh, will you allow Moses and his people to cause corruption in the land and abandon you and your gods?"

This slander, for the umpteenth time, reveals their anxiety about losing power, influence, and possessions, because they had seen signs that the people had begun to turn away from Pharaoh to Prophet Moses (peace be upon him), after witnessing the victory of his miracle. Especially after seeing the magicians prostrating themselves in faith, disregarding Pharaoh's threats against them.

In launching this slander, these dignitaries used political and religious elements. They accused Moses of undermining Pharaoh's position as the sole ruler in Egypt. In addition, Pharaoh's position as the one who had been deified would naturally disappear as well. Moreover, the gods that were worshiped by the Egyptian people at that time would also be abandoned, for example, the god "Osiris," who, according to their belief, his spirit incarnated in a cow they called "Apis." Besides that, they also worshiped "all kinds of animals." Similarly, they worshiped darkness, as well as the Akron statue, which they considered to be a fly repellent.

In short, Pharaoh's people at that time were at the peak of their deviation, because they worshiped the sun, moon, and stars, as well as humans and animals, both large animals and the smallest insects.

Pharaoh himself was a follower of animal worship, then he abandoned that belief, and then he claimed to be a god and ordered his people to worship him. This was after he saw himself having such great power among his people. (This information is found in the book *Al-Milal wan-Nihal* by asy-Syahrastany)

The slander of Pharaoh's dignitaries had successfully hit its target, namely influencing Pharaoh, who had lost his balance, thus arousing his emotions and anger. Therefore, he replied: "Alright, we will kill their sons and let their women live, and we will have full power over them."

The meaning is that in order to prevent the rise of Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) in Egypt, Pharaoh would take various actions, including killing every male child born to the women of the Children of Israel, namely the people of the same nation as Prophet Moses who lived in Egypt at that time. While the daughters they bore would be allowed to live, to then be used by Pharaoh and his dignitaries as slaves. With this action, Pharaoh hoped to stem the growth of Prophet Moses' power in Egypt, because he would still have more male manpower and greater power, while conversely, Prophet Moses and the Children of Israel in general would increasingly lack male manpower, so they would not oppose Pharaoh's power and free themselves from the chains of his enslavement.

This evil plan was truly carried out by Pharaoh and his dignitaries, so that the Children of Israel who lived in Egypt at that time suffered greatly, both physically and mentally.
text.128:
Understandably, upon hearing Pharaoh's threat, the Children of Israel who resided in Egypt at that time felt fear and great anxiety. This threat later proved true, as they were treated as slaves. In addition, every male child they bore was killed by Pharaoh's henchmen. Therefore, Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) said to them: "Seek help from Allah and be patient. Indeed, the earth belongs to Allah. He causes to inherit it whom He wills of His servants. And the [best] outcome is for the righteous."

Prophet Musa comforted and reassured his people by reminding them of Allah's power, that He is the One who owns and controls the earth, and that everything that happens on this earth is in accordance with His Sunnah, which is that every disbelieving and oppressive people will surely meet destruction, and every believing and patient people will certainly receive His help, so as to achieve victory and a good end. Therefore, they should seek His help, accompanied by patience, faith, unity, and courage in defending truth and justice.

Prophet Musa's words not only instilled hope for Allah's help and mercy to free them from Pharaoh's cruelty and to make the Children of Israel rulers in the future in the part of the earth that God had promised them, but also contained a very important warning for his people, namely, if in the future they become rulers, do not act arbitrarily like Pharaoh and his dignitaries, because Allah is always watching the actions and behavior of every creature. Therefore, if they rule and commit injustice as well, Allah will surely bring punishment upon them.

This verse contains a very valuable lesson about the attitude of humans when they are facing suffering, or before they obtain Allah's mercy, and after obtaining that mercy. A very reprehensible attitude is to complain and ask for Allah's help when experiencing hardship, and then deny or forget Allah's mercy after obtaining it.

The attitude that should be adopted is patience and reliance (tawakal) and seeking Allah's help when facing difficulties, and being grateful for Allah's mercy after obtaining happiness. Being grateful for Allah's mercy is not only with words, but more importantly, it is implemented with actions. Therefore, if someone obtains power, and then uses that power to commit injustice or enrich himself at the expense of others, then this means that he is not grateful for the mercy of Allah that he has obtained, namely rank and power, and therefore it is fitting that Allah inflicts punishment upon him.
text.129:
The Children of Israel complained to Moses (peace be upon him) that their fate was the same, both before the arrival of Moses (peace be upon him) to call them to the religion of Allah and free them from the slavery of Pharaoh, and after. They felt they had not benefited from the arrival of the Prophet Moses (peace be upon him). Previously, they were tormented and enslaved by Pharaoh, their children were killed, they were forced to work, and it was still the same now. This complaint shows the pettiness of their souls, the weakness of their fighting spirit, and their lack of patience.

Hearing this complaint, the Prophet Moses said, "Perhaps Allah will destroy your enemy and make you successors in the earth, then He will see how you act," meaning: even though this is happening, the hope that Allah will destroy your enemies and make you rulers in the part of the earth that your Lord has promised must remain.

In his speech to his people, the Prophet Moses (peace be upon him) used the expression "perhaps." He used this expression so as not to guarantee the coming of Allah's help and mercy to them.
