Because if he had used an expression that guaranteed it, his people might have ignored the obligations they needed to fulfill to obtain Allah's help, because Allah's help to His servants is not given just like that, but depends on the efforts made by the people concerned, such as sincerity, discipline, unity, and so on.
text.130:
In this verse, it is explained that the trials inflicted upon Pharaoh, in the form of a long drought that resulted in hardship for them, should have instilled awareness in their hearts. They should have realized that the strength and power they possessed were not the ultimate strength and power, and that there was still the power and authority of Allah, the Almighty, to bring down punishment that they could not overcome. If such awareness had been present in their hearts, they would have certainly changed their attitudes and actions, especially towards the Children of Israel. Furthermore, they would have accepted the call of Prophet Musa and abandoned their denial of Allah.

The punishment that Allah sends down upon His servants always contains lessons and education. This is because when people face difficulties and hardships in life, their hearts become softened, and they will turn their faces to Allah, the Most Compassionate, the Most Merciful, to ask for His help and mercy. In addition, they will also strive to improve their behavior by doing deeds that are pleasing to Allah. However, if these difficulties and hardships do not change their attitudes and behavior, and they remain in denial of Allah and constantly commit disobedience, then they are truly losers and greatly misguided because the difficulties they face do not bring about awareness and consciousness for them, but instead increase their denial and disobedience towards Allah. Such was the state of Pharaoh and his followers.
text.131:
In this verse, Allah explains the characteristics and nature of Pharaoh and his followers. When they experienced prosperity, they said that it was only natural, because their land was fertile and they worked diligently. It did not occur to them that all of it was a blessing from Allah that they should be grateful for. Conversely, when they experienced the dangers of drought, famine, and disease, they then blamed and cursed Prophet Musa. They said that all the calamities were caused by the fault of Prophet Musa and his people. They forgot the evil and injustice they had committed against the people of Prophet Musa, because they considered the enslavement and cruel acts they committed against the Children of Israel to be natural and their right as a powerful nation. This is the clearest illustration of the attitude and nature of imperialists throughout history.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that the trials that befall the disbelievers are a decree from Allah, but most of them do not know it. The meaning is that all the good they obtain, and all the trials they face, are all *qadha* and *qadar* that Allah has decreed, in accordance with His *sunnah* that applies to all His creatures, namely in accordance with cause and effect, so that what happens to humans is merely a consequence of their attitude, actions, and behavior. However, most of them refuse to realize this. They remain in disbelief and injustice.
text.132:
In this verse, their denial is explained, even though Prophet Musa had provided various clear explanations and proofs of his prophethood. They said to Prophet Musa: "No matter what signs you bring, we will never believe in you."

All the explanations that Prophet Musa had presented to them, which proved his prophethood, they considered as magic to influence them, so that they would abandon the religion of their ancestors. Then they affirmed that they would never validate all those explanations and proofs. This means that they would not accept the religion of Allah that was conveyed to Prophet Musa for all of them. But they continued to commit injustice against the Children of Israel (Bani Israil) and Prophet Musa.
text.133:
In this verse, it is narrated that as a consequence of their denial, disbelief, and injustice, Allah sent down a more severe punishment upon them in the form of a flood that struck their houses and trees, their gardens and fields. Then came a plague of locusts that destroyed their crops, and finally another epidemic emerged that changed the taste, smell, and color of their drinking water to be like blood, which they could not drink.

Despite the five kinds of punishments that Allah inflicted repeatedly upon Pharaoh and his people, they remained arrogant and committed sins, and that was their most prominent characteristic.
text.134:
In this verse, Allah recounts the state of Pharaoh and his people when they were afflicted with five kinds of torment. They were helpless and sought the help of Prophet Musa, asking him to pray to Allah to relieve them from the suffering caused by the torment. They said, "O Musa, invoke your Lord for us by virtue of your prophethood; if you remove the torment from us, we will surely believe in you, and we will let the Children of Israel go with you."

Thus, after they were unable to save themselves from the punishment, they pretended to believe and promised to free the Children of Israel and allow them to leave Egypt with Prophet Musa. But can the promises of disbelievers be trusted?
text.135: Thanks to the prayer of Prophet Musa (Moses) who pleaded to Allah to release Pharaoh and his people from the torment of Allah that befell them, Pharaoh and his people were eventually released from that torment, before Allah drowned them. However, their release from Allah's torment did not lead them to believe and keep their promise to free the Children of Israel from Egypt and from their oppression. Instead, they remained determined to oppose Allah and remained in disbelief (kufr).
text.136:
In this verse, Allah narrates the coming of destruction upon Pharaoh and his people, after the various punishments inflicted upon them previously did not change their attitude and actions, due to their disbelief and injustice.

Pharaoh and his people had broken their promise to allow the Children of Israel to leave the land of Egypt with Prophet Musa. Therefore, when Prophet Musa led his people out of that land towards Palestine through the Red Sea, Pharaoh and his people pursued them. Musa and his people safely crossed the Red Sea, but Pharaoh and his people drowned when they were in the middle of that sea, and thus they perished.

At the end of this verse, Allah explains that this punishment was inflicted because they constantly denied His verses, and refused to realize the consequences that befell them due to their disbelief and injustice, both the calamities in this world and the agonizing torment in the Hereafter. Some of Pharaoh's people perished with him, because they followed his error and disbelief. While others perished because of Pharaoh's cruelty and injustice towards them.
text.137:
In this verse, Allah explains His greatest favor upon the Children of Israel after they were oppressed and enslaved by Pharaoh and his people. That favor was inheriting the western and eastern regions that were fertile and blessed by Allah. Thus, Allah's promise to the Children of Israel was perfectly fulfilled; this favor was a reward for their patience in following the teachings of Prophet Musa and the true religion of Allah. Conversely, Allah gave Pharaoh and his people a fitting reward in the form of their destruction and all that Pharaoh had built, as a symbol of his arrogance.

Among the sufferings experienced by the Children of Israel was the killing of every male child born to them, while the female children were allowed to live. They were obligated to serve the interests of Pharaoh and his people who oppressed and enslaved them, by collecting very high taxes, making them forced and heavy laborers, and various other forms of oppression and enslavement.

Therefore, Allah sent Prophet Musa to free them from the slavery of Pharaoh and bring them out of Egypt. In this verse, it is explained that after that liberation, Allah bestowed upon the Children of Israel the eastern and western parts of the land that had been blessed by Allah. This verse is a fulfillment of Allah's promise in His saying:

"And We desired to show favor to those who were oppressed in the land and make them leaders and make them inheritors and establish them in the land. And We showed Pharaoh and Haman and their soldiers through them what they had feared." (al-Qashas/28: 5-6)

As for what is meant by the eastern and western lands that We have blessed in the Lord's saying, it is the land of Sham (Syria, Lebanon, Palestine, and Jordan) in the east, and Egypt in the west, as well as the lands around them that Pharaoh once controlled. These lands are very large and fertile, and have been given many blessings and goodness, Allah says:

"And We delivered him (Ibrahim) and Lot to the land which We had blessed for the worlds." (al-Anbiya/21: 71)

And Allah says:

"Exalted is He who took His Servant by night from al-Masjid al-Haram to al-Masjid al-Aqsa, whose surroundings We have blessed, to show him of Our signs." (al-Isra/17: 1)

With the salvation of the Children of Israel and the drowning of Pharaoh and his army, Allah's promise was fulfilled, to give help and blessings to those who uphold His religion, uphold the truth, and destroy those who undermine His religion and eliminate falsehood. Thus, Allah's promise was fulfilled, namely the rule of the Children of Israel in the fertile and blessed east. This is a great gift to the Children of Israel.

The abundant blessings were in accordance with Allah's decision and decree, because of the steadfastness and patience of the Children of Israel in facing the cruelty and oppression of Pharaoh and his people. Allah destroyed all that Pharaoh built with the aim of boasting and destroying the religion of Allah, such as beautiful cities and palaces, large buildings for the Egyptians, beautiful gardens and orchards, the tower that Haman made to see God, and so on.

Allah destroyed all that was built by Pharaoh and his people in order to:

1. Strengthen the prophethood of Musa a.s., and prove the truth that Musa had conveyed to Pharaoh and his people, such as the saying, "Allah will punish everyone who disobeys Him. Therefore, Allah punished them by sending hurricanes, locust plagues, and so on to them, which brought disaster and destruction."

2. Free the Children of Israel from the slavery of Pharaoh and his people.

3. Destroy Pharaoh and his people, so that they would no longer colonize other countries and their inhabitants. Before Pharaoh and his army drowned in the Red Sea, they had been warned by Musa as, but they ignored the warning. Their injustice increased, and they even intended to kill Musa as and those who believed with him. So Allah destroyed them because of their injustice, according to Allah's saying:

"Allah has not wronged them, but they were wronging themselves." (ali Imran/3: 117)

From this verse, it is understood that the firm faith in Musa as and Harun as and the revelation he received from Allah encouraged him to free the Children of Israel from the oppression of Pharaoh and his people. With full steadfastness and patience, Prophet Musa invited the Children of Israel to believe in Allah. He believed that his efforts, including efforts to affirm the religion of Allah and uphold the truth, would receive Allah's help. After going through a very difficult struggle and a long time, Allah gave help and victory with the destruction of Pharaoh and his people.

This can be used as an example and lesson by Muslims, that Allah's promise to believers is the same as the promise that Allah had promised to the Messengers in the past, when struggling to uphold the religion of Allah, namely to help and defend every effort to uphold the religion of Allah, and uphold the truth, as Allah says:

"O you who have believed, if you support Allah, He will support you and plant firmly your feet." (Muhammad/47: 7)

And Allah says again:

"And We have already sent messengers before you to their peoples, and they came to them with clear proofs. Then We took retribution from those who committed crimes, and it was incumbent upon Us to help the believers." (ar-Rum/30: 47)
text.138:
This verse explains that with the *inayah* (help) and power of Allah, the Children of Israel were saved to the other side of the Qulzum Sea (Red Sea) so that they were freed from the oppression of Pharaoh and his people. From this verse, it is understood that Moses and the Children of Israel easily crossed the Red Sea because of Allah's help, not because of other things such as the sea water being at low tide, etc. This event was a miracle for Prophet Moses.

In another verse, it is explained that after the oppression of Pharaoh and his people against the Children of Israel reached its peak, Allah commanded Moses to leave Egypt one night, taking the Children of Israel to escape Pharaoh's oppression. So Moses carried out all of God's commands. After hearing of the departure of Moses and his people, Pharaoh was angry, and in a short time his army was gathered and immediately chased after Moses and the Children of Israel that very night. In the morning, when the sun began to shine, Pharaoh was able to catch up from behind. Both sides saw each other, while Moses and the Children of Israel were already on the seashore. They were faced with a difficult situation: if they continued to run, they would be blocked by the sea; if they returned, the enemy's swords were drawn, waiting. At that moment, Allah showed His power by commanding Moses to strike the sea with his staff. Moses struck it, the sea water split, and between the split waters there was a road stretching to the other side. So Moses and the Children of Israel immediately passed through it, and from behind Pharaoh and his army continued to follow them. Finally, Moses and the Children of Israel safely reached the other side, while Pharaoh and his army, who tried to walk the road that Moses and his people had taken, were ambushed by the sea water that suddenly reunited, and the road that stretched disappeared, so that Pharaoh and his people died drowning to the bottom of the sea.

The event of the drowning of Pharaoh and his army is also explained by other verses. Allah says:

"And We had inspired Moses, "Travel by night with My servants and strike a dry path for them through the sea, not fearing to be overtaken [by Pharaoh] or being afraid [of drowning]." So Pharaoh pursued them with his soldiers, but the sea engulfed them." (Taha/20: 77-78)

The story of the drowning of Pharaoh and his army in the Qulzum Sea is also mentioned in the Old Testament, Exodus XIV: 15-31.

After Moses and the Children of Israel safely reached the other side of the Qulzum Sea, which is the area around the land of Arabia located at the tip of the Asian continent in the Southwest, they continued their journey. Then they arrived in a country whose inhabitants obediently worshiped idols. Seeing this situation, their memories returned to the customs and beliefs of their ancestors, which they used to do together with Pharaoh, such as worshiping gods other than Allah, whether in the form of animals, statues, stones, and so on. Therefore, they spontaneously asked Prophet Moses, "O Moses, make for us a god just as they have gods..."

From the request of the Children of Israel to Moses a.s., it is understood that even though Moses a.s. had conveyed his message as well as possible to the Children of Israel, the Children of Israel had not fully understood and appreciated the religion of *tauhid* that Moses conveyed. The customs and beliefs of their ancestors, such as worshiping idols, still had a very large influence on them, so that the *tauhid* belief that Moses had just instilled could easily be shaken.

It is known that the Children of Israel in Pharaoh's time were among the lower classes and lacked knowledge. There were almost no intellectuals from them; all the intellectuals came from the original inhabitants of Egypt, descendants of nobles. Most of the Children of Israel at that time lived as ordinary people, manual laborers, and many even lived as slaves forced to build pyramids and royal tombs.

Because of their condition, apathy arose among them; there was no ambition to free themselves from Pharaoh's slavery, no strong desire for independence. There was no firm attitude and strong ideals in them; this can be seen in their reactions, actions, and attitudes in accepting Moses' invitation. As soon as they faced obstacles and difficulties, they spontaneously expressed their despair to Moses, even stating that they preferred to live in Pharaoh's slavery and oppression.

The attitude of the Children of Israel towards Moses a.s.'s invitation to live as an independent nation was no different from their attitude towards Moses a.s.'s invitation to follow the true religion. Even though Prophet Moses had explained the religion well and clearly, so that they understood and followed it, as soon as they saw statues, people worshiping idols, people worshiping gods, and all kinds of forms of *shirk*, their memories returned to their previous beliefs. Therefore, they spontaneously asked Moses to make an idol for their worship. They felt more secure worshiping something that could be seen and touched, decorated, and so on, than worshiping something that was unseen, not visible to the eye, and could not be touched by hand.

This is different from the magicians who believed in Moses after their magical skills were defeated by Moses' miracle. They were among the people who had knowledge and were intellectuals at that time. Therefore, they could distinguish between what was wrong and what was right with their knowledge, so that they could know which were the signs of Allah's power and which were not, which could be achieved by the senses and which could not, and so on. Therefore, after they believed in Allah and Prophet Moses, they believed with all their hearts, unshaken by any circumstances and by any threats, including Pharaoh's threats to them. Their faith had a solid foundation, so that it was a strong conviction as a result of knowledge, feelings, experience, and what they had.

The Children of Israel, as explained above, were people who did not know the attributes of God, did not know the necessity of worshiping only Allah alone without associating Him with anything, and did not know the necessity of directing worship directly to Allah without taking intermediaries with anything, such as statues, buildings, tombs, or other objects that they made as intermediaries in worshiping Allah. They must believe that only Allah is the One.

This type of faith, like the faith of the Children of Israel caused by ignorance and the influence of ancestral beliefs, is also found in humans in general, and Muslims in particular, and is also found in every period in history, from the time of the Prophet Muhammad to the present time, as indicated by the *hadith* of the Prophet Muhammad saw:

Ahmad and An-Nasai narrated from Abi Waqid Al-Laitsy, he said: "We went out from Medina with the Messenger of Allah saw towards the battle of Hunain, then we passed a *sidrah* tree, I said: "O Messenger of Allah, make for us a "dhatu anwath" tree (a tree that can be a hanger) as the disbelievers have a "dhatu anwath". The Messenger of Allah replied: "(Allah is the Greatest). Your request is like the request of the Children of Israel to Moses: (Make for us a god, just as they have gods), indeed you are following the beliefs of the people before you." (Narrated by Ahmad and an-Nasai)

The reality of the existence of that belief indicated in the *hadith* above in the past and present should be a warning for Muslims to strive as hard as possible to provide understanding and enlightenment, so that all Muslims have *aqidah* and beliefs in accordance with what the Islamic religion teaches. There are still many Muslims who still worship tombs, believe in the existence of supernatural powers in stones, trees, caves, and so on. Therefore, they worship and adore them with submission and reverence, which sometimes exceeds submission and reverence to Allah. There are also many Muslims who use intermediaries (*washilah*) in worship, as if they do not believe that Allah is close to His servants and that worship directed to Him will reach without intermediaries. This belief is no different from the *shirk* belief held by the Arabs of *Jahiliyah* in the past; the only difference may be the name. This belief is contrary to the verse:

"...and We are nearer to him than [his] jugular vein." (Qaf/50:16)

And the confession of Ibrahim as mentioned in His word:

"Indeed, I have turned my face toward He who created the heavens and the earth, inclining toward truth, and I am not of those who associate others with Allah." (al-Anam/6: 79)

In fact, Allah affirms in His word again:

"And when My servants ask you, [O Muhammad], concerning Me - indeed I am near. I respond to the invocation of the supplicant when he calls upon Me. So let them respond to Me [by obedience] and believe in Me that they may be [rightly] guided." (al-Baqarah/2: 186)

A person who worships a god besides Allah is a person who makes a fool of himself, as Allah says:

And who would be averse to the religion of Abraham except one who has made a fool of himself... (al-Baqarah/2: 130)

The request of the Children of Israel was answered by Prophet Moses: "Indeed, you, O Children of Israel, do not know the attributes of Allah, what is obligatory for Him and what is impossible for Him. He is One and there is no partner for Him."

The religion brought by the messengers of Allah from ancient times until now, namely the religion brought by Prophet Muhammad saw, as the final prophet and messenger, is a religion that recognizes the oneness of Allah in truth, with no element of *shirk* in it at all. This is because worship is a feeling that arises from the depths of the heart. That feeling gives rise to submission of the heart and soul to the Most Great, fostering the belief that He alone has the right to be worshiped; while the others are His creatures who are equal in status to His other creations. Therefore, worshiping gods other than Allah will damage the *tauhid* that arises from the feeling that exists within a person, and shows a person's dependence on the god, in addition to depending on Allah. Therefore, Prophet Moses firmly rejected the request of his people.
text.139: This verse affirms that those who obediently and diligently worship deities other than Allah will be destroyed and annihilated by Allah, and the idols they worship are unable to provide benefit or harm to anyone. Their act of worshipping idols will not be rewarded in the slightest; rather, they will be given a great punishment. This verse is a soothing balm for the Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims who were facing ridicule and persecution from the polytheists of Mecca, because this verse hints at the victory of the Prophet Muhammad and the Muslims in the near future and the disappearance of polytheistic beliefs in the Arabian Peninsula.
text.140: Moses (peace be upon him) responded to the Israelites' request to make a deity other than Allah: "Should I seek for you a god other than Allah, while He is the Creator of the universe who has made you all a distinguished people in your time and made Islam your religion, namely the religion of monotheism, the religion brought by Prophet Ibrahim, the religion of the Prophets and Messengers whom Allah has sent. Why are you still looking for another religion?" This verse states that the request of the Israelites was a strange and astonishing request, because they had been given something good, namely the religion of monotheism, and then they wanted to exchange it for something bad, namely the religion of shirk.
text.141: In this verse, Allah reminds the Children of Israel, who desired a god other than Allah, that they had been given abundant blessings in the form of the sending of Prophet Musa (Moses) to them, to free them from the shackles of oppression and slavery of Pharaoh, who had killed every male child born to them, and allowed their female children to live with the intention that the Children of Israel would remain weak and in perpetual servitude to be oppressed forever. All kinds of trials and bitter experiences should be taken as lessons by drawing closer to Allah the Almighty and striving at all times to ensure that those experiences are not repeated.
text.142:
This verse explains the event of the Torah being revealed to Prophet Musa (Moses). Allah had established His promise to Prophet Musa that He would send down revelation containing the fundamental principles of religion and the fundamental principles of law that would serve as a guide for the Children of Israel in their efforts to achieve happiness in this world and the hereafter. The time for the promised revelation was thirty nights on Mount Sinai, then extended by ten more nights, making it forty nights.

Regarding the revelation of the Torah to Prophet Musa, it is narrated by Ibnul Mundzir and Ibn Abi Hatim from Ibn Abbas, when interpreting this verse, that Musa said to his people, "Indeed, my Lord (Allah) has promised me thirty nights. I will meet Him and I will appoint Harun (Aaron) to take care of you." So after Musa arrived at the promised place, which was in the month of Dzulqaidah and the first ten nights of Dzulhijjah, Musa stayed and waited on Mount Sinai for forty nights, and Allah revealed to him the Torah in the form of written tablets. Allah drew Musa near to Him to converse with him. After that, Allah spoke, and Musa heard the sound of the pen vibrating.

From these two narrations, it can be concluded that Musa a.s. went to Mount Sinai alone, with no one accompanying him, in the sense that he separated himself from his people, the Children of Israel. After Musa a.s. left, the Children of Israel were influenced by the invitation of Samiri, so they joined in worshiping the calf idol.

Before Musa a.s. departed to the place designated by Allah to receive the Torah, he entrusted the leadership of his people to his brother Harun a.s., and declared Harun as his representative, to take care of the interests of the Children of Israel during his absence. Musa warned Harun not to follow the desires and opinions of those who were misguided and liked to do evil.

Harun was the older brother of Musa a.s. and was appointed by Allah as a Messenger and Prophet. In another verse, it is mentioned that Musa, before facing Pharaoh, prayed to Allah that Harun be appointed as his wazir (helper), because his tongue was more eloquent (fasih) than Musa's tongue.

Allah says:

"And appoint for me a helper from my family, (that is) Harun, my brother, strengthen my back by him, and let him share my task." (Taha/20: 29-30-31-32)
text.143:
This verse explains that when Moses (peace be upon him) arrived at the place and time promised by Allah to receive revelation, Allah conveyed His revelation directly without an intermediary. Then, a desire arose within Moses to obtain another honor in addition to the honor of speaking directly with Allah that he had just received. This desire was to gain the honor of seeing Allah clearly. So Moses said, "O my Lord, show me Your holy essence and give me the strength to be able to see You clearly, because I am unable to see and know You perfectly." Allah answered, "O Moses, you will not be able to see Me." In a hadith of the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him), it is mentioned:

"From Abu Musa, he said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Allah's hijab (veil) is nur (light). If that light were to be unveiled, the majesty of His face's radiance would surely burn all creatures that His gaze reaches." (Narrated by Muslim)

Furthermore, Allah said to Moses, "Look at the mountain, if the mountain remains firm and strong as before after seeing Me, then surely you can also see Me, because you and the mountain are both My creations. But if the strong and sturdy mountain cannot withstand and is destroyed after seeing Me, how can you see Me? Because all the creatures that I created are unable and incapable of seeing Me."

It is narrated from Ibn Abbas, he said, "When Moses (peace be upon him) asked his Lord, "Show me Your essence," Allah answered: "You will never be able to see Me." Then Allah emphasized again, "You will never be able to see Me, O Moses." No one is able to see Me, and then remain alive." Finally, Allah said, "Look at the high and large mountain, if the mountain remains in its place, does not shake and is destroyed, then surely it sees My greatness, hopefully you can see it too, while you are truly weak and lowly. Indeed, the mountain shakes and is destroyed no matter how strong and terrible it is, while you are weaker and lowlier."

There are several opinions of the *mufassirun* (Quranic commentators) about what is meant by the verse: "When his Lord manifested Himself to the mountain." Some *mufassirun* say that what appeared to the mountain was the essence of Allah. Whatever the opinions of the *mufassirun*, it seems that Allah's appearance is not like the appearance of creatures. However, the appearance of God is not the same as the appearance of humans, in accordance with the attributes of Allah that cannot be measured by human standards.

After Moses (peace be upon him) regained consciousness from his fainting, and realized that he had asked Allah for something that could harm him, he felt that he had committed a sin. Therefore, he pleaded and prayed to Allah, "Glory be to You, O my Lord, I have sinned because I asked You for something beyond my ability to receive it, therefore I repent to You and will not repeat the mistakes of the past, and I am among the first believers in You."

Mujahid said, "*Tubtu ilaika*" (I repent to You), meaning: I repent to You, because I have asked You to be able to see Your essence, "*wa ana awwalul muminin*", (and I am the first of the believers), meaning I am the first of the Children of Israel to believe in You. While in another narration from Ibn Abbas, it is said that he was the first to believe and no one can see You (in this world).
text.144:
Furthermore, Allah explains that He chose Musa from among the people of his time by bestowing upon him favors that He did not grant to others, namely, elevating Musa as a Prophet and Messenger, giving him the opportunity to speak directly with Allah, even though limited by something that separated Allah and Musa.

In the Al-Quran, the way Allah conveys revelation to His Messengers is mentioned, as in Allah's saying:

And it is not for any human being that Allah should speak to him except by revelation or from behind a veil or by sending a messenger (angel) to reveal, by His permission, what He wills. Indeed, He is Most High, Wise. (Asy-Syura/42: 51)

So according to this verse, there are three ways Allah conveys revelation to His Messengers:

1. By inspiring the Messenger concerned, namely by instilling an understanding into the heart of the person to whom the revelation is sent.

2. By speaking directly with a barrier separating Allah and the servant He is speaking to. This second method is what Musa experienced in receiving revelation, so he is known as *kalimullah* (the one who spoke to Allah).

3. Through the angel Jibril (Gabriel) a.s. The Al-Quran was conveyed through this method.

Regarding the question of whether humans can see Allah with their own eyes, if the verses and hadiths of the Prophet are understood, the following conclusions can be drawn:

1. It is impossible for humans to see Allah while they are alive in this world, as Allah affirmed to Prophet Musa a.s.

2. Believers will be able to see Allah in the Hereafter, in accordance with:

a. Allah's saying:

"Some faces, that Day, will be radiant, Looking at their Lord." (Al-Qiyamah/75:22-23)

From this verse, it is understood that "seeing the Lord" on the Day of Judgment is a blessing given by Allah to the believers, therefore they always hope for it.

b. The words of Rasulullah saw:

Indeed, people said (to Rasulullah saw), "O Rasulullah, will we see our Lord on the Day of Judgment?" Rasulullah replied, "Does anything prevent you from seeing the moon on a full moon night?" They said, "No, O Rasulullah." Rasulullah said, "Then indeed you will see the Lord as you see the full moon." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

c. Everything that exists can be seen. Only that which does not exist cannot be seen. God is *wajibul wujud* (necessary existence), therefore God can be seen if He wills it. In addition, God sees everything that exists, including seeing Himself. If God can see Himself, then He certainly has the power to make humans see Himself if He wills it.

In the following part of the verse, Prophet Musa and his people are commanded to receive the holy book that Allah revealed, and the sharia that must be carried out to be used as a guide in life and practiced in the world. Only in this way can they be considered as people who are grateful and appreciate Allah's blessings.
text.145:
In this verse, Allah explains that He sent down to Prophet Musa (peace be upon him) tablets containing guidance, teachings, promises, and threats concerning the fundamental principles of religion, encompassing core tenets of faith, morality, and laws.

Scholars differ on whether these tablets were part of the Torah, with some suggesting they were revealed before the Torah itself. Among these opinions, the strongest is that the tablets represent the first revelation to Musa (peace be upon him), containing general and global laws, beliefs, and explanations. Later revelations were sent down gradually to elaborate on these, according to the needs, circumstances, time, and place.

Commentators also disagree on the number of tablets revealed to Prophet Musa (peace be upon him). Some say ten, and others say different numbers. There is no explicit *nash* (textual evidence) specifying the exact number of tablets.

Allah commanded Musa to firmly adhere to the fundamental principles of religion revealed to him, to implement all the guidance and laws, so that he would be happy in this world and the hereafter. And Allah commanded Musa and his people to hold fast to the teachings, guidance, and laws contained in the tablets. This would improve the character and worship of the Children of Israel and close the doors to *shirk* (polytheism). If you and your people do not take and hold fast to what We have revealed with truth, then you will become *fasiq* (rebellious), as experienced by the people of 'Ad, Thamud, and the Pharaoh's people, and so on, or We will show you later what those who disobey Me will experience.

From the verses above, several *iktibar* (lessons) can be drawn, as follows:

1.  It is obligatory to convey the teachings of the Messenger sincerely, in accordance with the message brought by the Messenger, so that the formation of a new community, full of peace under the protection of God, the Most Forgiving, can be achieved. This can be seen in the actions of the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) himself. He was a role model for his community in practicing the commands of Allah. This can be seen in his words, deeds, and actions. Therefore, the Arabs were attracted to the religion he brought, so that in a very short time, the inhabitants of the Arabian Peninsula had embraced Islam. The methods used by the Prophet were also used by the Companions and several famous caliphs in history, and they succeeded as the Prophet had succeeded. However, there were also some Muslims who made mistakes.

2.  We see in history that the Children of Israel became a great and powerful nation when they properly implemented the religion of Allah, and they became a colonized nation, living in misery, when they took the religion of Allah lightly and denied it.

3.  Similarly, the Muslims become strong and great when they properly implement the religion of Allah, when strong brotherhood arises among Muslims, and they become weak when they no longer pay attention to the religion of Allah.
text.146:
Allah will turn away the hearts of those who are arrogant, who boast about understanding the proofs and arguments brought by the messengers, especially those related to Allah's power and greatness, and will also turn their hearts away from carrying out Allah's religion and following guidance to the right path. This is in accordance with Allah's word:

"So when they deviated, Allah caused their hearts to deviate. And Allah does not guide the defiantly disobedient people." (Ash-shaff/61: 5)

*Takabur* in language means, "to consider oneself great," or "to feel grand." What is meant by this verse is rejecting the truth and belittling others. The character and nature of an arrogant person is to look down on others, as if he alone is clever, powerful, determines the occurrence of everything, and so on. Therefore, in his actions, he easily commits transgressions, acts arbitrarily, and likes to cause damage.

In this verse, the characteristic of *takabur* is coupled with the words " *bigairil haq* " - without a just cause. This shows that the attitude and actions of an arrogant person are carried out without thinking about the consequences caused by actions that are solely carried out to satisfy one's own desires, even if it harms others.

*Takabur* is a disease of the soul caused by errors in assessing and accepting something. Sometimes, a person's continuous success in his endeavors can also lead to *takabur*, resulting in an excessive belief in himself, that whatever he aspires to and plans will definitely be achieved and successful. Feeling confident in one's own abilities ultimately leads to the belief that he is not dependent on anyone, including Allah.

In this verse, the characteristics of arrogant people are explained, namely:

1.  If they see evidence of Allah's power and greatness, or read Allah's verses, they do not believe it and do not want to take lessons and lessons from it. Arguments, evidence of Allah's power and oneness, and verses of the Qur'an that contain the truth are rejected by them. Arguments and evidence are not beneficial for those who doubt and do not desire the truth, because they feel that the truth itself will limit and prevent them from arbitrary actions, so that their ideals and desires are not fulfilled. This verse is a signal to the Prophet Muhammad saw, that the polytheists and disbelievers who mocked him and denied the Qur'an and created chaos by looking for faults and weaknesses in the verses of the Qur'an and distorting its contents and the truth of the Qur'an. Even if the Prophet Muhammad wanted to follow their demands which were a condition of their belief in him, they still would not believe even if their demands had been met.

2.  If they see guidance and the right path, they do not want to follow it, they even avoid and stay away, even though that path is the best and the only path that can lead them to a place full of happiness.

3.  If they see a path that leads to misery, they follow it, because that path has been made by Satan in their minds as the best and most beautiful. They feel that by taking that path, all their desires and lusts will definitely be fulfilled. According to their belief, that is the paradise they aspire to.

At the end of this verse, it is explained why their hearts are turned away by Allah, so that they do not want to take lessons from Allah's verses, because they have denied Allah's verses.

It has become Allah's law that frequently doing a job makes it easier to do, and eventually the job and the people who do it become one, as if they cannot be separated anymore. The same is true between evil deeds and those who always do them, there is no difference, so that eventually the person and the evil deeds they do have become one and have merged with them.

Therefore, in essence, it is not Allah who turns away and locks the heart of a misguided person, but the misguided people themselves. Indeed, Allah does not create humans from birth as believers or as disbelievers, and He does not force His servants to be disbelievers or believers, but a person becomes a believer or becomes a disbeliever through his own efforts. They themselves choose and strive to become believers by following the guidance and teachings of religion by carrying out Allah's commands and avoiding His prohibitions. He always pays attention to the signs of Allah's power and greatness so that their faith grows stronger over time. Conversely, it is man himself who strives and chooses the wrong path or becomes a disbeliever by denying Allah's verses, belittling and ignoring Allah's verses, so that they can satisfy their desires and lusts. Because they always do sinful deeds, then that deed has become one with them, so that whatever truth comes is always rejected, as if their hearts have been locked shut, have turned away from the truth. This example is mentioned in Allah SWT's word:

"And We have certainly created for Hell many of the jinn and mankind. They have hearts with which they do not understand, they have eyes with which they do not see, and they have ears with which they do not hear. They are like livestock; rather, they are more astray. It is they who are the heedless." (al-Araf/7: 179)

The behavior of people as described in the verse above is often found in society throughout human history. They are people who are very influenced by worldly life, such as rank, power, wealth, pleasure, and so on, they always indulge their desires. They forget and deliberately forget religious teachings, both those related to carrying out Allah's commands and His prohibitions. If Allah's teachings are conveyed to them, then they carry them out merely to seek sympathy, so that their desires and desires are more easily fulfilled.
text.147: Those who deny the verses of Allah that have been revealed to His Messenger, do not believe in the meeting with Allah on the Last Day, and do not believe in the recompense that will be given on that Day. Then all the good deeds they have done in the world will not be rewarded by Allah, because those actions are not based on the desire to seek Allah's pleasure. And Allah does not wrong [them] in the least; they will be punished according to the sinful deeds they have committed.
text.148:
The Children of Israel worshipped a calf idol during Moses' absence on Mount Sinai receiving revelation from Allah. The calf idol was made by As-Samiri (20:85, 87). As-Samiri made the idol at the suggestion of the leaders of the Children of Israel, even though he was a pious and obedient man who held a respected position in society.

The name As-Samiri is mentioned in the Word of Allah SWT:

He (Allah) said, "But We have tested your people after you left, and As-Samiri has led them astray." (Taha/20:85)

The calf idol was made of gold, which came from the gold jewelry of Egyptian women borrowed by the women of the Children of Israel, which they took with them when they left Egypt. The gold jewelry was melted down and shaped by As-Samiri into a calf idol. According to ath-Thabari, the gold was borrowed from gold bracelets, a sign of the Children of Israel's enslavement by the native Egyptians. (For a more complete Tafsir, see Surah Taha/20:85)

The desire of the Children of Israel to worship a calf idol as a god besides Allah was influenced by their customs in Egypt in the past. Actually, their ancestors were *muwahhidin* (monotheists) because they were descendants of the Prophet Yaqub. However, after associating with the Egyptians, the symptoms of *wasaniyah* (worshipping other than Allah) were transmitted to them. This *wasaniyah* worship was ingrained in them, and they always had the desire to carry out these habits.

The calf idol that was worshipped as a god by the Children of Israel was in the form of a calf idol that was shaped in such a way that if wind was blown into it, it could make a sound.

The sound from the calf idol came out because wind entered the oral cavity and exited from another hole, creating a sound. This could be done by inserting a pipe-like device that could make a sound into the cavity of the calf idol. If wind was blown into the pipe, the calf idol would sound like a real calf. Because this was considered strange by the Children of Israel, they easily developed the belief that the calf idol was worthy of worship, just like worshipping Allah.

Allah rebuked the Children of Israel for their weak faith, for not being able to distinguish between the God who is worthy of worship and something strange that they had just seen and learned about for the first time. They could not distinguish between the God who sent down revelation to the Messengers and a creature of God that could only make a sound. If they wanted to think, their own abilities might be better and more capable of speaking than the calf idol.

The Children of Israel did this not based on any strong evidence; they did it only because of the influence of the customs of their ancestors in Egypt who worshipped calves. Even though they had been given clear proofs, such as the splitting of the sea, the staff turning into a snake, and so on. Because they did not want to pay attention to the proofs and evidence, they denied Allah, which had bad consequences for themselves. (see Surah Taha verses 85-87)
text.149: Finally, the Children of Israel realized that their act of worshiping the calf idol was a misguided act because it associated partners with Allah (shirk). Therefore, they regretted their actions and said: "Indeed, our sins are very great, and so are our disobedience and denial. Nothing can absolve us from the sin of this act except the mercy of Allah and His forgiveness. If our Lord did not have mercy on us by accepting our repentance, we would surely be among the losers in this world and receive a painful punishment in the Hereafter."
text.150:
This verse explains Prophet Musa's (Moses) attitude towards his people's act of worshipping the calf. He was saddened because he felt that all his efforts and arduous struggles had not yielded the desired results. He was very angry with his brother Harun (Aaron), who had been appointed as his representative to lead his people after he went to meet his Lord's call on Mount Sinai, as if Harun had not carried out his duties, and had allowed his people to go astray, without rebuking or taking any action against those who were disbelieving. Musa also feared Allah and was worried about receiving Allah's wrath upon him and his people who had become polytheists.

In a state of sadness, despair mixed with anger, harsh words were uttered towards his brother Harun and his people, stating that the task and mandate he had given to Harun had been in vain, not carried out as it should have been. With great difficulty, he had taught and educated his people, so that they had believed in Allah and worshipped only Him. He had just received Allah's revelation containing guidance and sharia that would be taught to his people. What happened to his people when he returned was very contrary to what he wanted. What he wanted was for his people to continue to worship Allah the One and Only after he left, then that submission and obedience would increase, after he could teach the new revelation he had received from Allah. What happened was the worst and most sinful act, namely associating partners with God.

Furthermore, Musa said to his people. Why couldn't you wait patiently for my return after conversing with the Lord, until you made an idol and worshipped it as you worship Allah, even though I was only late by ten nights. Do you have other suspicions about me because of my lateness?

According to a narration, Samiri once said to the Children of Israel when he showed them the newly made calf statue: This is your god and the god of Musa, indeed Musa will not return and indeed he has died.

In his anger, Prophet Musa threw down the tablets in his hands, but not with the intention of destroying them, as mentioned in the Old Testament, "And Moses' anger waxed hot, and he cast the tables out of his hands, and brake them beneath the mount." (Exodus 32:19). In fact, in 7:154, the objects were still intact, containing Allah's teachings. It seems disrespectful (if not to say insulting to God) to assume that God's Messenger destroyed the tablets containing God's teachings in his uncontrollable anger. Then he grabbed Harun's forelock, because he thought that Harun had not made a serious effort to prevent his people from worshipping the calf idol, and the actions that had been taken during his trip to Mount Sinai, or reported his people's straying. Musa's suspicion of Harun is depicted in Allah's words as follows:

"He (Musa) said, "O Harun! What prevented you, when you saw them going astray, from following me? Have you then disobeyed my order?" (Taha/20: 92-93)

Harun answered Musa's words, "O son of my mother, do not rush to criticize me, and do not rush to get angry with me, because you suspect that I did not seriously carry out your orders and did not prevent them. Actually, I have tried to prevent them from doing that misguided act and giving them advice. But they considered me a weak person, and they almost killed me. Do not act against me with actions that please the enemy; they are happy and laugh because of the disaster that befell me, do not include me in the group of people who like to do things that result in losses for myself, namely the group that worships the calf idol, I myself am not included in that group."

The different attitudes of Musa and Harun towards the actions of their people also show the different characters of these two Prophets of Allah. Musa was a harsh and firm person in dealing with a misguided act that Allah forbade, while Harun was a gentle person and did not want to use violence in dealing with misguided acts.
text.151:
Hearing Aaron's answer, Moses' heart softened, and he said while praying, "O my Lord, forgive me for my actions that were too harsh towards my brother, both in words and deeds, and forgive all the weaknesses of my brother as my representative and successor in acting against those who are misguided. O my Lord, admit us into Your vast mercy, and You are the Most Merciful of the merciful."

With the prayer of Prophet Moses, the hopes of those who desired a division between Moses and Aaron were dashed, as well as the hopes of those who wanted Moses to act harshly towards his brother Aaron.

This verse explicitly states that Aaron was not involved in the actions of his people who worshipped the calf, in accordance with his statement to his brother Moses.
text.152:
All of the Children of Israel who worshipped the calf idol, like Samiri and his followers, and who refused to repent to Allah, will receive Allah's wrath and their repentance will no longer be accepted, except by killing their desires, because they will live in humiliation in this world. As Allah says in Al-Baqarah/2: 54:

"And [recall] when Moses said to his people, "O my people, indeed you have wronged yourselves by taking the calf [for worship]. So repent to your Creator and kill yourselves [i.e., the guilty among you]. That is better for you with your Creator." Then He accepted your repentance; indeed, He is the Accepting of repentance, the Merciful." (al-Baqarah/2: 54)

According to some commentators, the phrase, "Thus do We recompense those who invent falsehood" in this verse is directed at the Prophet Muhammad saw, as a warning to the Jews who were around Medina at that time. This is due to their (the Jews') attitude and behavior towards the Prophet Musa in the past. If the Jews around Medina continued to behave in this way, refusing to follow the Messenger of Allah saw, with his call, then they would suffer destruction and humiliation in this world, and in the Hereafter, of course, they would receive a painful torment.

Adhering to either of these two opinions does not contradict the content of the verse, because one of the purposes of this opinion is to mention the stories of past peoples as examples and lessons for future generations. Hopefully, the mistakes made by those in the past will not be repeated by future generations.

This verse also warns that, like the retribution mentioned in this verse, Allah gives retribution to those who fabricate lies against Allah. It is narrated from Abi Qatadah, he said, "This verse is not only addressed to the Children of Israel at the time of the Prophet Musa, but is addressed to all those who fabricate lies against Allah."
text.153:
The person who commits evil deeds and disobedience, then repents after committing that evil with a sincere repentance, and promises not to repeat that action again, and strives to do as many righteous deeds as possible, then their repentance will be accepted by Allah, and Allah will grant forgiveness to those who truly repent with a sincere heart.

From this verse, it can be concluded that no matter how great the sin that someone has committed, it will surely be forgiven by Allah, as long as they are willing to repent sincerely, and are willing to fulfill all the conditions of repentance so that it is accepted by Allah. Indeed, Allah does not immediately punish His servants who are at fault, but always gives them the opportunity to repent and regret the evil they have committed by doing good deeds that are pleasing to Allah.
text.154: After Musa calmed down and his anger subsided, due to his misunderstanding of his brother Harun, and after seeking mercy and forgiveness from his Lord, he gathered the tablets that he had thrown down, and from them, the Torah was transcribed, containing guidance and mercy for his people.
text.155:
Moses chose seventy men from his people to go with him to a place on Mount Sinai to commune with his Lord. According to the mufassirun, who was chosen and where the designated place was had been revealed by Allah beforehand to Moses. The mufassirun differ in opinion; was Moses commanded by Allah to go to Mount Sinai with seventy chosen men of the Children of Israel after they worshipped the calf idol with the intention of repenting to Allah, or was it at the same time as asking Allah to show Himself clearly? If we look at the structure of the verse and the order of the story of Moses in Surah al-Araf, it can be concluded that Moses' departure with these seventy chosen men was after the Children of Israel worshipped the calf idol, that is, after Moses returned from meeting his Lord on Mount Sinai for forty days and forty nights.

Moses departed with the seventy chosen men towards the designated place. Then, when they were shaken by an earthquake caused by a terrible lightning strike, Moses prayed to his Lord, "O my Lord, indeed You destroy them, so I hope that You destroy them before they go with me to this place, and that You destroy me as well, so that I do not face such difficulties, which give them the opportunity to criticize and accuse me, that I have brought chosen people to this place to be destroyed. Because You did not destroy them before I brought them here with me, then do not destroy them now, after I have brought them here."

This verse explains why the chosen leaders of the Children of Israel were punished by Allah with a terrible lightning strike. In Allah's words, the reasons why they were struck by lightning and the consequences they experienced are explained. As in His saying:

"And [recall] when you said, "O Moses, we will never believe you until we see Allah outright," so the thunderbolt struck you while you were looking on. Then We revived you after your death that perhaps you would be grateful." (al-Baqarah/2: 55-56)

But in the Old Testament it is explained that the Children of Israel who worshipped idols (in the Al-Quran, the calf idol) were the seventy chosen men of the Children of Israel together with Aaron. They committed the act of idol worship while on Mount Sinai, when the Prophet Moses himself was facing God (read Old Testament 31:2-35).

In Numbers xvi:20-25, it is mentioned about the denial and disobedience of the Children of Israel towards Moses, then they were punished by Allah. While the Children of Israel who managed to escape were burned by lightning strikes.

Furthermore, Moses pleaded to Allah, "Do not, O Lord, destroy us because of the actions of those who are less intelligent who ask to see You."

All of that was a trial from Allah for them. But they could not endure and were not strong enough to face the trial, so they continued to urge Moses to have God show them His essence. Because of their actions, they were punished with lightning (thunderbolts) so that they all died. Then Allah brought them back to life so that they could repent and be grateful for the blessings of Allah that had been bestowed upon them. The trial was a test from God to His servants, with the trial those who are not strong in faith will go astray, and with the trial He gives guidance to His servants who are strong in faith.

Furthermore, Moses prayed, "O our Lord, You are the One who manages all our affairs, oversees everything we do, so forgive us for all our actions and deeds that result in punishment for us. Bestow mercy upon us, for You are the best of those who bestow mercy and the best of those who forgive. Only You forgive all sins and pardon all our mistakes. Forgiving and pardoning is not for any particular purpose, but solely because of Your attributes of being the Most Forgiving and the Most Pardoning."
text.156:
Then Moses prayed, "Grant us good in this world, namely physical and spiritual health, be given descendants to continue our lives and inherit our ideals, be given a life in a family filled with affection, be granted lawful sustenance, as well as *taufik* and *hidayah*, so that we may also be happy in the Hereafter. Indeed, we pray and repent to You, we promise not to commit forbidden acts and we return to true faith, and practice righteous deeds that You are pleased with."

Allah said, "My mercy comes to My servants faster than My wrath, and My punishment I specifically bestow upon My servants whom I will, namely those who commit evil, deny, and are disobedient." Regarding My mercy, blessings, and favors, all of that encompasses the universe, not one of My servants does not receive it, including the disbelievers, the disobedient, the Jews, the Christians, and the Muslims, the worshippers of the calf idol and so on. Indeed, if it were not for My mercy, blessings, and favors, I would have destroyed this entire universe, because most people are disbelievers, disobedient, who always commit disobedience.

"And if Allah were to punish people for what they have earned, He would not leave a single creature on earth, but He defers them for a specified term." (Fathir/35: 45)

Allah affirms that the mercy, the blessings of Allah that He gives to the disbelievers, are temporary in nature, not eternal, and not perfect, while perfect and eternal mercy will be bestowed upon those who are pious and those who pay *zakat*.

In this verse, *zakat* is mentioned, not other deeds that are no less valuable than *zakat*. This is related to the large number of people who are reluctant to pay *zakat* compared to the number of people who are reluctant to do other deeds commanded by Allah. It is also an indication of the nature of the Jews who are very fond of wealth and reluctant to give up some of their wealth in the path of Allah.

The establishment of mercy, blessings, and favors specifically to those who are pious and pay *zakat* is like Allah's special establishment to those who affirm His verses, and acknowledge the oneness of Allah and the truth of His messengers whom He has sent with an acknowledgment based on knowledge and conviction, not based on *taqlid* and the influence of the customs of their ancestors.
text.157:
The characteristics of Muhammad as a Messenger are:

1.  The *ummi* (illiterate) Prophet

In this verse, it is explained that one of the characteristics of Muhammad saw is that he was not good at writing and reading. This characteristic implies that an *ummi* person could not possibly read the Torah and the Gospel that were with the Jews and Christians, nor ancient stories related to past peoples. This proves that the message brought by Muhammad saw truly originated from God Almighty. It is impossible for someone who cannot read and write to create and read the Quran and hadith, which contain laws, regulations, and scientific knowledge of such high value. If the Quran were Muhammad's creation, not from the Lord of the Universe, then humans could create or imitate it, but until now, no human has been able to match it.

"And you (O Muhammad) did not recite before it any book, nor did you inscribe one with your right hand. Otherwise the falsifiers would have had [cause for] doubt." (al-Ankabut/29: 48)

2. The coming of Prophet Muhammad was foretold in the Torah and the Gospel

The coming of Muhammad as the final Prophet and Messenger is indicated in the Torah (Genesis xxi. 13,18; Deuteronomy xviii. 15) and the Gospel (John xiv. 16). In the Quran, it is clearly stated that they already knew Muhammad's personality and character:

"Those to whom We gave the Scripture know him as they know their own sons. But indeed, a party of them conceal the truth while they know [it]." (al-Baqarah/2: 146)

The Jews and Christians concealed the news about the sending of Muhammad saw by deleting this news and replacing it with something else in the Torah and the Gospel. Many verses of the Quran explain the actions of the Jews and Christians in changing the contents of the Torah.

Even so, there are still verses in the Old Testament and the New Testament that indicate the coming of Muhammad. In the book of Genesis xi:13, it is explained that a Prophet of the end times will come from the descendants of Ishmael.

From the Torah, there are several indications that can be used as evidence to state that Prophet Muhammad saw is a prophet among the prophets. This shows that those who are appointed by God will arise from the brothers of the Children of Israel, but not from the Children of Israel themselves. As for the brothers of the Children of Israel, they are the Children of Ishmael (the Arab race), because Ishmael is the older brother of Isaac, the father of Prophet Jacob. And Prophet Muhammad saw is clearly a descendant of the Children of Ishmael.

Then, in the book of Kalnest, there is the word, "One like you," which gives the meaning that the prophet who will come must be like Prophet Moses, a Prophet who brings a new law (*sharia* - Islamic law) that also applies to the people of Israel. It is further explained that the prophet is not arrogant, even before becoming a prophet. Before becoming a Prophet, he was already liked by people, as evidenced by the title given to him by the Arabs "Al-Amin"; which means, "The trustworthy one." If he were an arrogant person, he would certainly not be given such a praiseworthy title. After becoming a Prophet, he became even more friendly and humble.

Christians attribute this prophecy to Prophet Jesus, while they acknowledge that Jesus died (was crucified). This clearly contradicts the prophecy itself. Because the Prophet must not die. It is also mentioned that God has come from Mount Sinai, meaning giving revelation to Moses, and has risen for them in Seir (Deuteronomy ii. 1-8)", meaning sending down revelation to Prophet Jesus, and the brilliance of its light from Mount Paran, meaning sending down revelation to Muhammad saw. Paran (Faron) is the name of one of the hills in Mecca.

In John xiv.16, xv.26 and xvi.7, the prophecy of Prophet Muhammad saw is mentioned as follows: "But when the Helper comes, whom I will send to you from the Father, the Spirit of truth, who proceeds from the Father, he will bear witness about me. And you also will bear witness, because you have been with me from the beginning." The word "Periclytos" is Greek, which means the same as "Ahmad" in Arabic. This is in accordance with the word of Allah swt:

"And [mention] when Jesus, the son of Mary, said, "O children of Israel, indeed I am the messenger of Allah to you, confirming what came before me of the Torah and bringing good tidings of a messenger to come after me, whose name is Ahmad." (ash-shaff/61: 6)

Thus, even though there are parts of the Torah and the Gospel that have been changed, added to, and removed, there are still indications about the prophethood and apostleship of Muhammad saw. That is also why some Jewish and Hebrew scholars who recognized the truth of the news immediately believed in Muhammad and the message he brought, such as Abdullah bin Salam from the Jews, and Tamim ad-Dari from the Christians.

3. The Prophet commands good and forbids evil

Good deeds (*maruf*) are good deeds that are in accordance with common sense, beneficial to themselves, humanity, and in accordance with religious teachings. While evil deeds (*mungkar*) are bad deeds that are not in accordance with common sense and can cause harm to oneself, to humanity. The highest value of good deeds is recognizing the oneness of Allah and showing obedience to Him, while the worst evil deed is associating partners with Allah swt.

4. Making lawful what is good and prohibiting what is bad

What is meant by good is what is lawful and good, does not damage the mind, thoughts, body and soul. While what is meant by bad is what is forbidden, which damages the mind, thoughts, body and soul.

5. Removing various burdens and shackles that are burdensome

The meaning is that the *sharia* brought by Prophet Muhammad saw no longer has heavy burdens like those imposed on the Children of Israel. For example, prescribing suicide or killing desires for the validity of repentance, requiring *qishash* (retaliation) for murder, whether intentional or unintentional, without allowing the payment of *diyat* (blood money), cutting off the body part that committed the mistake, throwing away or cutting cloth that has been contaminated with impurity, and so on. In accordance with the word of Allah swt:

"Allah does not intend to make difficulty for you, but He intends to purify you and complete His favor upon you that you may be grateful." (al-Maidah/5: 6)

Likewise, Rasululllah saw said:

"Give glad tidings and do not give frightening news, make things easy and do not make things difficult, unite and do not disagree." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Indeed, heavy laws have been indicated to the Children of Israel, both laws of worship and laws of *muamalat* (social and economic transactions). Then, heavy laws of worship were prescribed to Prophet Jesus as. While the *sharia* of Prophet Muhammad saw is not burdensome, but rather expands and lightens the burden, both in relation to the laws of worship and in relation to the laws of *muamalat*.

Allah explains the ways to follow the Messenger whose characteristics have been mentioned, in order to live happily in this world and in the hereafter, namely believing in him and in the message he brought, helping him with a sense of respect, upholding and elevating the religion he brought, and following the Quran he brought.
text.158:
Allah commanded Muhammad to call all of mankind to follow the religion he brought, wherever they may be, and whatever nation they are, so that he may explain that he is the Messenger of Allah sent to them all. The universality of Muhammad's message (peace and blessings be upon him) is further stated by Allah's word:

And We have not sent you (O Muhammad) except to all of mankind as a bearer of good tidings and a warner... (Saba/34: 28)

And Allah's word also:

...This Qur'an has been revealed to me that I may warn you thereby and whomever it reaches... (al-Anam/6: 19)

Similarly, the hadith of the Prophet explains the universality of his message as follows:

"I have been given five things which were not given to any prophet before me. I was helped by instilling fear in my enemy for a distance of one month's journey, and the earth was made a masjid (place of prayer) and a means of purification for me. So whoever of my ummah is overtaken by the time of prayer, let him pray (wherever he is), and spoils of war were made lawful for me, which were not lawful for anyone before me, I was given intercession (syafaat), and a prophet was sent to his own people only, while I have been sent to all of mankind." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim)

Allah explains His Oneness, that there is no god but Him, only He is worthy of worship, because He manages the heavens and the earth, regulating the entire universe. He gives life to all that lives and causes all that dies to die. In this verse, three main powers of God are explained: namely, the owner of what is in the heavens and the earth, the only God who can be worshiped, the God who gives life and causes death.

Then Allah commands all mankind to believe in Allah and to believe in the unlettered Prophet, to believe in His revelation, namely the previous books, and commands mankind to follow that prophet.

That unlettered Messenger purifies devotion to Allah, believing in the books that have been revealed to the previous Prophets. After the command to believe, Allah follows it with the command for mankind to implement all the sharia brought by the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him).
text.159:
Among the people of Moses, there was a large group who guided people to the right path according to what Allah commanded, invited people to do good, established justice among people, did not follow their desires, did not eat food that Allah had forbidden, and did not do forbidden deeds, whether they were in the time of Moses or in the time after him.

The state of the people of Moses is further explained in Allah SWT's words:

"They are not (all) alike. Among the People of the Scripture are a community standing (in obedience), reciting the verses of Allah during periods of the night and prostrating (in prayer)." (Ali Imran/3: 113)

Some of the people of Moses accepted and implemented Allah SWT's guidance with all their hearts. They are of three types:

a. The people of Moses who were present during the time of the Prophet Muhammad SAW, or after he died, they read the Torah, then believed in Muhammad SAW, according to the indications they read in the Torah.

b. The people of Moses who truly believed in Muhammad SAW after he died.

c. The people of Moses who lived in two periods, namely the period before Muhammad was sent. They fully believed in the Prophet Moses. After Muhammad was sent, they believed in Muhammad according to the guidance they found in the Torah.
text.160:
Allah divided the people of Moses (Bani Israil), both those who believed in Allah and those who disbelieved in Him, into twelve tribes called "Sibth." On a journey in the desert, his people suffered from thirst, so Allah revealed to Moses to strike a rock with his staff. After Moses struck it, twelve springs gushed forth from the rock, corresponding to the number of the tribes of Bani Israil (al-Baqarah/2: 60). Each tribe was provided with a spring, and they knew their drinking place; to maintain order and avoid crowding.

This event was a miracle for the Prophet Moses to prove his apostleship and to show the power of Allah. If previously he struck the sea with his staff so that a path was stretched out for the Bani Israil to escape from the pursuit of Pharaoh and his army, then in this event Moses struck a rock with his staff, so that water came out of the rock to quench the thirst of his people. This event, besides being a miracle for the Prophet Moses, also shows the greatness of Allah's grace that has been bestowed upon the Bani Israil.

In addition to that grace, Allah mentions another grace that He has given to the Bani Israil, namely:

1. Allah protected them with clouds when they walked in the desert and during the scorching heat of the sun. If there were no clouds to protect them, they would have been burned by the heat of the sun. This happened when they left Egypt and after crossing the Red Sea. They arrived in the desert on the Sinai Peninsula and were struck by scorching heat. Therefore, they asked Moses to pray to God to give His help. So Allah helped them by bringing clouds that could protect them from the scorching heat of the sun.

2. In addition, Allah also bestowed upon them food called "al-manna", a kind of sweet food like honey, which came down continuously from the sky, from dawn until sunrise. In addition, Allah also bestowed upon them a type of quail food called "shalwa".

3. Allah commanded them to eat halal food, which is good, beneficial for the body and soul, mind and thought.

Allah has bestowed His immense grace upon the Bani Israil, but they did not want to be grateful, instead they committed acts that Allah forbade, disbelieved in Him and in His Messengers, which resulted in them receiving His torment and punishment. They were punished solely because of their own actions, not because Allah wanted to persecute them. It is mentioned in a Hadith Qudsi:

"O My servants, indeed I have forbidden (committing) injustice upon Myself, and I have made injustice (as an act) forbidden among you, so do not be unjust to one another (among yourselves). O My servants, you will never be able to cause harm to Me, so that I will suffer harm because of it, and you all cannot give benefit to Me, so that I will receive benefit from it." (Hadith Qudsi is the word of Allah spoken or conveyed by the Prophet Muhammad, but it is not a verse of the Al-Quran. Narrated by Muslim)
text.161:
These verses 161 and 162 of Surah al-A'raf are essentially a continuation of verses 58 and 59 of Surah al-Baqarah, even serving as a complement and explanation of those verses. In verses 58 and 59 of Surah al-Baqarah, Allah commanded the Children of Israel to enter Baitul Maqdis with humility as a sign of obedience and gratitude to Allah, because they had been saved from the pursuit of their enemies, and were also safe in that very difficult and arduous journey, and furthermore, to ask forgiveness from Allah for all the sins they had committed. If they carried out all these commands, Allah would forgive all their sins and mistakes and would give them additional grace and reward.

In verses 161 and 162 of Surah al-A'raf, it is understood that the Children of Israel had entered Baitul Maqdis as Allah had commanded. They were also commanded by Allah to reside and settle in that land. However, the wrongdoers among them did not carry out Allah's commands perfectly; in fact, they committed acts and actions that contradicted those commands, even though the command came from the Helper who freed them from misery and hardship. They easily twisted those commands. They entered Baitul Maqdis not with humility, and they did not ask to be freed from sin. As a result of their denial and disobedience, they were afflicted with a severe punishment. According to some commentators of the Quran (ahli tafsir), the punishment inflicted upon them was in the form of a cholera epidemic that spread and infected some of them.
text.162:
These verses 161 and 162 of Surah al-A'raf are essentially a continuation of verses 58 and 59 of Surah al-Baqarah, even serving as a complement and explanation of those verses. In verses 58 and 59 of Surah al-Baqarah, Allah commanded the Children of Israel to enter Baitul Maqdis with humility as a sign of obedience and gratitude to Allah, because they had been saved from the pursuit of their enemies, and were also safe in that very difficult and arduous journey, and furthermore to ask forgiveness from Allah for all the sins they had committed. If they carried out all those commands, Allah would forgive all their sins and mistakes and would give them additional grace and reward.

In verses 161 and 162 of Surah al-A'raf, it is understood that the Children of Israel had entered Baitul Maqdis as Allah had commanded. They were also commanded by Allah to reside and settle in that land. However, the wrongdoers among them did not carry out Allah's commands perfectly; in fact, they committed deeds and actions that contradicted those commands, even though the command came from the Helper who freed them from misery and hardship. They easily twisted those commands. They entered Baitul Maqdis not with humility, and they did not ask to be freed from sin. As a result of their denial and disobedience, they were afflicted with a severe punishment. According to some commentators of the Quran (ahli tafsir), the punishment inflicted upon them was in the form of a cholera epidemic that spread and infected some of them.
text.163:
This verse was revealed in Mecca, at a time when the Islamic religion began to be disseminated and conveyed by the Prophet Muhammad saw, who at that time had never had direct contact with Jewish scholars, and he was someone who did not know how to write and read, as Allah swt says:

"And you (O Muhammad) did not recite before it any book, nor did you inscribe one with your right hand, for then the falsifiers would have doubted." (al-Ankabut/29: 48)

This verse demonstrates the miraculous nature of the Al-Quran, which explains news, events, or occurrences that happened in the past, without anyone providing the information, except from the All-Knowing Lord.

This verse is addressed to the Prophet Muhammad so that he could explain to the Jews in Medina at that time, about the actions that had been carried out by their ancestors, who always denied the calls of the Prophets, despite whatever evidence had been presented to them. The one narrating about the actions and attitudes of their ancestors is the Prophet Muhammad, an illiterate Prophet, who had never had contact with the Jews at the time of receiving this verse. Is this not enough to be proof for them that Muhammad is truly a messenger of Allah?

The *qaryah* (town/village) referred to in the verse is as follows: some mention Ailah, some mention Tobaiah, and some mention other cities. In the past, the ancestors of the Children of Israel who lived in Ailah, a city on the coast of the Red Sea between the cities of Madyan and Sinai, whose livelihood was catching fish, were once tested and tried by Allah, to test their faith and obedience. They were ordered to perform worship every Saturday, and were forbidden to catch fish on that day. When fish appeared in abundance on the surface of the water (sea) on Saturday, appearing tame and easy to catch, they violated Allah's prohibition on that day to catch fish and did not perform worship as Allah had commanded on that day.

Thus, Allah gave tests and trials to the Children of Israel. They could not endure and were not steadfast in facing them, they even violated Allah's prohibition and did not carry out His command. Because of their attitude and actions, *Sunnatullah* (Allah's law/decree) applied to them, which is that whoever obeys Allah's command and stops His prohibition will be granted the pleasures of life in this world and in the hereafter. Conversely, whoever denies Him will suffer in this life, while in the hereafter they will receive a painful torment. Of course, this *Sunnatullah* also applies to the wicked and the Jews who are in Medina, as it applied to their ancestors.
text.164:
The attitude of a group of the ancestors of the Children of Israel who reproached another group of the Children of Israel, namely, warning the Children of Israel who had denied Allah's command and did not stop His prohibitions.
