In this verse, it is also understood that not all the ancestors of the Children of Israel ignored Allah's command and violated His prohibitions on the Sabbath day; some of them observed it.

From this verse, it can also be understood that in responding to Allah's commands and prohibitions, they were divided into three groups:

1. The group that ignored Allah's command and violated His prohibitions on the Sabbath day.

2. The group that advised the group that ignored Allah's command and violated His prohibitions.

3. The group that refuted the actions of the group that gave advice.

The second group said to the third group: "We give lessons to them, is to free ourselves from sinful deeds and to carry out our duty, which is to prevent evil deeds. We hope that those who are disobedient will realize and return to the right and straight path."

When the Children of Israel remained defiant and unwilling to return to the path of Allah, and continued to ignore the advice that had been given, then Allah inflicted a severe punishment upon them and saved those who gave the advice.

Some scholars are of the opinion that Allah's punishment did not befall the third group, while other scholars are of the opinion that the punishment also befell the third group, because only the second group was obedient, while the third group did not forbid the commission of evil deeds, but even refuted and blamed those who forbade the commission of evil deeds.
text.165:
Those who violated Allah's ordinances on the Sabbath are called "Those who forgot the reminder." This means those who disregarded Allah's threats directed at those who disbelieve in Him, did not heed His advice and warnings, and did not implement His teachings. They even turned away from those teachings, as if they had forgotten them and there was no trace whatsoever within them of the reminder that had been given.

Therefore, Allah affirms that His Sunnatullah (established way) applies to them, which is that Allah saves those who are obedient to Him and punishes those who are wicked and disobedient. Allah explains that the Children of Israel were punished not solely because of their wickedness in violating Allah's ordinances on the Sabbath, but also because of the wicked deeds they always committed. According to Sunnatullah, He also punishes the disobedient directly in this world because of the sins they have committed, as Allah SWT says:

"And if Allah were to punish men for their wrongdoing, He would not leave on it (the earth) a single moving (living) creature..." (an-Nahl/16: 61)

And Allah forgives a large portion of the sins of His servants, as in His saying:

"And whatever of misfortune befalls you, it is because of what your hands have earned. And He pardons much." (asy-Syura/42: 30)

In this verse, Allah will directly punish a people or nation in this world before they receive punishment in the Hereafter, if the injustice of that people or nation has a great impact and is difficult to eliminate from human life and humanity, as Allah stated in His saying:

"And fear a trial which will not strike those who oppress [only] among you, and know that Allah is severe in punishment." (al-Anfal/8: 25)

The punishment referred to has been inflicted upon previous nations who denied the calls of the Prophets who were sent to them.
text.166:
When the Children of Israel increased in their oppression, ignoring all advice, Allah punished them by turning them into despised apes. According to some *mufassirin* (Quran commentators), this is the interpretation of the phrase "a severe punishment" found in the verse above. Others say that this was a separate punishment that Allah inflicted in addition to the severe punishment.

The *mufassirin* differ in their opinions regarding: Were the Children of Israel transformed into actual apes, or were only their characteristics and nature ape-like, while their bodies remained like ordinary human bodies? The majority of scholars hold the opinion that they truly became apes, like real apes. However, they did not reproduce, eat, drink, or live for more than three days.

According to Mujahid, as narrated by Ibn Jarir, and the opinion of al-Manar: Their appearance was not changed into apes, but rather their hearts, souls, and characteristics were transformed into those of apes. (For a complete explanation, see Tafsir Surah al-Baqarah/2:65).
text.167:
In this verse, Prophet Muhammad is reminded by Allah about His notification to the Jews, that He would send other people more powerful than them to colonize and torture them. They will always live in humiliation and suffering until the end of time, due to their actions that contradict the laws of Allah. History has clearly proven this threat from Allah. After the time of Prophet Solomon, the Jewish people were fought by the Babylonians under King Nebuchadnezzar, they were destroyed, many men were killed and many women were made slaves. Many of them were also taken to Babylon as prisoners, after which they were colonized alternately by various kingdoms, therefore they suffered for centuries due to incessant wars. Finally, they fell into the hands of the Romans until the time of Prophet Jesus. During the Roman Christian era, they no longer had power, in fact they were expelled from their land and scattered in several countries. Some of them fled to the Arabian Peninsula. They lived in this area safely. But then after Islam came, they opposed Prophet Muhammad. Even though he had given them the freedom to live in Islamic areas based on agreements with them. Because of their hostile and treacherous attitude, the Muslims were forced to expel them from Islamic areas. Some of them were killed or died because they sided with the polytheists during the war (Battle of the Trench/Ahzab).

In the 20th century, they experienced indescribable suffering. In the last World War II, many Jews became victims of Nazi Germany's power. In America, Europe and Russia, they still experience a lot of humiliation today. Even though the Jews now have a homeland (the State of Israel), they remain in suffering, because of their attitude as well, because the people of the world, especially Muslims, are hostile to them. The State of Israel was formed by expelling the Palestinian people who were the original inhabitants of that country. Such is the fate of the Jewish people. Indeed, the law of Allah applies to people who disobey His commands and create chaos. But Allah's forgiveness and love are very great and vast for those who repent from their sins, return to the path of Allah with full awareness, and by making improvements. Allah will surely erase their suffering.
text.168:
In this verse, Allah describes their punishment and suffering, which is that they were scattered across the earth, one group in one region and another group in another region.

Some of them became people who always made improvements and believed in the Prophets, but others were truly immersed in disbelief and wickedness to the point of killing the Prophets, distorting the contents of the Torah, and opposing the Prophet Muhammad.

To make them aware, they were tested with alternating pleasure and suffering, but it did not deter them. Those who were good were given the grace of goodness and happiness. Those who were disobedient were brought down with the calamity of misery. All of this was a trial for them so that they would return to the right path.
text.169:
In this verse, Allah explains a generation of Jews who replaced the previous Jewish people. They are the Jews who lived during the time of Prophet Muhammad, inheriting the Torah from their ancestors and accepting everything written in it as is. They knew the laws of halal and haram, commands and prohibitions in the book, but they did not practice them. They prioritized worldly interests with all their fleeting splendor. They sought wealth through efforts detached from moral and religious laws, developing usury (riba), taking bribes, showing favoritism in the law, and so on, because they believed that Allah would forgive their sins in the future. These Jews considered themselves Allah's beloved and a chosen people. Such assumptions only misled their minds. Therefore, whenever there was an opportunity to gain worldly advantages such as bribes, usury (riba), and so on, they would not waste it.

Allah affirms the error of their opinions and assumptions, which persisted in misguidance and were immersed in material desires. Allah reveals the existence of a covenant between them and Allah, as stated in the Torah, that they would not say anything about Allah except the truth. But they distorted the contents of the Torah, driven by the desire to obtain worldly gains, even though they understood the contents of the Torah well and were aware of the wrongfulness of their actions. They should have prioritized the interests of the hereafter by acting in accordance with Allah's guidance and the Torah, rather than worldly gains. For those who are pious, the happiness of the hereafter is better than the limited happiness of this world. Why do they not reflect on such things?

This verse explains that the inclination towards materialism and a material life is a factor that caused the deceitfulness of the Jews as a nation with a state. Because of their great love for worldly life, they lost religious guidance and became dry in their spiritual lives.

What befell the Jews of the past may also befall Muslims of today, because they prioritize material life more and set aside spiritual life, so their actions are very far from the teachings of the Al-Quran.
text.170:
This verse mentions some Jews who deserve an award of appreciation for their steadfast adherence to the contents of the Torah. They obeyed all of God's commands and avoided all His prohibitions. These Jews, upon hearing the call of the Prophet Muhammad, immediately believed in him in accordance with the guidance of the Torah, such as Abdullah Ibn Salam and his companions. They established prayer (salat), which is the pillar of religion and the differentiator between believers and disbelievers. God will not waste any of the good deeds they have done. Surely, He will reward them, because they have made amends for their actions.

Allah swt says:

"Indeed, those who have believed and done righteous deeds - indeed, We will not allow to be lost the reward of any who did well in deeds." (al-Kahf/18: 30)
text.171: Then Allah concludes the story of the Jews by reminding them again of the event when they first received the Torah. When Mount Sinai was raised above their heads so that the mountain was like a dark cloud, they saw the mountain floating in the air about to fall upon them. They became aware of Allah's threat that if they opposed religious commands, they would surely perish. At that time, Allah called out to them to accept and obey the religious laws contained in the Torah earnestly. And they should remember His commands and prohibitions in the Torah, practice them and not neglect them, even if they experience difficulties and suffering. Their obedience to religious laws and His commands and prohibitions in truth, leads them to personal development and taqwa.
text.172:
In this verse, Allah explains the promise made when humans were born from the wombs of their parents, generation after generation, namely that Allah created humans based on *fitrah* (natural disposition). Allah commanded their souls to witness the arrangement of their own creation, which proves His Oneness, the miracle of the creation process from a drop of semen to becoming a complete human being, possessing sensory perception, with an amazing network of veins and nervous systems, and so on. Allah said to the souls of humans, "Am I not your Lord?" Then the souls of humans answered, "Yes (You are our Lord), we have witnessed." This answer is an acknowledgment by the individual human soul from the beginning of its creation of the existence of Allah, the One and Only, who has no other god worthy of worship except Him.

With this verse, Allah intends to explain to humans that the essence of human creation is based on belief in Allah, the One and Only. Since humans are born from the wombs of their parents, they have already witnessed the signs of Allah's Oneness in their own creation. Allah says in another verse:

So direct your face toward the religion, inclining to truth. (Adhere to) the *fitrah* of Allah upon which He has created [all] people. No change should there be in the creation of Allah. (ar-Rum/30: 30)

The *fitrah* of Allah means *tauhid* (monotheism). The Messenger of Allah said:

"There is no one born except according to *fitrah*. It is his parents who make him a Jew, a Christian, or a Magian. As an animal gives birth to its young with perfect ears, do you know of any defect in the young animal?" (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim, from Abu Hurairah)

The Messenger of Allah in a *hadith Qudsi*:

Allah Ta'ala said, "Indeed, I created My servants inclined (towards the religion of *tauhid*). Then the devils came to them and turned them away from their religion (*tauhid*), so they made unlawful for them everything that I had made lawful for them." (Narrated by al-Bukhari from Iyadh bin Himar)

The rejection of the teachings of *Tauhid* brought by the Prophet is actually an act that contradicts human *fitrah* and the voice of their conscience. Therefore, it is not right for humans on the Day of Judgment to offer the excuse that they were oblivious, never reminded to single out Allah. Their own *fitrah* and the teachings of the Prophets constantly remind them to single out Allah, obey the call of the Messenger, and distance themselves from *shirk* (polytheism).
text.173:
Then in this verse, Allah affirms again that it is not true for the disbelievers to say on the Day of Judgment, as an excuse, that their ancestors were the first to create polytheism and then pass on the habit of shirk to them. As their descendants, they say that they did not know the mistakes made by their ancestors, so they did not know the path to tawhid. "Should we be destroyed and punished for the mistakes and actions of our ancestors?"

Blindly following (taqlid) ancestors cannot be used as an excuse to deny the oneness of Allah, because the evidence of Allah's oneness is very clear before them, and they are able to draw conclusions from that evidence so that they arrive at tawhid.
text.174: Then Allah states that everything mentioned above, namely regarding the creation of mankind based on a fitrah (natural disposition) inclined towards the religion of tawhid (monotheism), and the weakness of their reasons for rejecting the teachings of tawhid, is a warning from Allah to mankind, about His ayat (signs/verses), so that they may use their reason and intellect and return to the path of tawhid, return to their fitrah, and distance themselves from taqlid (blind following) of their ancestors and from heedlessness and ignorance.
text.175:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to recite to the Jews and the polytheists a story of a man to whom Allah had given knowledge of the contents of the Book and divinity, and he understood the proofs of the Oneness of Allah, so that he became a knowledgeable person.

Regarding who this person is in this verse, several commentators (mufasir) have different opinions. There were several prominent people in the time of the Prophet who had read the holy books and knew that Allah would send a messenger at that time. Those who were ambitious hoped that they would be the ones sent to be prophets, such as Umayyah, a famous poet from the Saqif tribe. Some say that person was Abu 'Amir ar-Rahib, while others say the verse is not directed at an individual, but at a group, namely the Quraysh, with the verses revealed to the Prophet, but they rejected them. Another opinion says that it refers to the hypocrites among the People of the Book who knew the Messenger of Allah as well as they knew their own families, but they also rejected him. Some even say that it refers to someone in the time of Prophet Musa, while another opinion says it refers to Pharaoh and his group who rejected Musa's call. Several commentators tend to accept the statements of Qatadah, Ikrimah, and Abu Muslim from the salaf, that the purpose of this verse is general, as a very great spiritual lesson, not directed at a specific individual or group, as stated by some later commentators. The type of person referred to here is someone who understands the divine message, but refuses to accept the truth, he is already controlled by the material world, as indicated in the following verse, "and he inclined to the earth and followed his own vain desires."
text.176:
In this verse, Allah explains that if He had willed to elevate that man with the knowledge He had given him to a higher status, He would certainly have been able to do so. But that man had determined his choice towards the path of error. He took a path contrary to his fitrah (natural disposition), turning away from his own knowledge, driven by personal denial, namely the luxuries of worldly life. He followed his desires and was tempted by Satan. He forgot all guidance from Allah, and no longer listened to the voice of his conscience.

Allah says:

"Indeed, We have made that which is on the earth adornment for it that We may test them [as to] which of them is best in deed." (al-Kahf/18: 7)

Ideally, a person who is given knowledge and ability should elevate his spirituality, place himself at a level of perfection, and fill his knowledge and faith with noble deeds accompanied by sincere intentions and correct beliefs. But that man, after being given the blessing of knowledge about the Oneness of Allah, came out "like a snake that comes out of its skin and sheds it forever." In this verse, the word insalakha, Ø§Ù†Ø³Ù„Ø® "to come out of skin, covering, or sheath," is used, meaning to shed the knowledge that Allah gave him, and remain a disbeliever as if he had not been given anything. Therefore, in the following verse, Allah likens him to a dog whose condition is the same whether it is burdened or left alone, it still lolls its tongue. A man who has the characteristics of a dog is among the worst of people.

This illustrates greed for worldly possessions. He always occupies his soul and body in pursuing worldly things, so that he appears as someone who is hungry and thirsty and never satisfied. His condition is like a dog that lolls its tongue, appearing always thirsty and hungry, never satisfied in wanting water and food.

Likewise is the parable of the people who deny the verses of Allah. They oppose them, whether due to ignorance or because of their fanaticism towards the world, which causes them to close their eyes to the truth and abandon it. They realize the truth that Muhammad brought, and acknowledge the errors and mistakes of their ancestors after they reflect on the evidence of the truth brought by the Messenger of Allah. But that awareness and acknowledgement disappear from their souls because of their desires that only pursue worldly pleasures, such as wanting power and wealth. The Jews and the Arab polytheists rejected the verses of Allah because they wanted to maintain their power and interests. They were afraid of losing the pleasures and luxuries of life. Satan had tempted them to slip from their fitrah, which is the inclination towards the religion of Tawhid (monotheism).

The story of the man who has many similarities with the opponents of the verses of Allah deserves attention so that they are willing to reflect on and think about the verses of Allah honestly and objectively, free from hostility and personal interests.
text.177: In this verse, Allah reaffirms how terrible the parable is for those who deny the verses of Allah. They are likened to dogs, either because of the similarity in their weakness, namely that they remain in error whether warned or not, or because of the similarity in their habits. A dog has no ambition except the desire to obtain food and satisfaction. Whoever abandons knowledge and faith and then inclines towards their desires is like a dog. Such a person is no longer ready to think and reflect on the truth. Such a person is actually oppressing themselves.
text.178:
In this verse, Allah explains that those who receive guidance from Allah are those who are guided by Him in using their intellect, senses, and energy in accordance with their fitrah (natural disposition) and the guidance of their own religion. They are grateful for Allah's blessings, they fulfill their religious obligations, so they are fortunate in this world and the hereafter. Conversely, those who are at a loss in this world and the hereafter are those who are kept away from the guidelines set by Allah in using their intellect, senses, and energy, they follow their desires, do not want to understand Allah's verses, and do not want to be grateful for the blessings that Allah has given them. Indeed, the path to Allah's guidance is only one, which is to worship Him with good deeds that arise from faith. Meanwhile, the paths that lead to error are many and varied, because people are divided, hostile to one another, and give rise to various kinds of evil.

Allah says:

And indeed, this is My path, which is straight, so follow it; and do not follow [other] ways, for you will be separated from His way. (al-Anam/6: 153)
text.179:
Then, in this verse, Allah elaborates on what was not detailed in the previous verses regarding the things that cause people to fall into error. Allah explains that many people become the inhabitants of Hell, just as those who enter Paradise do, according to their respective deeds.

The things that cause people to be punished in Hell are: that their minds and feelings are not used to understand the oneness and greatness of Allah, even though belief in the oneness of Allah cleanses their souls from all kinds of doubts and from the characteristics of being base and inferior, and instills in them a sense of self-confidence.

Likewise, they do not use their minds for spiritual life and eternal happiness. Their souls are bound to worldly life, as Allah says:

"They know what is apparent of the worldly life, but they, of the Hereafter, are heedless." (ar-Rum/30: 7)

They do not understand that the purpose of being commanded to avoid disobedience and do good deeds is for happiness in this world and the Hereafter. They do not understand the laws of society and the influence of Islamic religious belief in uniting the ummah. They do not understand the signs of Allah's oneness, both within human beings and on the face of the earth. They do not understand and contemplate the revelation of God that was conveyed to His Messenger.

They have eyes, but they are not used to see the evidence of the truth and oneness of Allah. All events in human history, all events that occur in human life every day, what is seen and what is heard, do not become material for thought and reflection to be analyzed, and this is concluded by Allah in His word:

"And We had established them in that which We have not established you, and We made for them hearing and vision and hearts. But their hearing and vision and hearts availed them not since they were ever denying the signs of Allah, and they were enveloped by what they used to ridicule." (al-Ahqaf/46: 26)

They cannot utilize their eyes, ears, and minds, so they do not obtain Allah's guidance that leads them to happiness in this world and the Hereafter. Their condition is like animals, even worse than animals, because animals do not have the power of thought to process the results of their sight and hearing. Animals react to the outside world based on instinct and aim only to maintain life. They eat and drink, and fulfill their needs, not exceeding the limits of animal biological needs. But what about humans, when they have become slaves to their desires? And their minds are no longer useful. They are excessive in fulfilling their own physical needs, excessive in reducing the rights of others. They extort the rights of others, sometimes even beyond humanity.

If such a trait befalls a nation and a country, then that country will become greedy and oppress other nations and countries. They have hearts (feelings and thoughts), but they are not used to understand the verses (of Allah). They forget and neglect the evidence of Allah's truth in themselves, in humanity, and in this universe; they forget the use of feelings and thoughts for noble purposes and abandon the essential interests of human life as individuals and as a nation.
text.180:
Al-Asmaul Husna means the names of Allah that are the best, the broadest, and the deepest in meaning, as the Prophet Muhammad said:

"Indeed, Allah has ninety-nine names, one hundred less one, whoever memorizes them will enter Paradise." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

The number ninety-nine does not mean a limit to the number, indeed the names of Allah are unlimited. In the Al-Quran, the names of Allah are more than that number. These names are attributes of the essence of Allah, the One and Only, not the essence of God as imagined by the polytheists.

Regarding the ninety-nine Asmaul Husna, it is narrated by at-Tirmizi and al-Hakim from the path (sanad) of al-Walid bin Muslim as follows:

He is Allah, there is no god but Him. (1) The Most Gracious, (2) The Most Merciful, (3) The Sovereign, (4) The Most Holy, (5) The Source of Peace, (6) The Granter of Security, (7) The Protector, (8) The Almighty, (9) The Compeller, (10) The Possessor of Greatness, (11) The Creator, (12) The Originator, (13) The Fashioner, (14) The Forgiver, (15) The Subduer, (16) The Bestower, (17) The Sustainer, (18) The Judge, (19) The All-Knowing, (20) The Withholder, (21) The Expander, (22) The Abaser, (23) The Exalter, (24) The Giver of Honor, (25) The Humiliator, (26) The All-Hearing, (27) The All-Seeing, (28) The Judge, (29) The Just, (30) The Subtle, (31) The Aware, (32) The Clement, (33) The Magnificent, (34) The Forgiving, (35) The Appreciative, (36) The Most High, (37) The Greatest, (38) The Preserver, (39) The Ordainer of Time, (40) The Reckoner, (41) The Majestic, (42) The Generous, (43) The Watcher, (44) The Responsive, (45) The Vast, (46) The Wise, (47) The Loving, (48) The Glorious, (49) The Raiser of the Dead, (50) The Witness, (51) The Truth, (52) The Trustee, (53) The Strong, (54) The Firm, (55) The Protector, (56) The Praiseworthy, (57) The Accounter, (58) The Originator, (59) The Restorer, (60) The Giver of Life, (61) The Taker of Life, (62) The Living, (63) The Self-Subsisting, (64) The Finder, (65) The Noble, (66) The Independent, (67) The One, (68) The Ultimate, (69) The Powerful, (70) The Determiner, (71) The Expediter, (72) The Delayer, (73) The First, (74) The Last, (75) The Manifest, (76) The Hidden, (77) The Governor, (78) The Exalted, (79) The Beneficent, (80) The Acceptor of Repentance, (81) The Avenger, (82) The Pardoner, (83) The Kind, (84) The Owner of Sovereignty, (85) The Possessor of Majesty and Honor, (86) The Equitable, (87) The Gatherer, (88) The Rich, (89) The Enricher, (90) The Preventer, (91) The Distresser, (92) The Benefiter, (93) The Light, (94) The Guide, (95) The Incomparable, (96) The Everlasting, (97) The Inheritor, (98) The Guide to Rectitude, (99) The Patient. (Narrated by at-Tirmizi and al-Hakim)

The translation of the names of Allah cannot actually be translated accurately. This translation is merely to explain its meaning according to the limitations of the Indonesian language.

Allah commands His servants to mention these best names in prayer and remembrance (dhikr). Because by praying and remembering Him, they always remember Allah, and their faith becomes more alive and fertile in their souls.

In addition, Allah also commands the believers to abandon the behavior of those who distort the meaning of the names of Allah from the correct meaning, for example by giving *ta'wil* or twisting the meaning so as to obscure the absolute perfection of the attributes of Allah. Those who do so will be afflicted by Allah's punishment. Deviation or distortion from the names of Allah, the Most Perfect, takes various forms, including:

1.  Giving Allah names that are not found in the Al-Quran or in authentic hadith of the Prophet. All scholars agree that the names and attributes of Allah must be based on the explanation of the Al-Quran and the hadith of the Prophet (tauqifi).

2.  Rejecting the names and attributes that Allah has established for His essence, or refusing to attribute an action to Allah because they consider it inappropriate for His holiness or diminishes His holiness. Those who reject this view themselves as if they know better than Allah and His Messenger, what is appropriate and what is not appropriate for Allah.

3.  Naming something other than Allah with a name that is only appropriate for Allah.

4.  Distorting the names and attributes of Allah with one's own interpretations so that they deviate from the true meaning and intent, such as the understanding that the attributes of Allah are the same as human attributes, such as hearing, seeing, speaking, having a face, hands, feet, laughing, being angry, being happy, and so on. Although Allah has the attributes of hearing, seeing, and so on, Allah's hearing is not the same as the hearing of creatures, Allah's seeing is not the same as the seeing of creatures. Or the understanding that gives *ta'wil* to the attributes of Allah in such a way that the attributes of Allah have no meaning at all.

5.  Associating Allah with worship other than Allah in terms of names that are specific to Allah. Such as using the word Allah for an idol or the words *Rabbul alamin*.
text.181:
In this verse, Allah explains that He also created a large community to inhabit Paradise. They consist of communities and tribes who strive to guide humanity to the right path and educate them to be steadfast. They uphold the justice and truth that Allah has established, and they have no choice but the path of Allah. These are the ummah of Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him).

The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said in relation to this verse:

"This is my ummah, with truth they command, make decisions, take (their rights) and give (the rights of others)." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim in the *shahihain*)

The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) said in another hadith:

"There will always be a group from my ummah who uphold the truth; those who oppose them will not be able to harm them until the decree of Allah (the Day of Judgment) comes." (Narrated by Ibn Majah from Thauban)

From these hadiths, it can be concluded that the *ijma'* (consensus) of the scholars is a proof (*hujah*) in every era, and in every era there must be people who are experts in *ijtihad* (independent reasoning).
text.182:
In this verse, Allah explains that those who deny Allah's verses, like the Quraysh who opposed the da'wah of Muhammad saw, will certainly receive Allah's punishment gradually without realizing the consequences of their error. This is because they do not understand the Sunnatullah in the growth and development of humanity, that the struggle between truth and falsehood, between right and wrong, will surely result in the victory of truth. That which benefits mankind overcomes that which harms them.

Allah says:

"Rather, We dash the truth upon falsehood, and it destroys it, and thereupon it departs." (al-Anbiya/21: 18)

And Allah swt also says:

"As for the foam, it vanishes, [passing away] as useless; but what benefits the people remains on the earth. Thus does Allah present examples." (ar-Rad/13: 17)

Allah's warning to those who oppose and deny the prophethood of Muhammad saw, that they will be destroyed gradually (istidraj), has been proven true. The disbelieving Quraysh who fiercely opposed the Prophet Muhammad and his companions suffered defeat in various battles against the Muslims. The Quraysh were deceived by their own greatness and strength. Although they always suffered defeat, they did not realize that they were gradually heading towards destruction.
text.183:
In this verse, Allah affirms that those who deny the truth will gradually receive punishment. Because Allah allows them to live long, prosper, and be capable of warfare, it is not because Allah loves them, but as a deception for them. With the luxury and power they possess, they indulge in injustice, possessing no moral norms except those that suit their desires. They are those who deny religion and disbelieve in Allah. Throughout human history, whether as individuals or as nations, if they act unjustly and oppressively, the end of that injustice is their own destruction. Allah SWT says:

"So leave them in their heedlessness for a time. Do they think that what We extend to them of wealth and children is because We hasten for them good things? Rather, they do not perceive." (al-Muminun/23: 54-55-56)

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Indeed, Allah SWT gives respite (does not immediately inflict punishment) upon the unjust, but when Allah SWT punishes him, He will not let him escape." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Musa)
text.184:
In this verse, Allah condemns the attitude of the Quraysh who deny the Prophet Muhammad, and do not reflect on the realities of the Prophet's own personality. In fact, because of his honesty, he was given the title "Al-Amin" (The Trustworthy) by themselves. Why do they not also reflect on the core of his da'wah, as proof of his prophethood and the verses of the Al-Quran that establish the oneness and power of Allah.

If they were willing to reflect on such things, the truth would surely be apparent to them, and the accusation that Prophet Muhammad was insane would not come out of their mouths. He has been their friend since childhood, and there is not the slightest sign of madness in him, as they themselves have witnessed in the development of his life. Allah tells in the Al-Quran about their accusations with His words:

"Then do they not reflect upon the word (of Allah), or has there come to them what did not come to their forefathers? Or do they not know their Messenger, so they deny him? Or do they say, "He is mad?" But he has come to them with the truth, and most of them are averse to the truth." (al-Muminun/23: 68-69-70)

The word of Allah swt:

And they say, "O you to whom the message has been sent down, indeed you are mad." (al-Hijr/15:6)

The accusation of madness against the Prophet Muhammad by the disbelievers of Mecca was actually a common practice of the disbelievers of ancient times towards their Prophets, such as Prophet Noah, Prophet Moses, and others.

The word of Allah swt:

Similarly, there did not come to those before them any messenger except that they said, "A magician or a madman." (adz-dzariyat/51: 52)

Indeed, Prophet Muhammad is not insane, but he is a Messenger, one who conveys a warning to mankind about the torment and suffering they will experience if they disbelieve in Allah and reject His religion. Prophet Muhammad only advises them that happiness in this world and the hereafter, both for individuals and society, can only be achieved through the religion he brought.
text.185:
In this verse, Allah rebukes those who deny the Messenger. Why do they not observe what exists in the kingdom of the heavens, in the vast expanse of space with millions of stars and a number of planets whose conditions are not yet known with certainty, along with the moons that orbit each of those planets? And why do they not observe what happens on earth, the seas and the land with all the animals and plants that live in both realms? All these creatures, no matter how small, are subject to a neat and definite law, "Who created that law or Sunnah?" If they were to reflect for a moment on the contents of the kingdom of the heavens and the earth, they would surely obtain guidance to affirm the prophethood of Muhammad saw, and they would believe in the verses of the Al-Quran that he brought.

Similarly, if they paid close attention to themselves. Humans, as living beings, will inevitably end in death, sooner or later. Will they face God carrying deeds of evil? The disbelievers will realize how wise it would have been if they had accepted the warnings and teachings brought by the Messenger. What the Messenger brought is actually beneficial for them in this world and the hereafter, namely the belief in the Day of Judgment and the Day of Recompense, good and bad, and the news of life after death. If they do not believe in the teachings of the Al-Quran brought by the Messenger, then is there any other teaching or news that they should believe? If they find no other news or teachings, then the Al-Quran is the only choice and guide for them.
text.186:
Then Allah affirms in this verse that for those whom Allah has led astray, there is no guide for them. A person becomes misguided because they have lost the potential within themselves (fitrah) to receive guidance. This loss of potential is caused by their own negligence in guarding it from the influence and temptations of Satan and their own desires (hawa nafsu). Because of the absence of that potential, their soul does not respond to the contents of the Qur'an when it comes to them. Instead, they have a negative reaction, namely rejecting and not accepting the Qur'an. Even though the Messenger who brings the Qur'an to them possesses noble character and perfect intellect, because they have lost that willingness, the Qur'an remains ineffective on the soul of the person whom Allah has led astray. Their soul has become dark, not receiving the teachings of the Qur'an. Therefore, there is no light of guidance for them.

Their dark heart becomes increasingly dark as a result of evil deeds and transgressions that exceed the limits. Doubt increasingly grips the hearts of such people, and ultimately it becomes difficult for them to find a way out of that misguidance.

Allah SWT says:

"No! Rather, what they used to earn has covered their hearts." (al-Muthaffifin/83: 14)

Every evil deed adds to the darkness of the human heart. A dark heart gives rise to evil deeds again. Thus, the misguided person ultimately revolves in a circle of misguidance. They wallow in the mire of sin and misguidance. They can escape and be saved from this circle of misguidance if they have a strong will to return to the path of Allah and the Divine Light (Nur Ilahi).
text.187:
In this verse, Allah affirms that He alone knows when the Day of Judgment will occur. The certainty of the Day of Judgment and what will happen on that day have been extensively explained by the Al-Quran. However, specifically regarding the timing of the Day of Judgment, it is not explained in the Al-Quran. That knowledge rests solely with Allah.

We can learn from this warning that no human being knows when the Day of Judgment will occur. This means we should not believe in predictions or news that the Day of Judgment will occur on a specific day, date, month, or year, or at a particular time. This warning applies universally to all times. It turns out that even in our time, this often happens, whether in the West, in Africa, or in our own country, there are always people or groups who believe that the Day of Judgment is near, that it will occur at certain times, mentioning when it will happen. Many people believe and are deceived by predictions or news made by people claiming to be religious leaders, resulting in casualties.

Those who asked about the timing of the Day of Judgment were the Quraysh. This verse was revealed in Mecca. In Mecca, there were no Jews who informed and taught the Quraysh about prophethood, the Day of Resurrection, Paradise, and Hell. This is different from the Arabs of Medina, who had interacted extensively with the Jewish people. They already had an understanding of prophethood and the Day of Resurrection.

If the Quraysh asked about the Day of Judgment, it was actually motivated by their assumption that the Day of Judgment was impossible and a false report. Allah describes their thoughts with His words:

"Those who do not believe in the Hour seek to hasten it, but those who believe are fearful of it and know that it is the truth. Unquestionably, those who dispute concerning the Hour are in extreme error." (asy-Syura/42: 18)

Because the content of the question was denial, the Prophet Muhammad was instructed to answer it with a very wise answer. The Prophet answered that the issue of when the Day of Judgment would occur was not a human issue, nor was it the Prophet's issue, but it was Allah's issue alone. Only He knows when the Day of Judgment will occur and how it will happen. The Prophet was tasked by Allah to warn about the certainty of the Day of Judgment and the horrors that will occur at that time, according to the news in the Al-Quran.

The Quraysh wanted to elicit an answer from the Messenger of Allah (saw), and from that answer, they intended to mock and deny him. The secrecy of when the Day of Judgment will occur contains great wisdom for those who believe. They surrender with a submissive heart the issue of what will happen on the Day of Judgment only to Allah. He will unveil the secret, and no one else will accompany Him or be an intermediary with His servants to inform them when the Day of Judgment will occur. The prophets are only tasked with warning about the existence of the Day of Judgment.

Indeed, the Day of Judgment is a heavy burden for the inhabitants of the heavens and the earth, because on that day all their deeds will be accounted for. And it is also difficult for them because they do not know when the Day of Judgment will occur. The Day of Judgment will occur suddenly when they are negligent and unaware. For those who are busy with good deeds and trust in Allah to face the Day of Judgment, whenever that terrible event occurs, they are ready to face it.

Then Allah affirms again to the Prophet Muhammad that the polytheists asked him about the Day of Judgment because they assumed that the Prophet knew about it. If the Prophet did not know, the Prophet could directly ask Allah. So Allah commanded the Prophet again to emphasize that the timing of the Day of Judgment remains a secret of Allah, He alone knows when the Day of Judgment will occur. No one else knows, and no one will be given the knowledge to know why Allah keeps the occurrence of the Day of Judgment a secret and what wisdom is contained in keeping it a secret. And many people do not know what is appropriate to ask and what is not appropriate to ask.

According to Zahir, the Prophet Muhammad did not know when the Day of Judgment would occur, he only knew the nearness of the Day of Judgment.

The Prophet Muhammad (saw) said:

"I was sent and the coming of the Day of Judgment is like these two," while showing his index finger and middle finger. (Narrated by at-Tirmizi)

Meaning the time distance between him and the Day of Judgment is very close like the distance between the two fingers. Even though Allah keeps the timing of the Day of Judgment a secret, Allah has informed the Prophet Muhammad of the signs before the Day of Judgment occurs. As Allah swt says:

"Then do they await except that the Hour should come upon them unexpectedly? But already there have come [some of] its indications. Then what good to them, when it has come, will be their remembrance?" (Muhammad/47: 18)

So a clear sign that the Day of Judgment is near is the sending of the Prophet Muhammad as the last Prophet to mankind. With his rise, the religious guidance by Allah to humans is perfected, meaning that spiritual life and material life are also perfected, but after material life reaches its peak, destruction and annihilation will come.

In the hadith, there are also many signs that explain the occurrence of the Day of Judgment. Among them is the desire of humans to have material possessions or needs that contradict their desire for spiritual satisfaction. At one time, humans prioritize spiritual needs, and material needs are defeated. Then material needs are won again along with the development of error, evil, immorality, and disbelief, until the Day of Judgment comes when humans are wallowing in evil.
text.188:
Then Allah commanded His Messenger to affirm to mankind that all matters in this world, whether beneficial or harmful, originate from Allah. Even Prophet Muhammad, despite his closeness to Allah, did not possess control over benefit and harm, so that he could manage them according to his will.

Initially, the Muslims assumed that every person who became a Messenger would certainly know unseen matters, possess abilities beyond ordinary human capabilities, both to seek some benefit or to ward off some harm for himself or for others. To correct this erroneous view, Allah commanded the Messenger of Allah to explain that the position of a Messenger has no connection with such things. The Messenger is only a giver of guidance and direction; he has no power to create or nullify. What he knows about unseen matters is what Allah has informed him of.

If the Prophet (saw) knew unseen matters, for example, knowing events in the future, surely the Prophet (saw) would prepare himself inwardly and outwardly, morally and materially, to face that event, and surely he would not be afflicted with hardship.

In reality, the Messenger (saw) is an ordinary human being. The difference with ordinary people lies only in the revelation he receives and the task entrusted to him, namely, providing guidance and teaching that Allah has outlined for mankind. The Prophet is only a warner and brings good news to those who believe.
text.189:
In this verse, Allah explains that humankind was created from a single type, and from that single type, its mate was created. Thus, they live as pairs, male and female (husband and wife), and find tranquility with their wives. Living as husband and wife is a natural requirement of human beings, both spiritually and physically. When a person reaches adulthood, the desire to live as husband and wife arises, and they will experience inner turmoil if that desire is not fulfilled. This is because tranquility is realized in the husband-wife relationship. Tranquility will not be realized within a person outside of the husband-wife relationship. Therefore, the purpose of a wife's presence for a man in Islam is to create that paired life itself. Islam prescribes that people live as husband and wife, because in such a living situation, humans find spiritual and physical tranquility and happiness.

When the husband and wife come together, the wife begins to carry the seed. The initial stage of the seed's growth feels light. First, menstruation ceases, and then the seed continues to develop, slowly. Then, when the pregnancy becomes heavy, the parents offer prayers to Allah, asking that they both be granted a righteous child, perfect in body, noble in character, and capable of carrying out their duties and obligations as human beings. Secondly, the wife promises to obligate herself to be grateful to Allah for receiving that blessing through words, deeds, and belief.
text.190: Allah answered the prayer of the husband and wife by bestowing upon them a righteous child. But then they were not grateful to Allah for that blessing; rather, they attributed the righteous child to idols, saying that the child was a servant of statues, or they associated the child with animals or nature. They did not say that the child was a gift from Allah. Therefore, they were not grateful to Allah. Exalted is Allah above what they associate with Him.
text.191:
Then, in this verse, Allah strongly condemns the attitude, thoughts, and behavior of those who worship idols that cannot create anything, even things of low value, because the idols themselves are made by human hands. It is not appropriate for people with minds to make these idols objects of worship, whether they are seen as partners of Allah in receiving worship or as intermediaries between humans and Allah. Because all praise or worship to other than Allah is of no benefit whatsoever. Allah SWT says:

"O people, an example is presented, so listen to it. Indeed, those you invoke besides Allah will never create [as much as] a fly, even if they gathered together for that purpose. And if the fly should steal away from them a [tiny] thing, they could not recover it from him. Weak are the pursuer and pursued." (al-Hajj/22: 73)
text.192: This verse, like the previous verses, describes idol worshippers in general, including the polytheism of Arab Mecca. Allah explains that the objects of worship of the polytheists have no ability whatsoever, neither to provide help to themselves when an enemy attacks the worshippers, nor when they are struck by disaster; the idols cannot provide assistance. Even if someone were to defile the idols or steal their jewelry, surely the idol could not defend itself. Thus, the idols are only worshipped and defended, but the worship receives no reward whatsoever from the idol.
text.193:
In this verse, Allah SWT states to the polytheists that if they were to ask those idols to guide them, just as they ask Allah to grant them goodness, those idols would certainly not be able to guide them to the path that leads to their aspirations or to the path that leads to their salvation from the difficulties and hardships that befall them. Those idols cannot fulfill their desires, nor can they grant their requests. It is all the same whether the idol worshippers ask something of the idol or whether they ask for nothing. The idol will not understand their requests, will not hear, and will not contemplate what is said to them.

Is it fitting that something possessing the above characteristics should be worshipped? What should be worshipped is Allah, Who benefits those who worship Him, Who punishes those who disobey Him, Who destroys His enemies, Who guides those who are obedient to Him, and Who listens to the prayers of those who pray to Him.
text.194:
In this verse, it is emphasized that the objects of worship besides Allah, which are the destination of the prayers of the polytheists, are actually creatures like themselves. Prayer is a hope and request from the person who utters it to anyone they deem to have greater power than them to fulfill that hope, whether to obtain benefits or to ward off hardship and loss. Why do they offer prayers to idols that are actually creatures of Allah like themselves, who are subject to the power and will of Allah SWT? It is very illogical for them to ask those idols for something that they themselves, and also the idols, cannot achieve. They should pray to Allah, the Creator and Regulator of all causes and effects in this universe. All inanimate and living things in this universe are subject to His Sunnah.

However, if the polytheists believe that their belief is correct, that the idols are able to provide benefits or ward off harm that humans are unable to do, let them pray to the idols if that prayer can indeed be answered by the idols. Truly misguided are the thoughts of those who consider inanimate objects to have power and strength like their Creator God.
text.195:
In this verse, Allah warns those who worship these objects that these idols are not only not equal to them but are even lower than them. These idols do not possess bodily attributes such as legs, hands, eyes, and so on, which can grant the requests and demands of their worshippers. These objects are not like their worshippers, who are in a more perfect and complete state. This warning from Allah is a mockery and humiliation of the polytheists, but the polytheists are not aware of their own condition; instead, they feel arrogant and conceited. They refuse to accept guidance and lessons from the Messenger (peace be upon him) on the grounds that the Messenger is a human being. They said to each other about the humanity of the Messenger, as Allah states:

"And if you were to obey a human being like yourselves, indeed, you would then be losers." (al-Muminun/23: 34)

Herein lies the absurdity of their thinking. They reject the Messenger because he is a human being. Whereas the Messenger (peace be upon him) has superior knowledge, wisdom, and guidance from Allah compared to other human beings. They prioritize idols over a Messenger. They even elevate idols and objects of worship to the level of gods. Therefore, Allah commands the Messenger to challenge them by saying to them that if their idols truly have power, let them unite to destroy the Messenger (peace be upon him). They do not need to give the Messenger (peace be upon him) a chance to destroy them first. Such a challenge would not have been uttered by the Prophet (peace be upon him) if his faith in Allah's help was not truly certain.

Such a challenge must be uttered. Because proofs and scientific reasons are no longer useful in demonstrating the falsehood of the beliefs of the Arab polytheist society. Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) was commanded to ask them to have their idols destroy Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Such a challenge is enough to make the hearts of the idol worshippers tremble.
text.196: This verse explains the continuation of Prophet Muhammad's speech before the polytheists, namely that indeed Allah is his protector, the One who manages his affairs, and the One who is his helper. Allah is the One who revealed the Al-Quran, which explains His Oneness and obligates mankind to devote themselves and pray to Him in all circumstances. The Al-Quran also exposes the errors and falsehood of idol worship. Therefore, the Messenger of Allah (saw) did not pay attention to those idols and was not afraid of them, even though the polytheists threatened him with those idols. Allah will also give His help and protection to His righteous servants, namely those who possess a pure soul thanks to the purity of their creed, and from the purity of that soul are born noble deeds, useful for personal and community life.
text.197:
Allah SWT reaffirms to the polytheists that the idols they hope for help from cannot do anything, not even help themselves, let alone help others. Neither to give benefit nor to ward off harm, as was done by Prophet Ibrahim AS. He destroyed the idols of his people, shattering them into pieces. The idols could not defend themselves or take revenge.

It is narrated by Ibn Kathir that Muaz bin Amr bin al-Jamuh and Muaz bin Jabal RA embraced Islam when the Prophet Muhammad arrived in Medina. Both were still young. One night they went to destroy the idols of the polytheists and used them as firewood for the widows. The intention was for their people to know and learn from the event.

His father, named Amr bin al-Jamuh, a tribal chief, had an idol that he always worshipped and perfumed. One night, the two young men came to the idol. Then they turned the idol upside down, put its head down, and smeared it with human excrement. The next day, Amr bin Al Jamuh came to the place of his worshipped idol and saw what had happened. He then cleaned the idol and perfumed it, then placed a sword beside it. He said to the idol: "Defend yourself." But the next day the two young men returned to repeat their actions, and the old man returned to do the same again.

Finally, the two young men took the idol and tied it together with a dead dog, then placed it near a well close to the place. Then, when the old man came again and saw what had happened to his idol, he realized that the religion he had followed all this time was a false religion. Then Amr bin Jamuh embraced Islam and became a good Muslim. He died as a martyr in the Battle of Uhud (See Tafsir Ibn Kathir, volume 2, page 277).
text.198: In this verse, Allah states again that even if the polytheists ask those idols to give them guidance, those idols will not hear the request. This is because those objects do not have hearing, even though they have ears. The polytheists see those idols looking at them, even though they do not see, because those idols do not have sight, even though they have eyes carved by their makers.
text.199:
In this verse, Allah commands His Messenger to adhere firmly to the general principles of morality and law.

1.  An Attitude of Forgiveness and Open-mindedness

Allah swt commands His Messenger to forgive and be open-minded towards the actions, behavior, and morals of people, and not to demand from them what is very difficult for them, causing them to flee from the religion.

The Messenger of Allah saw said:

"Make things easy, do not make things difficult, and give glad tidings, do not cause distress." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Musa and Muadz)

Included in the principles of religion is making things easy, avoiding difficulties, and everything that troubles people. Similarly, in the field of human character, much is influenced by the environment. In fact, many narrations state that what is intended by forgiveness here is forgiveness in the field of morals or character (Tafsir Ibn Kathir in the commentary of the verse).

The Messenger of Allah said in connection with this verse:

"Is this so, O Gabriel?" Gabriel replied, "Indeed, Allah has commanded you to forgive those who wrong you, to give to those who refuse to give to you, and to maintain relations with those who sever them." (Narrated by Ibn Jarir and Ibn Abi Hatim, from Ibn Ubay from his father)

2.  Enjoining Good (Ma'ruf) on People

The meaning of *urf* in this verse is *ma'ruf*. As for *ma'ruf*, it is the good customs of society that do not contradict the teachings of Islam. In the Al-Quran, the word "ma'ruf" is used in relation to important laws, such as in the laws of government and marriage. In the sense of society, the word "ma'ruf" is used in the sense of customs and *muamalah* in a society. Therefore, it varies according to differences in nation, country, and time. Among the scholars, some define "ma'ruf" as what is considered good to do according to pure human nature, not contrary to sound reason. For Muslims, the main thing is to adhere firmly to the strong *nash* from the Al-Quran and Sunnah. Then, to pay attention to the customs and norms that exist in society as long as they do not clearly contradict the *nash* of religion.

3.  Ignoring the Disturbances of the Ignorant

What is meant by the ignorant are those who are always rude and cause disturbances to the Prophets, and cannot be made aware. Allah commands His Messenger to avoid the ignorant, not to serve them, and not to repay their violence with violence.
text.200:
In this verse, Allah explains the possibility of Prophet Muhammad being tempted by Satan, leading him to be unable to implement the aforementioned principles. Therefore, Allah commands His Messenger to always seek refuge in Allah when the groups of Satan come, by reciting "Taawwuz," which is:

"I seek refuge in Allah from Satan, the accursed."

Allah SWT is All-Hearing of every supplication uttered and All-Knowing of what crosses a person's mind, which can drive him to commit evil or mistakes. If the tempted person recites this prayer with a sincere heart and a pure submission to Allah, then Allah will drive Satan away from him and protect him from Satan's temptations.

Allah SWT says:

"So when you recite the Quran, seek refuge with Allah from Satan, the accursed. Indeed, he has no authority over those who have believed and rely upon their Lord." (an-Nahl/16:98-99)

The Prophet Muhammad SAW said:

"There is none among you but has been assigned to him a companion from among the jinn." The Companions said: "Even you, O Messenger of Allah?" He replied, "Even me, but Allah has helped me against him and he has submitted, so he only enjoins me to do good." (Narrated by Muslim from Aisyah RA and Ibn Masud)

Although the command in this verse is addressed to the Messenger, this command encompasses all of his followers in this world.
text.201:
In this verse, Allah explains the reaction of those who are pious when tempted by Satan. This verse also reinforces the previous verse about the necessity of seeking refuge in Allah from the temptations of Satan.

Indeed, those who are pious are those who believe in the unseen, establish prayer, and spend a portion of their sustenance. When they feel an urge within themselves to commit evil, they immediately realize that it is a temptation from Satan, and they immediately utter the *isti'adzah* prayer and surrender themselves to Allah to be protected from Satan's cunning. Thanks to that awareness, they are spared from the abyss of destruction and the snares of Satan, because they can restrain themselves from falling into Satan's trap, while those who fall into Satan's trap are only those who are heedless of Allah and lack self-awareness.

The most powerful weapon to repel Satan is remembrance and *muraqabah* (drawing near) to Allah in all circumstances. Constant remembrance of Allah will instill in the soul a love of truth and virtue, weakening negative/bad tendencies. A soul filled with faith is a healthy soul. A healthy soul is like a healthy body that has immunity. A body that has immunity, a strong body, is not easily attacked by disease. Bacteria and germs cannot thrive in a body full of immunity. Likewise, the soul of a pious person is not easily defeated by Satan's temptations. A pious person immediately reacts to the stimuli of Satan that arise within him. This reaction takes the form of remembrance of Allah accompanied by awareness of Satan's cunning and all its consequences.

Maintaining a healthy soul from Satan's temptations is the same as maintaining a healthy body, which requires continuous care to keep it clean and healthy, requiring constant *muraqabah*, remembering Allah in all circumstances. Thus, Satan does not get a chance to disturb oneself.
text.202: This verse explains that ignorant and disbelieving people help Satan in misleading and causing corruption. This is because these ignorant people are always influenced by Satan and do not remember Allah. If animalistic desires arise within them, they indulge them in the form of animalistic actions and deeds. There is no strength of soul to restrain these animalistic desires. Therefore, they continuously commit corruption and wallow in error.
text.203:
This verse explains the behavior of Satan's companions in their efforts to oppose the Prophet Muhammad. When revelation did not come to the Prophet Muhammad due to a delay in the verses being revealed, the polytheists urged the Prophet Muhammad to create the verses himself. Their urging actually implied a denial of the Quran revealed by Allah to the Prophet Muhammad. Because they viewed the Quran as merely the creation of the Prophet Muhammad, it could be made at any time. Therefore, Allah commanded the Prophet to explain to them that the Quran is Allah's revelation revealed to him. The Prophet only follows what is revealed to him. It is not his right to urge Allah to create something; the Prophet can only wait for the revelation that will be conveyed to him, to be conveyed to his people as well. If there is no revelation, he may not change the Quran himself because the Quran is the word of Allah, and it has three functions for believers as explained by Allah in this verse.

First,

As a clear proof from Allah to demonstrate His oneness, the prophethood of Muhammad, and the Day of Judgment. Whoever pays attention to and contemplates the contents of the Quran will surely be convinced that the Quran is from Allah SWT.

Second,

As guidance or a guideline that guides humans in seeking truth and the straight path.

Third,

As a mercy in human life, both in this world and the hereafter, for those who believe. The Quran provides regulations and teachings that are easy to understand and easy for Muslims to implement in their daily lives.
text.204:
It is narrated from Abu Hurairah that this verse was revealed because the companions prayed behind the Messenger of Allah while talking. In this verse, Allah commands the believers to pay serious attention to the Quran. They should listen as well as possible or to its contents in order to understand it, take lessons from it, and practice it sincerely.

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said:

"Whoever listens (attentively) to a verse from the Quran, manifold good deeds will be written for him, and whoever reads it, it will be a light for him on the Day of Judgment." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Imam Ahmad from Abu Hurairah)

Believers should be calm when the Quran is recited, because it is in that calmness that they can contemplate its contents. Their minds should not wander when the Quran is being recited, so that they cannot understand the verses well. Allah will bestow His mercy upon the Muslims if they fulfill Allah's command and appreciate the contents of the Quran.

There are several opinions regarding the command to listen and be calm when the Quran is recited:

1.  It is obligatory to listen and be calm when the Quran is recited based on this command, whether in prayer or outside of prayer. This is the opinion of Hasan al-Bashri and Abu Muslim al-Ashfahani.

2.  It is obligatory to listen and be calm, but specifically to the recitations of the Messenger (peace and blessings be upon him) in his time and the recitations of the Imam in prayer, as well as the recitations of the khatib in the Friday sermon.

3.  Listening to the recitation of the Quran outside of prayer and the khutbah, such as at receptions, is considered highly recommended so that we may receive Allah's mercy.
text.205:
In this verse, Allah commands the Messenger and his followers to mention the name of Allah or remember Him (dhikr). This dhikr can be through reciting the Quran, tasbih (saying Subhanallah), tahlil (saying La ilaha illallah), supplication (dua), or other praises according to religious guidance, with humility (tadharru) and a gentle voice at all times, especially morning and evening, so that we are not among the heedless. Then, Allah outlines for us the etiquette and manner of performing dhikr or mentioning the name of Allah as follows:

1. The best dhikr is performed with a gentle voice, because this makes it easier to lead to good contemplation (tafakur).

It is narrated that on a journey, the Prophet heard people supplicating with a loud voice. He said to them:

"O people, have mercy on yourselves, for you are not calling upon one who is deaf or far away from you. Indeed, the One you are calling upon is Allah, the All-Hearing and the Near. He is closer to you than the neck (of the camel) of your mount." (Narrated by Ibn Majah)

2. Dhikr can be performed in the heart or with the tongue, because dhikr in the heart shows sincerity (ikhlas), is far from showing off (riya), and is close to the pleasure of Allah SWT. Dhikr can be performed with the tongue, the tongue uttering and the heart following.

3. Dhikr can also be performed in congregation (jamaah), with the aim of educating the community to become accustomed to performing dhikr.
text.206:
In this verse, Allah explains that the angels, who hold a noble position in the sight of God, do not feel burdened or reluctant to worship Allah. Mankind should emulate the obedience of these angels to God. The angels are always sanctifying Allah from attributes that are not befitting of Him, and from worshipping idols. The angels prostrate and pray to Allah SWT.

This verse is the first *ayat sajadah* in the Quran. It is recommended for Muslims to perform *sujud* after reading or hearing this verse recited.

Abu Darda narrated the following:

"Indeed, the Messenger of Allah SAW considered this verse to be one of the *ayat sajadah* in the Quran." (Narrated by Ibn Majah)
